questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, presents with heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) and severe dysmenorrhea (DM) that has been progressively worsening since the birth of her youngest child 3 years ago. Her menstrual cycles are regular, occurring once every 24 to 25 days. They last 7 to 9 days, and she soaks through at least one to two pads every 2 hours for the first 4 days of bleeding. She has no intermenstrual bleeding. She denies constipation, urinary symptoms, and pelvic pain or pressure outside of menses. Her medical history is notable for two prior uncomplicated cesarean births. The operative reports, reviewed in the electronic medical record, describe a “grossly normal appearing uterus” in both instances. Family and social histories are noncontributory, and the patient takes no medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. A pelvic exam shows a globally enlarged, boggy uterus with a smooth contour and mild tenderness to palpation. No discrete masses are palpable, and the adnexa are both normal in size and nontender. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Multiple endometrial implants within the myometrium
Multiple encapsulated areas of monoclonal myometrial proliferation
Multiple endometrial implants on the uterine serosal and pelvic peritoneal surfaces
Multiple abnormal endometrial growths around vascularized stalks
Diffuse endometrial inflammation affecting normal endometrial hemostatic mechanisms

questions.solution:
This patient presents with heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) and dysmenorrhea (DM) that is secondary to adenomyosis based on the findings described in the vignette. Adenomyosis is caused by the implantation of endometrial glands within myometrial tissue, resulting in significant pain and bleeding during regular menses. The uterus may be mildly tender even outside of menses, which can lead to chronic pelvic pain and/or dyspareunia in some patients. Risk factors for adenomyosis include a history of uterine surgery, shorter menstrual cycles (≤ 25 days), and early menarche. On exam, the uterus may be globally enlarged and is often described as globular or boggy (i.e., the uterus feels squishy). Because there are no large masses, the uterus retains a smooth contour on exam.        

Pelvic ultrasound should be performed in patients who present with HMB. It can provide valuable information about the presence or absence of potential structural causes of HMB, including adenomyosis. Adenomyosis is suggested on ultrasound by a heterogeneously thickened myometrium, myometrial cysts, subendometrial lines radiating into the myometrium, and an irregular endo-myometrial junction. A summary of the history, exam, and ultrasound findings in patients with abnormal uterine bleeding is detailed in the table below.      



Option Analysis

✅ Multiple endometrial implants within the myometrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multiple encapsulated areas of monoclonal myometrial proliferation:
Incorrect: This describes uterine leiomyomas. Leiomyomas can also present with HMB and DM, but multiple leiomyomas tend to create an irregular rather than a smooth uterine contour.  
❌ Multiple endometrial implants on the uterine serosal and pelvic peritoneal surfaces:
Incorrect: This describes endometriosis, which presents with DM and/or pelvic pain symptoms. However, HMB and an enlarged uterus are not directly caused by endometriosis. 
❌ Multiple abnormal endometrial growths around vascularized stalks:
Incorrect: This describes endometrial polyps. Endometrial polyps can lead to HMB, but intermenstrual bleeding is also common, which this patient does not have. They also do not globally enlarge the uterus; rather, they result in a thickened endometrial stripe on imaging. 
❌ Diffuse endometrial inflammation affecting normal endometrial hemostatic mechanisms:
Incorrect: This describes chronic endometritis, which can be a cause of abnormal uterine bleeding. Patients are more likely to experience irregular and/or intermenstrual bleeding, and endometrial dysfunction does not enlarge the uterus.

questions.text: A 23-year-old nulligravid woman presents to her gynecologist for evaluation of chronic pelvic discomfort. The patient has a history of severe dysmenorrhea that has worsened over the past year. Her menstrual cycles are regular, coming once every 26 days, with average flow and lasting five days, without intermenstrual bleeding. She is not currently sexually active and does not desire pregnancy in the near future. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals normal physiologic vaginal discharge and tenderness to palpation of the posterior vaginal fornix. A pelvic ultrasound is normal, and a urine pregnancy test is negative. In addition to ibuprofen, which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a likely diagnosis of endometriosis based on her history of worsening dysmenorrhea, tenderness in the posterior cul-de-sac on exam, and no identifiable alternative etiology on pelvic sonography. Endometriosis refers to the ectopic implantation of endometrial tissue outside of the endometrial cavity. It can present with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, chronic pelvic pain, and/or infertility. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) analgesia plus combined hormonal contraceptive therapy is considered first-line treatment for patients with a clinical diagnosis of endometriosis who do not desire immediate pregnancy.

Endometriosis management is determined by a patient’s desire for future fertility, severity of symptoms, treatment goals, and personal preferences. Patients who are attempting to become pregnant and present with infertility should have a full infertility evaluation, receive anti-inflammatory analgesia (NSAIDs) and pelvic floor physical therapy, and consider laparoscopy for both definitive diagnosis and surgical treatment of the disease.

Patients who do not have an immediate desire for pregnancy should be treated with analgesia and combined hormonal contraceptive therapy to reduce endometriosis-associated inflammatory pain and suppress the growth of ectopic endometrial tissue. For patients who do not respond to this initial treatment, alternative hormonal options should be considered, including GnRH analogs or progestins (e.g. medroxyprogesterone acetate, norethindrone acetate, levonorgestrel intrauterine device). These patients should also be considered for laparoscopy. Aromatase inhibitors and hysterectomy are options in patients with recalcitrant disease.

Option Analysis

✅ Combined oral contraceptive pills:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Leuprolide :
Incorrect: Leuprolide, a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist, is reserved for patients with endometriosis who do not respond to treatment with combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
❌ Pelvic MRI:
Incorrect: Pelvic MRI is used to better characterize gynecologic diseases in patients with equivalent ultrasound findings. However, most endometriosis lesions are not visible on pelvic ultrasound or MRI and empiric treatment is started based on clinical diagnosis.
❌ Laparoscopy:
Incorrect: Diagnostic laparoscopy and surgical removal of ectopic endometrial tissue is typically reserved for patients with endometriosis who do not respond to combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or for those who want to become pregnant immediately or in the near future.
❌ Anastrozole:
Incorrect: Anastrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is reserved for recalcitrant disease in patients with an inadequate response to NSAIDs, hormonal contraceptives, and/or laparoscopy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2P1, presents to the emergency department with progressive, right sided, lower abdominal pain for the past 18 hours and light vaginal spotting. The pain is sharp and intermittent. She does not have fever, chills, diarrhea, dysuria, dizziness, or shoulder pain. She has had mild nausea without vomiting for the past two weeks. Her last menstrual period was seven weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner without the use of contraception. Past surgical history is significant for appendectomy at age 10. She had one vaginal delivery two years ago and was treated for a chlamydia infection three years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Pelvic examination reveals a 6 cm uterus, right adnexal fullness without a discrete mass, and cervical motion tenderness. Qualitative hCG is positive. Which of the following would most likely be seen with serial quantitative hCG testing?

choices.text: Initial hCG level of 2,100 mIU/mL, hCG level of 2,550 mIU/mL after 48 hours
Initial hCG level of 200,000 mIU/mL and 358,000 mIU/mL after 48 hours

questions.solution:
This patient presents seven weeks after her last menstrual period with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting and with pelvic examination findings of right adnexal fullness and cervical motion tenderness (indicating pelvic pathology). The most likely diagnosis is a tubal ectopic pregnancy, which is the most common type of ectopic pregnancy. This patient has several risk factors for ectopic pregnancy, including previous abdominal surgery and a previous STI. An initial hCG level of 2,100 mIU/mL that increases to 2,550 mIU/mL after 48 hours would be consistent with this diagnosis.    

HCG is produced by placental trophoblast cells. In the presence of a normal pregnancy, levels should rise by at least 53% in 48 hours and double every 48 to 72 hours until reaching a peak at 10 weeks. Since there is significant variability in the levels, the pattern of change is very important. In an ectopic pregnancy, serial hCG levels rise more slowly than expected in a normal pregnancy, and they may plateau or even decrease. However, in about one third of ectopic pregnancies, hCG levels may rise appropriately.    

Falling or abnormally rising serum levels of hCG are diagnostic of an abnormal early pregnancy, either a failed intrauterine gestation or an ectopic pregnancy. It is important to consider clinical context, ultrasound findings, along with the level and trend of hCG over time.       

Option Analysis

❌  Initial hCG level of 8,700 mIU/mL, hcG level of 15,660 mIU/mL after 48 hours  :
Incorrect: These hCG levels can be seen with a threatened miscarriage, where there is normal increase in hCG consistent with normal pregnancy but vaginal bleeding through a closed cervical os is present. In a threatened miscarriage, hCG levels can rise appropriately with at least a 53% rise in 48 hours, similar to a normal pregnancy. However, this patient’s clinical presentation and pelvic examination findings suggest an ectopic pregnancy.  
✅ Initial hCG level of 2,100 mIU/mL, hCG level of 2,550 mIU/mL after 48 hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initial hCG level of 1,200 mIU/mL, hCG level of 1,080 mIU/L after 48 hours :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a missed miscarriage where the fetus has either not developed or has been lost but has not been expelled from the uterus. hCG levels may be lower than expected at a specific gestational age, may not double appropriately and may plateau or decrease. This patient’s clinical presentation suggests an ectopic pregnancy.
❌  Initial hCG level of 3,250 mIU/mL, hCG level of 1,625 mIU/mL after 48 hours :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a complete miscarriage, which occurs when all pregnancy tissue has been expelled. HCG falling by 50% is consistent with the absence of any hCG producing tissue and the known half-life of hCG. This patient’s clinical presentation suggests an ectopic pregnancy. 
❌ Initial hCG level of 200,000 mIU/mL and 358,000 mIU/mL after 48 hours:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a molar pregnancy where abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic tissue causes significantly higher than expected levels of hCG for a specific gestational age as well as hCG levels that are rising faster than expected.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, is admitted to the hospital in labor and ready to begin pushing. Her previous pregnancies resulted in spontaneous vaginal deliveries of infants whose birth weights were normal. Her body mass index (BMI) prior to pregnancy was 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her cervix is 10 cm dilated, 100% effaced, and grossly ruptured membranes. The fetal head delivers after 130 minutes but immediately retracts against the perineum. Gentle downward traction of the head does not deliver the shoulders. Which of the following clinical features, if present, would be the strongest risk factor for the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: 35 lb. of maternal weight gain during pregnancy
A prolonged active phase of labor
Delivery at 41 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA)

questions.solution:
This woman, who presents with retraction of the fetal head against the perineum (turtle sign) and with shoulders that do not deliver with gentle downward traction, has shoulder dystocia. This is an obstetric emergency caused by impaction of the fetal shoulders on the bony pelvis, preventing delivery of the body after delivery of the head. Gestational diabetes (GDM) more than doubles the risk of shoulder dystocia compared to non-diabetic individuals.    

Other major risk factors include a history of prior delivery complicated by shoulder dystocia and fetal macrosomia, which is defined as a fetus with an estimated fetal weight of > 4000 to 4500 grams (definitions vary). Conditions associated with macrosomia are also generally considered risk factors for shoulder dystocia, including GDM, obesity, excessive maternal weight gain, and post-term pregnancy. Importantly, GDM also increases the risk of a higher fetal shoulder-to-head ratio, further increasing the risk regardless of fetal weight. Intrapartum, a prolonged second stage of labor, and assisted vaginal delivery (e.g., forceps or vacuum) are both associated to lesser degrees than with other conditions with shoulder dystocia.        

Despite these known risk factors, there is no way to accurately predict when shoulder dystocia will occur. In 50% of cases, no risk factors are identified, and birthweight is <4000 grams. In addition, most patients with risk factors do not experience shoulder dystocia. However, physicians should be more vigilant when any risk factors are present.       

Option Analysis

❌ 35 lb. of maternal weight gain during pregnancy :
Incorrect: Obesity and excessive maternal weight gain are modest risk factors for shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. However, in a patient like this one with a normal pre-pregnancy BMI, 25 to 35 lbs. of weight gain is recommended, so 35 lbs. of weight gain would be normal for this patient and not be a risk factor for shoulder dystocia.  
❌ A prolonged active phase of labor :
Incorrect: A prolonged 2nd stage of labor, not active phase, should raise suspicion of shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. There is no significant link between shoulder dystocia and a prolonged active phase, referring to dilation from 6 to 10 cm in the first stage of labor.  
❌ Delivery at 41 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA):
Incorrect: Post-term pregnancy, defined as pregnancy extending beyond 42 weeks EGA, is associated with an increased risk of shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. However, at term, gestational diabetes would be a more significant risk factor for shoulder dystocia than an EGA of 41 weeks. 
✅ Gestational diabetes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gestational hypertension:
Incorrect: Gestational hypertension is not associated with shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy are more often associated with fetal growth restriction, which reduces the risk of shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2 at 41 weeks' gestation, is undergoing induction of labor for pre-labor rupture of membranes (PROM). She experienced rupture of membranes 24 hours ago, and spontaneous labor did not occur with expectant management. She has received regular prenatal care, and this pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her previous pregnancy was also uncomplicated and resulted in a vaginal delivery of an infant at term whose weight was within normal limits. Past medical and surgical histories are unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is 10 cm dilated and 100% effaced. The presentation is cephalic at station 0 cm. After 20 minutes of pushing, the head delivers. The shoulders do not deliver with gentle downward traction. Which of the following clinical signs is indicative of the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of the patient in the vignette is consistent with shoulder dystocia, which is a clinical diagnosis made when the fetal shoulders fail to deliver with gentle downward traction of the fetal head, and additional maneuvers are required to effect delivery of the body. The presence of the turtle sign is indicative of shoulder dystocia and describes the retraction of the fetal head against the perineum. The name comes from the resemblance to a turtle withdrawing into its shell.    

Shoulder dystocia occurs when the anterior shoulder becomes impacted behind the mother’s symphysis pubis or, less commonly, when the posterior shoulder becomes impacted on the sacral promontory, preventing further fetal descent. In this position, the fetal chest and abdomen are compressed within the pelvis, preventing both expansion of the lungs and perfusion through the umbilical cord, which can rapidly lead to fetal hypoxia.    

Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency that requires prompt recognition and management to prevent neonatal complications such as brachial plexus injury or fetal asphyxia. All obstetrical care providers should be prepared for potential shoulder dystocia at every delivery, as 50% of patients with shoulder dystocia have no identifiable risk factors.    

Option Analysis

❌ Chadwick sign:
Incorrect: Chadwick sign is the bluish discoloration of the cervix and vagina from increased vascularity of the stroma. It is often seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. Although pregnancy-related, it is not related to shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. 
❌ Goodell sign:
Incorrect: The Goodell sign describes the softening of the pregnant cervix from edema. It is a normal early sign of pregnancy detected with palpation. It is not associated with shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. 
✅ Turtle sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acanthosis nigricans:
Incorrect: Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques in intertriginous areas. It is associated with insulin resistance. Although gestational diabetes is a risk factor for shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis in the vignette, acanthosis nigricans, is not diagnostic of shoulder dystocia.
❌ Homan sign:
Incorrect: The Homan sign refers to calf pain with dorsiflexion of the foot. It can indicate deep vein thrombosis. Although pregnant women are at a higher risk of venous thromboembolism when compared to non-pregnant women, there is no connection to shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the clinic for a follow-up appointment for vulvar pruritus. She was previously diagnosed with lichen sclerosus and has been using topical clobetasol propionate as prescribed. She reports significant improvement in her symptoms, with decreased pruritus and stabilization of the skin changes. She has no new complaints and is interested in discussing the future management of her condition. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the vulvar skin shows signs of chronic inflammation but no erosions, ulcerations, or other suspicious lesions. The rest of her examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with improvement of skin findings and symptoms after appropriate therapy for lichen sclerosus. Because this is a chronic condition with recurrences and can be associated with the development of vulvar squamous cell carcinoma, routine follow-up and monitoring is recommended.        

Lichen sclerosus is a chronic, progressive, inflammatory skin condition that results in skin atrophy and scarring. Although it can occur at any age, it is more common in prepubertal and postmenopausal populations. The exact cause of lichen sclerosus is unknown, but potential risk factors include autoimmune conditions, genetic predisposition, and hormonal imbalances. Symptoms typically include intense pruritus, discomfort, and pain. Physical examination often reveals white, patchy skin that is thinner than normal. The affected skin may also have bruises, tears, or blisters, and in advanced cases, it can lead to scarring and significant changes in the architecture of the genitals.        

The primary treatment for lichen sclerosus involves topical corticosteroids, which help in reducing inflammation, alleviating symptoms, and preventing further skin damage. Regular follow-up is crucial because lichen sclerosus can lead to complications, such as scarring. There is also a small but significant risk of developing vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Hence, ongoing monitoring (every 6–12 months) is recommended, even after symptoms and skin changes are controlled.      



 Caption: Vulvar squamous cell carcinoma which developed several years after a woman was diagnosed with lichen sclerosus.    CC by 2.0 Openi    https://openi.nlm.nih.gov/detailedresult?img=PMC4564427_PAMJ-21-48-g001&query=lichen%20sclerosus&it=xg&lic=by&req=4&npos=45   

Option Analysis

✅ 6-month follow-up and monitoring:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ No further management is required.:
Incorrect: Lichen sclerosus has a chronic course and places the patient at an increased risk for vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia and squamous cell carcinoma. Thus, patients should have routine follow-up examinations to monitor for signs of malignancy. 
❌ Referral for surgery:
Incorrect: Surgical intervention is typically reserved for cases of lichen sclerosus with severe scarring leading to anatomical changes or when malignancy is suspected. This patient has a stable disease with no evidence of complications that would warrant surgical intervention. 
❌ Discontinuation of therapy and observation:
Incorrect: Discontinuing treatment after achieving control of symptoms in lichen sclerosus is not recommended because the condition is chronic and can flare. Maintenance use of topical corticosteroids at the lowest effective dose is often necessary to maintain symptom control and prevent progression. 
❌ Transition to systemic corticosteroid therapy:
Incorrect: Systemic corticosteroids are generally not used for the management of lichen sclerosus. They are reserved for severe cases or cases not responding to topical treatment. This patient’s symptoms are well-controlled with topical therapy, making systemic treatment unnecessary and potentially exposing her to unnecessary side effects.

questions.text: A 25-year-old non-binary person, assigned female at birth, gravida 0, presents to the emergency department with 2 hours of sudden-onset, severe left lower quadrant pain unrelieved by ibuprofen. The symptoms are associated with nausea, but without vomiting. Review of systems is otherwise negative. Past medical history is notable for prior use of intramuscular testosterone injections for twelve months at age 20. The patient takes no oral medications but has a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (IUD) in place for contraception and menstrual suppression. Temperature is 36.5 °C (97.7 °F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mmHg. On exam, the patient has exquisite tenderness in the left lower quadrant, with rebound tenderness and guarding. A bimanual exam reveals a tender, enlarged left adnexa. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Pelvic ultrasound shows an 8 cm complex left adnexal mass with heterogeneous contents, an echogenic nodule with posterior shadowing, fat fluid levels, and absent blood flow to the adnexa on Doppler exam. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has signs and symptoms of ovarian torsion, which refers to the twisting of the ovary around its vascular pedicles, leading to a compromised blood supply and potentially resulting in necrosis. Patients typically present with severe, unilateral pelvic pain with acute onset and signs of an acute abdomen, including rebound tenderness and guarding. Torsion occurs most often in the setting of an ovarian mass, which can be seen on ultrasound. Additionally, a lack of blood flow to the adnexa on Doppler ultrasound strongly suggests the diagnosis. Ovarian torsion is a surgical emergency, and the preferred procedure is typically operative laparoscopy.

The mass present on this patient’s ultrasound is consistent with a mature cystic teratoma, also called a dermoid cyst. These cystic masses are benign germ cell neoplasms that contain differentiated cells from all three embryological cell layers. They often contain sebaceous material, hair, skin, and teeth, and are most prevalent among biological females in the second and third decades of life. Due to the heterogeneous and asymmetric distribution of their contents, dermoid cysts, especially larger ones, significantly increase the risk of ovarian torsion. Dermoid cysts can typically be diagnosed on ultrasound, and findings include a cystic mass with heterogeneous contents, fat-fluid levels, thick internal echoes, and an echogenic nodule with posterior shadowing.   

Option Analysis

✅ Operative laparoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ CA-125:
Incorrect: This patient has signs and symptoms of ovarian torsion and ultrasound findings that suggest a mature cystic teratoma. CA-125 is indicated in patients with risk factors or ultrasound findings concerning ovarian cancer, which this patient lacks. 
❌ Pelvic MRI:
Incorrect: A pelvic MRI can provide additional details in patients with a suspicious ovarian mass. This patient has signs and symptoms of ovarian torsion and ultrasound findings that suggest a mature cystic teratoma. Urgent surgery is indicated, and pelvic MRI findings would not change management. 
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: This patient has signs and symptoms of ovarian torsion and ultrasound findings that suggest a mature cystic teratoma. Urgent surgery is indicated, with operative laparoscopy preferred over laparotomy. 
❌ Supportive care and observation:
Incorrect: This patient has signs and symptoms of ovarian torsion and ultrasound findings that suggest a mature cystic teratoma. Urgent surgery is indicated, so observation is not appropriate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of worsening pelvic pressure and bloating. Her last menstrual period was 10 years ago, and she has not had postmenopausal bleeding. She has no nausea or vomiting, but does note recent constipation. Her past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, and her medications include levothyroxine, a daily multivitamin, and a calcium supplement. Family history is significant for a maternal aunt with breast cancer at age 68. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and body mass index is 34 kg/m2. The abdominal exam reveals mild distension, but no tenderness to palpation. A large pelvic mass is palpable on bimanual exam. A pelvic ultrasound shows a 12 cm multiloculated cystic structure in the left adnexa, with thick septal walls that lack internal vascularity. The mass has no mural nodules, papillary projections, or solid components. The uterus is small, and the endometrial thickness is 6 mm (slightly thicker than what is usually seen in postmenopausal women). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has features that can be seen with both a benign adnexal mass, such as a cystadenoma, and ovarian malignancy. These features include age > 55 and a large, loculated cystic mass. Features that increase the risk of malignancy include thicker septal walls (seen in the vignette), and the presence of vascular flow within the septal walls, mural nodules, papillary projections, and solid components (which were not seen in the vignette). Most complex masses in postmenopausal patients require surgical excision. However, the recommended procedure is different for benign and malignant masses. Therefore, the best next step in the evaluation is to further assess the patient’s risk of malignancy by ordering serum tumor markers, such as a CA-125.

Based on the serum tumor marker results, if the risk is high, additional imaging may be warranted to assist with pre-operative planning and to investigate for metastasis. The best way to definitively confirm the diagnosis of an ovarian mass is with a pathology assessment.

Diagnostic features of different types of adnexal masses are detailed in the table below.


Option Analysis

✅ Serum tumor markers:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Pelvic MRI :
Incorrect: A pelvic MRI is typically used to further characterize complex masses in indeterminate cases, assist in surgical planning, and look for evidence of metastasis. Before ordering a pelvic MRI, the best next step is to better assess the patient’s risk of malignancy with serum tumor markers. 
❌ Genetic testing:
Incorrect: Genetic testing is indicated in patients with a high risk of familial cancer syndrome, such as those with mutations in the BRCA genes. There are numerous criteria that warrant genetic testing (e.g. first-degree relative with breast or ovarian cancer diagnosed at a young age), but these are not evident in this patient.  
❌ Surgical pathology assessment:
Incorrect: The surgical management of an adnexal mass varies based on whether the mass is thought to be benign or malignant. Therefore, the best next step is to further assess the patient’s risk of malignancy with serum tumor markers, though surgical pathology is ultimately required to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Endometrial biopsy:
Incorrect: An endometrial biopsy can detect endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy. Although this patient has a slightly thickened endometrium, she has no postmenopausal bleeding or uterine enlargement. The patient’s presentation is more concerning for ovarian cancer, so obtaining tumor markers is the best next step.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 37 weeks of gestation is in labor for an anticipated spontaneous vaginal delivery and is found to have a fever. Contractions are occuring every five minutes. Labor has been complicated by prolonged rupture of membranes. The pregnancy has otherwise been uncomplicated. The patient has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and is the same when taken 30 minutes later, heart rate is 110 bpm, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination demonstrates fundal tenderness. Monitoring demonstrates a fetal heart rate of 170 bpm. Which of the following clinical factors in this case indicates the need for treatment with antibiotics?
questions.solution:
This patient at 37 weeks of gestation who is in labor is found to have a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) and fundal tenderness. The presence of a fever 38.0°C (100.4°F) to 38.9°C (102.02°F) on ≥ 2 measurements 30 minutes (apart without another clear source of infection) PLUS at least one of the following: fetal tachycardia (FHR > 160), maternal leukocytosis (WBC > 15,000), or purulent fluid from cervical os is diagnostic for intraamniotic infection and indicates a need for treatment with antibiotics.

Patients may have symptoms of fundal tenderness, malaise, and tactile fevers, and they will typically have at least one risk factor for the development of intraamniotic infection. Physical examination may reveal purulent fluid from cervical os or fundal tenderness. Diagnosis is made if maternal temperature exceeds 39.0°C or if temperature is 38.0°C to 38.9°C and at least one of the following is present: fetal tachycardia (FHR > 160), maternal leukocytosis (WBC > 15,000), or purulent fluid from cervical os.

Patients who meet diagnostic criteria for an intraamniotic infection should receive empiric antibiotic therapy with ampicillin and gentamicin with the addition of metronidazole if the patient is undergoing cesarean delivery. Patients with a temperature between 38.0°C and 38.9°C with or without a persistent temperature elevation 30 minutes later and without other clinical findings indicating intraamniotic infection are considered to have an isolated maternal fever. Management can include antibiotic therapy or observation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Fetal heart rate of 170 bpm:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Maternal heart rate of 110 bpm:
Incorrect: Fetal tachycardia, not maternal tachycardia, is a clinically significant factor used to diagnose and treat intraamniotic infection. Fetal tachycardia is defined as fetal heart rate >160 bpm.  
❌ Anticipated spontaneous delivery:
Incorrect: The anticipated route of delivery is not used to make a diagnosis of intraamniotic infection. 
❌ Presence of fundal tenderness:
Incorrect: Fundal tenderness is a non-specific finding in patients with intraamniotic infection. The presence of fundal tenderness should raise suspicion for intraamniotic infection, and other findings should be used to determine the diagnosis and need for antibiotics. 
❌ Gestational age of 37 weeks:
Incorrect: Gestational age is not a clinically significant factor for determining the need for antibiotics in patients with suspected intraamniotic infection.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old nulligravid woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of amenorrhea. Her cycles have always been irregular, and typically come once every 30 to 45 days. She has never gone this long without a cycle before and is concerned. A review of systems is notable for 8 kg of weight loss and intermittent diarrhea over the past year. Past medical history is notable for anemia and diabetes mellitus (DM) type 1, for which she uses an insulin pump. Family history is notable for breast cancer in her grandmother at age 58. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 114/74 mm Hg, and body mass index is 19 kg/m2. Physical exam is unremarkable and lab results are shown in the table. A pelvic ultrasound shows normal female anatomy and a thin, homogenous endometrium. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation?
 
 Laboratory value     Result   
 Serum chemistry    
 Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH)     5 IU/L    
 Luteinizing hormone (LH)     4 IU/L    
 Estradiol (E2)     low    
 Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)     2.7 mU/L    
 Prolactin (PRL)     12 ng/mL    
 Urine     
 Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)     negative

choices.text: Repeat FSH and estradiol in 4 weeks

questions.solution:
The patient in the vignette presents with secondary amenorrhea most likely caused by functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) secondary to chronic disease. A progestin challenge is the most appropriate next step in management.

FHA is seen most often in patients with a low BMI, a history of disordered eating, intense athletic performance, chronic illness, or excessive psychological stress. It is especially common in athletes whose performance can be affected by weight, such as distance runners, gymnasts, dancers, etc. This patient’s presentation is suspicious for undiagnosed celiac disease due to her history of weight loss, low BMI, diarrhea, and history of DM-type 1, in the setting of lab findings consistent with FHA.

FHA is a “survival” response in which the body intentionally suppresses the reproductive cycles to prevent pregnancy in times of low energy resources. The hypothalamus suppresses the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), leading to low FSH levels, which in turn leads to low estrogen, and a lack of endometrial stimulation, resulting in a thin, homogeneous endometrial lining, all of which are seen in this patient.

A diagnosis of FHA is a diagnosis of exclusion but would be further supported by a negative progestin challenge test. In this test, the patient is typically given 10 to 14 days of progestin, and upon cessation of the progestin, a withdrawal bleed is expected. A negative test (i.e., withdrawal bleeding does not occur), indicates that either estrogen is not present to stimulate the endometrium (which is the case in FHA and primary ovarian insufficiency ([POI]), or there is an anatomic abnormality, such as Asherman syndrome. This patient’s lab findings are inconsistent with POI, and chronic disease is more likely in this situation than Asherman syndrome. A positive test suggests the cause of amenorrhea is anovulation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Progestin challenge:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Repeat FSH and estradiol in 4 weeks:
Incorrect: Repeating FSH and estradiol levels are indicated to confirm primary ovarian insufficiency in patients with elevated FSH levels (> 20 IU/L) and low estradiol. These patients typically present with signs and symptoms of menopause, including vasomotor symptoms and vaginal dryness. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with functional hypothalamic amenorrhea secondary to chronic disease. Therefore, a progestin challenge is the next best step. 
❌ Diagnostic hysteroscopy:
Incorrect: A diagnostic hysteroscopy is indicated in patients with a presentation suspicious for intrauterine adhesions. This patient lacks a history or ultrasound findings that would raise suspicion for intrauterine adhesions, while her presentation is suspicious for functional hypothalamic amenorrhea secondary to chronic disease. A progestin challenge is a better next step. 
❌ Pituitary MRI:
Incorrect: A pituitary MRI is indicated in patients with findings that are suspicious for a pituitary adenoma, such as elevated prolactin, symptoms of a pituitary mass (e.g., visual changes, headaches), and/or galactorrhea. Additionally, a history of a massive postpartum hemorrhage followed by difficulty lactating suggests pituitary necrosis, which would be supported by a small pituitary gland on MRI. None of these findings are present in this patient, whose presentation is most consistent with functional hypothalamic amenorrhea secondary to chronic disease. 
❌ Serum androgen testing:
Incorrect: Serum androgen testing is appropriate in patients with evidence of hyperandrogenism, such as cystic acne or hirsutism (ie, male pattern hair growth), and is most often seen in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Other suspicious findings for PCOS include an elevated BMI, hypertension, evidence of insulin resistance, and polycystic appearing ovaries on pelvic ultrasound. In addition to a low BMI and normal-appearing ovaries, this patient has DM-type 1, while PCOS is associated with DM-type 2.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 2, aborta 1, at 6 weeks gestational age by last menstrual period, presents to the emergency department with left lower quadrant pain and vaginal bleeding. She and her partner have been trying to conceive and had a positive home pregnancy test last week. Her initial antenatal appointment is scheduled for next week. Past medical history is notable for two uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal deliveries and one ruptured ectopic pregnancy treated with a right salpingectomy 6 years ago. She also has a history of endometriosis and mild intermittent asthma requiring the use of albuterol 2 to 3 times per month. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.7 °F), heart rate is 86 bpm, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mmHg. Weight is 125 pounds. The exam is notable for left adnexal tenderness and a small amount of bright red blood in the vaginal vault. Labs are obtained, with results shown below. A transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterine cavity and a 3.2 cm complex left adnexal mass. Neither a gestational sac, yolk sac, nor embryo are visible. Which of the following clinical factors indicates the need for surgical management in this patient? 
 
 Lab values      Results   
 Hemoglobin      12.1  g/dL    
 Total leukocyte count     7500/mm³    
 Platelet count     87,000/mm³    
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)     23 mg/dL    
 Creatinine     1.3  mg/dL    
 Aspartate aminotransferase      20 U/L    
 Human Chorionic gonadotropin     4200 mIU/ml
questions.solution:
This patient can be diagnosed clinically with an ectopic pregnancy based on the ultrasound showing an empty uterine cavity in the setting of an HCG above the discriminatory level of 3500 mIU/mL. Her abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and sonographically visible complex adnexal mass also support the diagnosis. This patient has moderate thrombocytopenia (platelet count between 50 and 99,000/mm3), which is an absolute contraindication to methotrexate, and therefore, surgical management is indicated.

An ectopic pregnancy is a gestation that has implanted outside the uterine cavity; it is a non-viable pregnancy that can lead to life-threatening hemorrhage if it ruptures. Treatment options include medical management with methotrexate (MTX) and surgical management with either a salpingectomy or salpingostomy. Patients with a contraindication to methotrexate require surgical management. Factors associated with increased rates of MTX failure are also considered relative contraindications, including an initial HCG > 5000 mIU/mL, an adnexal mass > 4 cm, and embryonic cardiac activity.

The table below reviews clinical factors that can be used to determine the appropriate treatment modality. Appropriate candidates for MTX treatment should be counseled on both MTX and surgical options, and the final decision regarding treatment modality should rest with the patient. Rh-immune globulin is also indicated for all Rh-negative patients.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Thrombocytopenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ HCG level:
Incorrect: An initial HCG level above 5,000 mIU/mL is a relative contraindication to methotrexate (MTX) because it is associated with higher rates of MTX failure. MTX may still be appropriate in well-counseled, motivated patients who prefer this method. 
❌ History of asthma:
Incorrect: Active pulmonary disease, except for asthma, is a contraindication to methotrexate. This is because MTX affects rapidly dividing cells, including the respiratory epithelium, but asthma is a disease caused by airway hyperresponsiveness. Therefore, methotrexate is not contraindicated. 
❌ Size of the adnexal mass:
Incorrect: Ectopic pregnancy size > 4 cm on transvaginal ultrasound is a relative contraindication to methotrexate (MTX) because it is associated with higher rates of MTX failure. MTX may still be appropriate for well-counseled, motivated patients who prefer this method. 
❌ Creatinine level:
Incorrect: An intermediate methotrexate dose is used to treat ectopic pregnancy. The dose can be adjusted based on creatinine clearance, and it should be avoided in patients with very low creatinine clearance. This patient’s creatinine clearance is 54 mL/min and methotrexate is safe to use without renal dose adjustment.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, presents to the clinic with irregular menstrual cycles and undesired hair growth on the face. Previously, her menstrual period occurred once every 25 to 35 days. Over the past eight months, however, menstruation has become more irregular with cycles ranging from 20 to 74 days in length. Additionally, although she has always tweezed soft hairs off her upper lip, she has noticed a significant increase in coarse hair on her upper lip and chin. Past medical history is notable for two uncomplicated vaginal deliveries 3 and 5 years ago. A urine pregnancy test in clinic is negative. Which of the following findings would go against the most likely diagnosis based on history?

choices.text: Prior need for clomiphene citrate to conceive

questions.solution:
The most common diagnosis in patients presenting with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is a common condition that is characterized by the combination of ovulatory dysfunction, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovarian morphology on ultrasound. PCOS is a diagnosis of exclusion, so alternative conditions must be ruled out with a comprehensive evaluation. In PCOS, excessive androgens often result in hirsutism and acne, but androgen levels are typically not high enough to cause virilization (i.e. the development of male body characteristics, such as clitoromegaly or deepening of the voice). Virilization occurs at exceptionally high androgen levels suggestive of an androgen-secreting tumor of the ovary or adrenal gland.        

Metabolic dysfunction is also strongly associated with PCOS. Therefore, obesity, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and insulin resistance are all common findings in patients with PCOS and would support a diagnosis of PCOS. Patients diagnosed with PCOS must be screened for metabolic dysfunction and treated appropriately to reduce their cardiovascular risk or pregnancy risks if they are trying to conceive. Additionally, the ovulatory dysfunction seen with PCOS frequently leads to fertility challenges. Therefore, ovulation induction with either letrozole or clomiphene citrate is often helpful in this population of patients when they are trying to conceive.   

Option Analysis

✅ Clitoromegaly:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acanthosis nigricans:
Incorrect: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is associated with metabolic dysfunction, including insulin resistance, so acanthosis nigricans would support a diagnosis of PCOS.  
❌ Prior need for clomiphene citrate to conceive :
Incorrect: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is associated with ovulatory dysfunction and infertility. Clomiphene citrate is used to induce ovulation in anovulatory people, so this history would support a diagnosis of PCOS.  
❌ Body mass index (BMI) of 38 kg/m2:
Incorrect: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is associated with metabolic syndrome, so a BMI > 25 kg/m2 or waist circumference of > 35 inches would support a diagnosis of PCOS.  
❌ Coarse hair around the nipples:
Incorrect: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The hirsutism seen in PCOS can include coarse hair growth in a typical male distribution, including on the face, chest (including periareolar), back, abdomen, and groin. Evidence of virilization (e.g. clitoromegaly and deepening of the voice) suggests exceptionally high androgen levels that are not typically seen in PCOS.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a fertility evaluation. She has been trying to conceive with her partner for the past year without success despite regular unprotected intercourse. Her menstrual cycles are irregular, making it harder for her to predict the timing of ovulation. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is well-controlled with metformin. Her only other medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 154/92 mmHg, and body mass index is 36 kg/m2. The physical exam is otherwise unremarkable. A urine pregnancy test done in clinic is negative, and a review of her records shows a recent hemoglobin A1c of 5.8% and blood pressure of 142/88. A bedside pelvic ultrasound shows a normal-sized uterus with a mildly thickened endometrium and no evidence of uterine fibroids; there are 23 antral follicles in the right ovary and 11 in the left. In addition to nutritional counseling and support for healthy weight loss, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient in the vignette is presenting with infertility and has polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Infertility due to ovulatory dysfunction, as seen in this patient, is a common initial presentation in patients with PCOS. The patient in the vignette has untreated hypertension and should be started on nifedipine, which is a preferred antihypertensive agent in pregnancy.        

PCOS is closely associated with metabolic syndrome. Therefore, all patients with PCOS should be screened for obesity, hypertension, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia. Any metabolic dysfunction should be treated, which often includes nutritional counseling and support for weight loss; antihypertensive agents; and insulin-sensitizing agents, such as metformin. Weight loss can improve a patient’s chances of conceiving spontaneously, and treatment of diabetes and hypertension should be optimized first to avoid pregnancy complications.        

Further management is determined by a patient’s fertility desires. If a patient desires pregnancy, it is appropriate to try ovulation induction with either letrazole or clomiphene citrate after addressing any metabolic issues. If a patient with PCOS does not desire pregnancy, oral contraceptive pills are considered first-line therapy because they both protect the endometrium from the unopposed estrogen present in anovulatory cycles and reduce luteinizing hormone concentrations, resulting in lower ovarian androgen production. For patients who are not candidates for OCPs (i.e. patients who are over 35 years old or smokers), a levonorgestrel intrauterine device (IUD) is an alternative for endometrial protection. Symptoms of hyperandrogenism can be further addressed with mechanical hair removal, spironolactone (which has anti-androgen properties), and topical eflornithine.    

Option Analysis

✅ Nifedipine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Letrazole:
Incorrect: This patient has polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is associated with metabolic dysfunction. Management of diabetes and hypertension should be optimized before starting ovulation induction with medications.  
❌ Oral contraceptive pills:
Incorrect: This patient has polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Oral contraceptive pills are first-line therapy for patients with PCOS who do not desire pregnancy, unlike the patient in the vignette who is trying to conceive. This patient needs optimal control of her hypertension. 
❌ Insulin:
Incorrect: This patient has polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is associated with metabolic dysfunction. Management of diabetes and hypertension should be optimized prior to ovulation induction. However, this patient’s diabetes is already well-controlled on metformin, so switching to or adding insulin is unnecessary. This patient needs optimal control of her hypertension. 
❌ Spironolactone:
Incorrect: This patient has polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Spironolactone is commonly used to reduce androgen levels in PCOS patients with hirsutism or severe acne. However, it is contraindicated in pregnancy, so it is inappropriate to start spironolactone in this patient who is trying to conceive.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, presents to labor and delivery triage at 26 weeks of gestation with painless vaginal bleeding that began 2 hours ago. She has saturated about 50% of a pad already. An anatomy ultrasound at 20 weeks of gestation showed an anatomically normal fetus, a posterior placenta with the lower margin located 8 mm from the internal cervical os, a velamentous cord insertion, and umbilical vessels passing within 14 mm of the os. Her medical history is notable for three prior C-sections that were uncomplicated. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. A speculum examination shows a very slow trickle of bright red blood coming from a closed cervical os. The fetal heart rate (FHR) tracing shows a baseline of 130/min with no accelerations or decelerations and a saw-tooth, sinusoidal pattern, and there are no contractions seen on the monitor. Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan?

choices.text: Inpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 32 weeks
Inpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 34 weeks
Outpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 37 weeks

questions.solution:
The patient in the vignette is presenting with vasa previa, a low-lying placenta, and acute bleeding. Vasa previa is diagnosed when the fetal umbilical vessels pass within 20 mm of the internal cervical os. Placenta previa is diagnosed when the placenta overlies the os, whereas a low-lying placenta does not cover but is within 20 mm of the os.  Blood loss from vasa previa originates from the fetus and can result in rapid fetal exsanguination, whereas blood loss from placenta previa comes from the pregnant person. In this vignette, the maternal vital signs are stable, but a sinusoidal FHR pattern is present, indicating severe fetal anemia and significant fetal distress. Therefore, an emergent C-section is indicated because the fetus is unstable.         

The first step in the acute management of painless antenatal bleeding is to assess the stability of both the patient and the fetus. Emergent C-section to control the hemorrhage is indicated if either the fetus or the pregnant person is unstable. To assess the pregnant person, a primary survey is performed, and an initial set of vital signs is obtained. Management of hemorrhagic shock in the pregnant person includes standard resuscitation measures, with attention to the airway, breathing, and circulation, and IV fluids and blood products as needed. The fetus is assessed with cardiotocographic monitoring and an ultrasound. The primary sign of an unstable fetus is an FHR pattern indicating severe distress, such as bradycardia or a sinusoidal pattern.    

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent C-section now:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 32 weeks:
Incorrect: This patient has a known vasa previa and presents with acute fetal blood loss.  The sinusoidal FHR pattern in the vignette indicates an unstable fetus with severe fetal anemia. The fetus is exsanguinating and an emergent C-section should be performed.  
❌  Inpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 34 weeks:
Incorrect: This plan is appropriate for stable mother-fetus dyads with a vasa previa. This patient has a known vasa previa and presents with acute fetal blood loss. The sinusoidal FHR pattern in the vignette indicates the fetus is unstable and has severe fetal anemia. Emergent C-section is indicated. 
❌ Outpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 37 weeks:
Incorrect:  This plan is appropriate for stable mother-fetus dyads with placenta previa. The patient in the vignette has a vasa previa and presents with acute fetal blood loss. The sinusoidal FHR pattern indicates the fetus is unstable and has severe fetal anemia. Emergent C-section is indicated. 
❌ Outpatient monitoring until spontaneous labor:
Incorrect: This plan is appropriate for stable mother-fetus dyads with a low-lying placenta that is 11 to 20 mm from the internal os. The patient in the vignette has a vasa previa and presents with acute fetal blood loss. The sinusoidal FHR pattern indicates the fetus is unstable and has severe fetal anemia. Emergent C-section is indicated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 37 weeks of gestational age, presents for induction of labor for gestational hypertension. She has no headaches, visual changes, shortness of breath, or right upper quadrant pain. Her first delivery was a cesarean birth due to breech presentation at term, and her second delivery was an uncomplicated vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). Her blood pressure on admission is 140/84 mm Hg, and her cervix is less than 1 cm dilated, thick, and high. Maternal-fetal cardiotocographic monitoring shows a baseline fetal heart rate of 140 bpm, moderate variability, and no accelerations, decelerations, or contractions. An ultrasound confirms the fetus is in a vertex presentation, and a single deepest vertical pocket of fluid is 3.5 cm. A urinalysis shows trace proteinuria and serum blood work is unremarkable. Which of the following should be part of her intrapartum management?

choices.text: Avoidance of a Foley balloon for cervical ripening
Fetal scalp electrode during the active phase of labor
Intrauterine pressure catheter during the active phase of labor

questions.solution:
This patient presents for induction of labor (IOL) with an unfavorable cervix and a history of a prior cesarean birth. Cervical ripening is needed, but prostaglandins are contraindicated in patients undergoing a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) due to the increased risk of uterine rupture. For these patients, mechanical ripening with a Foley balloon and/or judicious use of oxytocin is preferred for cervical ripening. Despite this patient's need for an IOL, her prior history of successful VBAC makes her a good candidate for TOLAC, with appropriate management.        

The most significant risk associated with TOLAC is uterine rupture, which is an obstetric emergency requiring an emergent cesarean birth. For this reason, patients undergoing TOLAC should have an IV placed on admission and continuous maternal-fetal cardiotocographic monitoring throughout labor. Anesthesia providers, a surgical team, and an operating suite must all be immediately available. As mentioned above, prostaglandins for cervical ripening are contraindicated. Additionally, although acceptable for use in patients undergoing TOLAC, oxytocin should only be used judiciously, at the lowest effective dose, because it also increases the risk of uterine rupture.    

Option Analysis

✅ Avoidance of prostaglandins:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Intrapartum magnesium sulfate is indicated in patients with preeclampsia with severe features, HELLP syndrome, and eclampsia. This patient lacks severe features, and therefore magnesium sulfate is not indicated. 
❌ Avoidance of a Foley balloon for cervical ripening:
Incorrect: During a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), a Foley balloon could be used for mechanical cervical ripening. It is usually used in conjunction with judicious use of oxytocin because prostaglandins are contraindicated during TOLAC. 
❌ Fetal scalp electrode during the active phase of labor:
Incorrect: During a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), both the parturient and fetus must be continually monitored to immediately detect evidence of a uterine rupture. However, external monitors are appropriate without the need for a fetal scalp electrode. 
❌ Intrauterine pressure catheter during the active phase of labor:
Incorrect: During a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), both the parturient and fetus must be continually monitored to immediately detect evidence of a uterine rupture. However, external monitors are appropriate without the need for an intrauterine pressure catheter.

questions.text: A healthy 26-year-old nulligravid woman presents to the clinic with heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) and dysmenorrhea that have both been getting progressively worse over the past year. Her menstrual cycles now last 8 days, and she soaks through one pad per hour for the first 4 days of her cycle. She rates her menstrual cramping as an 8 out of 10 on a 10-point scale and notes that the pain has caused her to miss days at work. Review of systems is negative, and the past medical history is noncontributory. The patient’s mother required fertility treatments to conceive and had a hysterectomy at age 45 for heavy menstrual bleeding. Vital signs are within normal limits, and body mass index is 24 kg/m2. The pelvic exam is notable for a uniformly enlarged uterus with a smooth contour that is mildly tender to palpation. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on pelvic ultrasound?

choices.text: Heterogenous, thickened myometrium with myometrial cysts
Multiple small cystic structures around the periphery of each ovary
Subserosal myometrial mass at the uterine fundus
A hyperechoic linear structure with posterior shadowing in the endometrial cavity

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) and dysmenorrhea. On exam, the uterus was enlarged and had a smooth contour. The patient in the vignette lacks risk factors for endometrial malignancy and has no additional symptoms to suggest an endocrine cause of her irregular bleeding (such as thyroid disease or polycystic ovary syndrome). Therefore, of the choices offered, adenomyosis is the most likely diagnosis.  Adenomyosis refers to the implantation of endometrial glands within the myometrium which can lead to HMB, dysmenorrhea, and global uterine enlargement. The diagnosis is further suggested on ultrasound by a heterogeneous thickened myometrium with myometrial cysts; the posterior wall is often thicker than the anterior wall.  Echogenic subendometrial lines radiating into the myometrium and an irregular endometrial-myometrial junctional zone are also relatively specific findings.        

Uterine leiomyoma, or fibroid, is the other common cause of HMB and pelvic pain symptoms and can be difficult to differentiate from adenomyosis based on history and exam findings alone. While a subserosal fundal fibroid would have an irregular contour on exam, multiple smaller fibroids or larger submucosal fibroids could have exam findings like those in the vignette. Therefore, an ultrasound is recommended to confirm the underlying cause of HMB.   

Option Analysis

✅ Heterogenous, thickened myometrium with myometrial cysts:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thickened endometrium:
Incorrect: A thickened endometrium can be seen with endometrial polyps, hyperplasia, or malignancy. Polyps do not enlarge the uterus. While hyperplasia and malignancy can enlarge the uterus, the patient lacks any risk factors for these conditions; adenomyosis is a much more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Multiple small cystic structures around the periphery of each ovary:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). This patient lacks evidence of hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne, hirsutism) and metabolic dysfunction, which are both closely associated with PCOS, making adenomyosis a more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Subserosal myometrial mass at the uterine fundus:
Incorrect: This finding would be highly suggestive of a uterine leiomyoma, or fibroid. While fibroids can also present with HMB and dysmenorrhea, this patient has a smooth uterine contour, and a subserosal fundal mass would result in an irregular contour. 
❌ A hyperechoic linear structure with posterior shadowing in the endometrial cavity:
Incorrect: This is how an intrauterine device (IUD) appears on ultrasound. Copper IUDs can cause HMB and dysmenorrhea. Without a history of an IUD, this finding is unlikely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting for the past 12 hours. The patient is unable to tolerate oral intake. Her last menstrual period was 14 days ago. The patient has had 3 sexual partners in the past 6 months. Past medical history is significant for pelvic inflammatory disease that was treated with antibiotics. The patient has no allergies and takes no medications. Temperature is 39°C (102.2 F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 100/56 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes, and lower abdominal tenderness. Pelvic examination shows normal external genitalia and purulent discharge from the cervical os. Bimanual examination reveals cervical motion tenderness. Laboratory evaluation shows a leukocyte count of 18,000/mm3 with 50% neutrophils. Pregnancy test is negative. Blood cultures are obtained and empiric treatment with clindamycin is initiated. In addition to clindamycin, which of the following antibiotics is indicated in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, purulent cervical discharge, and cervical motion tenderness consistent with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). This condition is typically caused by the organisms Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae and is treated with broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. This patient requires hospitalization and treatment with parenteral antibiotics due to her associated nausea, vomiting and leukocytosis, and fever. Initial therapy includes intravenous clindamycin in combination with gentamicin (an aminoglycoside).

In addition to complicated PID, aminoglycosides are often indicated in combination with a β-lactam or glycopeptide (vancomycin) in select circumstances:

  • For treatment of healthcare-associated pneumonia or sepsis, against multidrug-resistant gram-negative organisms (P. aeruginosa, Enterobacter sp., Klebsiella sp., and Serratia sp.)  
  • To achieve synergistic bactericidal activity in the treatment of endocarditis due to gram-positive Enterococci sp.  
Other indications for aminoglycosides include urinary tract infections or meningitis caused by gram negative organisms resistant to β-lactams. Streptomycin and amikacin serve as alternative agents for the treatment of infections due to drug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis or to other nontuberculous mycobacteria. Adverse effects of aminoglycosides include: 
       
  •  Irreversible vestibular and auditory dysfunction  
  •  Nephrotoxicity, especially when co-administered with loop diuretics  
  •  Teratogenicity 
  •  Allergic skin reactions (neomycin) and are contraindicated in patients who are allergic to them  
  •  Neuromuscular blockade and apnea–aminoglycosides should be avoided in patients with  myasthenia gravis or associated neuromuscular disorders.   

Option Analysis

❌ Vancomycin :
Incorrect: Vancomycin is indicated in the management of multidrug-resistant gram-positive organisms including MRSA, S. epidermidis, sensitive Enterococcus sp., and Clostridium difficile. Vancomycin is not indicated in the management of pelvic inflammatory disease. 
✅ Gentamicin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chloramphenicol :
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol can be used in the treatment of meningitis secondary to Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis or Streptococcus pneumoniae or rickettsial diseases. Chloramphenicol is not effective against Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 
❌ Linezolid :
Incorrect: Linezolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor used in the treatment of gram-positive bacterial infections (MRSA) and vancomycin resistant organisms. It is not effective against Chlamydia trachomatis (intracellular organism) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gram-negative). 
❌ Daptomycin :
Incorrect: Daptomycin is a lipopeptide that disrupts the cell membranes of gram-positive cocci by creating transmembrane channels. It can be used to treat skin infections caused by S. aureus (MRSA), bacteremia, endocarditis and VRE. It is not effective against Chlamydia trachomatis (intracellular organism) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gram-negative).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 28 weeks of gestation, comes to the emergency department for shortness of breath. The patient has a history of asthma treated with as needed albuterol and fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler daily. She was in her usual state of health until the past week when she needed to use her albuterol multiple times a day for chest tightness and shortness of breath. Today, she has used her albuterol inhaler multiple times with only minimal improvement of her symptoms. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on 4 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula. The patient has mild accessory muscle usage and can speak only in 4-5-word sentences. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals diffuse wheezes bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. Fetal heart tones are 150 beats per minute. The peak expiratory flow rate is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This pregnant patient with a history of asthma, shortness of breath, diffuse wheezing on lung exam, and a significantly reduced peak expiratory flow rate (40% of predicted) can be diagnosed an acute asthma exacerbation. The priority is to stabilize this patient's respiratory status while ensuring fetal well-being. Nebulized albuterol and intravenous glucocorticoids are appropriate and safe treatments for pregnant patients with acute asthma exacerbations.

Acute asthma exacerbations are common during pregnancy and increase the risk of preeclampsia, gestational diabetes, placental abruption, and placenta previa—requiring prompt management. Acute management involves stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. The recommended pharmacotherapy of acute asthma during pregnancy does not differ substantially from the management in non-pregnant patients. Pharmacologic therapy involves treatment with inhaled short-acting beta-agonist albuterol, inhaled ipratropium, as well as oral or intravenous glucocorticoids. Intravenous magnesium sulfate may be beneficial in acute severe asthma as an adjunct to inhaled beta agonists and intravenous glucocorticoids.

The well-being of the fetus must be managed as well in pregnant patients with acute asthma exacerbations, and the management will depend on the gestational age. If the pregnancy is previable, fetal heart tones via Doppler should be obtained. In pregnancies past 22 weeks gestation, continuous electronic fetal monitoring should be performed, and a biophysical profile should be considered.   

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous theophylline:
Incorrect: Intravenous theophylline is not the preferred initial treatment due to its narrow therapeutic window and potential for significant side effects. Current guidelines favor the use of beta-agonists and corticosteroids for acute asthma exacerbations in pregnancy. 
✅ Nebulized albuterol and intravenous glucocorticoids:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Intravenous magnesium sulfate may be used as an adjunct treatment for treatment of severe asthma exacerbations unresponsive to initial therapy. It is safe in pregnancy. 
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: Endotracheal intubation should be considered when patients fail to respond to medical therapy and exhibit signs of respiratory failure. This patient does not have signs of imminent respiratory failure and has not yet had medical therapy.  
❌ Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin:
Incorrect: Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin would be considered for bacterial community-acquired pneumonia, which is not indicated given the absence of fever and localized lung findings. The patient’s physical examination and history favors the diagnosis of an acute asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 26 weeks of gestation, presents to the clinic for a regular prenatal visit. She has a history of asthma that was previously well-controlled with an as-needed albuterol inhaler that she used about once a week. However, recently she has had to use her albuterol inhaler twice a day.  Previously, she did not experience nighttime awakenings. She does not have nasal congestion, postnasal drip, fevers, or cough with sputum. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable, and lung examination reveals scattered wheezes bilaterally. Fetal heart rate is 160 beats per minute. Which of the following additional findings would be consistent with moderate persistent asthma?

choices.text: Occasional coughing while doing very hard cross fit sessions

questions.solution:
Before becoming pregnant, this patient had a history of asthma that was controlled with the use of an albuterol inhaler once a week; this would be considered mild asthma. Since becoming pregnant, she has had to use her inhaler twice a day, indicating a worsening in her asthma control. In addition to daily symptoms, she now has nighttime awakenings occurring more than once a week, limitations and interference with daily activities, and an FEV1 or peak flow of 60-80% (70% in this case); this is now consistent with moderate persistent asthma.

Pregnant patients with mild and well-controlled moderate asthma tend to do well and have excellent pregnancy outcomes. However, those with severe and poorly controlled asthma have an increased risk of perinatal complications, like preeclampsia, fetal growth restriction, and premature birth. Additionally, severe asthma exacerbations may cause life-threatening respiratory failure. Pregnant patients with asthma should be assessed for severity and control in the same manner that patients with asthma who are not pregnant are assessed, and changes in management should be initiated based on the results of regular assessments.   

Option Analysis

❌ FEV1 of 85:
Incorrect: Peak flow measurement showing FEV1 greater than 85% is considered normal. In a patient with moderate persistent asthma, the FEV1 would be 60-80%. 
❌ Cough and wheezing two days a week :
Incorrect: This would be consistent with mild persistent asthma. Patients with moderate persistent asthma have daily symptoms. 
❌ Occasional coughing while doing very hard cross fit sessions:
Incorrect: This would be considered a minor limitation of activities occurring only with vigorous activities. Patients with moderate persistent asthma have limitations that interfere with daily activities like climbing stairs and going grocery shopping. 
✅ FEV1 of 70%:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Nighttime awakenings every other week:
Incorrect: Patients with moderate persistent asthma would have nighttime awakenings more than once a week.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 0020, at 18 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA), presents for a routine antenatal appointment. Her partner who fathered this pregnancy has an A-positive blood type, while her blood type is O-negative. She had some light vaginal bleeding 4 weeks ago, and an ultrasound in the emergency department (ED) showed a strong fetal heartbeat at the time. She was given an injection, and her bleeding resolved after a few days. She has not had any complications since that time. Her obstetrical history is notable for an ectopic pregnancy treated “with several different types of shots,” followed by a miscarriage at 6 weeks EGA which was diagnosed by an ultrasound showing only a yolk sac without development of a fetal pole. Her miscarriage was treated with “pills only, no shots.” Today, her vital signs are within normal limits, and a physical exam is unremarkable. A type and screen show maternal Rh antibodies are present. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?

choices.text: Recent administration of anti-D immune globulin after light vaginal bleeding
Antibody formation after early pregnancy loss
Antibody formation after the ectopic pregnancy
It is a normal finding when the parents are RhD-discordant

questions.solution:
When assessing a patient with a positive RhD antibody screening test, it is important to determine if that person received anti-D immune globulin within the past 12 weeks, as would be the case for this patient who had a bleeding episode at 14 weeks. Recent anti-D immune globulin administration can result in a positive screening test without true alloimmunization.

Rh alloimmunization refers to the development of maternal antibodies to the Rhesus D antigen present on Rh-positive red blood cells (RBCs). Alloimmunization can occur whenever Rh-negative maternal blood encounters Rh-positive blood; these situations are known as sensitizing events, which are detailed in the box above.

If maternal IgG antibodies develop, they can cross the placenta and attack Rh-positive fetal RBCs, leading to potentially severe fetal anemia, hydrops fetalis, and death. For this reason, anti-D immune globulin is routinely administered to patients after sensitizing events to prevent alloimmunization. Fortunately, alloimmunization is unlikely if these patients are appropriately treated, which is likely what occurred with the patient in this vignette. However, the antibodies can persist and cause a positive antibody screen for up to 12 weeks after administration.   

Option Analysis

✅ Recent administration of anti-D immune globulin after light vaginal bleeding:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Antibody formation after early pregnancy loss:
Incorrect: Maternal antibodies can develop after miscarriage of an Rh-positive fetus. However, before 7.5 weeks EGA, there are not enough (or any) erythrocytes to trigger an immune response. Therefore, the risk of alloimmunization is non-existent after a miscarriage occurs before a fetal pole is present. 
❌ Antibody formation after the ectopic pregnancy:
Incorrect: Bleeding associated with an ectopic pregnancy can trigger the development of maternal anti-RhD antibodies. However, the ectopic pregnancy was treated with “different shots,” likely methotrexate and anti-D immune globulin. With the administration of anti-D immune globulin, alloimmunization would be extremely unlikely. 
❌ Alloimmunization after recent antenatal bleeding:
Incorrect: Although bleeding at 14 weeks EGA can lead to the development of maternal anti-RhD antibodies and alloimmunization, the injection she received in the ED after having vaginal bleeding, likely anti-D immune globulin, is more likely cause of the positive antibody screen. 
❌ It is a normal finding when the parents are RhD-discordant :
Incorrect: A positive antibody screen is not a normal finding with RhD-discordant partners. Maternal IgG antibodies against fetal erythrocyte antigens can cross the placenta, attack fetal erythrocytes, and lead to severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and fetal demise.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 12 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA), presents for a routine prenatal appointment. She has no bleeding, cramping, or abnormal discharge. She had a prior vaginal birth at term, complicated by retained placenta and postpartum hemorrhage that required dilation and curettage and blood transfusion. She has no medical problems, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. On exam, the patient is well-appearing with no abdominal tenderness. Laboratory studies show that her blood type is A-negative with a positive antibody screen, while her partner is A-positive with a heterozygous genotype. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
