A 22-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of five days of vaginal discharge and itching. She has been sexually active with three different biologically male partners in the last month and has not used condoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals yellow, frothy vaginal discharge and cervical petechiae. The vaginal pH is 4.9. A wet mount of a sample of the vaginal discharge is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


Image by CDC/ Joe Miller is licensed under Public Domain. Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons.
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vaginal itching and yellow, frothy discharge that has an elevated vaginal pH. Flagellated protozoa are seen on wet mount, consistent with a diagnosis of trichomoniasis. The parasites appear as small pear-shaped organisms with four flagella and undulating membranes, which will collectively show motility during the microscopic examination. Multiple sexual partners and unprotected intercourse are risk factors for trichomoniasis.    

Vaginal trichomoniasis is a parasitic infection caused by flagellated protozoa. Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with symptoms such as malodorous vaginal discharge, vaginal pruritus, dyspareunia, and dysuria. Physical examination may show a frothy yellow or green discharge and vaginal or cervical erythema with petechiae (known as “strawberry cervix”).    

Having multiple sexual partners and unprotected intercourse are risk factors. The sharing of sex toys can also lead to infection, since the parasites can spread through vaginal fluid. Hygiene practices, such as douching, which remove some of the bacteria that make up the normal vaginal flora, can increase the risk of overgrowth of infectious pathogens such as Trichomonas vaginalis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Trichomoniasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial vaginosis:
Incorrect: Bacterial vaginosis typically causes thin vaginal discharge that may be gray, white, or green and foul-smelling. However, the wet mount would show clue cells, and not flagellated protozoa seen in this wet mount which is consistent with trichomoniasis.  
❌ Candidiasis:
Incorrect: Vaginal candidiasis typically causes a thick white vaginal discharge with budding yeast or pseudohyphae on microscopy. This patient has flagellated protozoa on wet mount consistent with trichomonas infection. 
❌ Gonorrhea:
Incorrect: Gonorrhea can present with thick vaginal discharge and discomfort. It is caused by gram-negative bacteria, not flagellated protozoa seen on this wet mount, which is consistent with trichomoniasis. 
❌ Chlamydia:
Incorrect: Chlamydia can cause vaginal discharge and discomfort, but it is caused by intracellular bacteria, not flagellated protozoa as seen on this wet mount, which is consistent with trichomoniasis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for her yearly well-check. She has no current complaints. Her last colonoscopy was five years ago, mammogram six months ago, and HPV/Pap co-test three years ago: all were normal. She has a smoking history of 15 pack years and quit 20 years ago. Her family history is significant for Parkinson disease in her father. She no longer has menstrual periods. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 98% on room air, and BMI is 24. Physical examination is unremarkable. Calculated FRAX score is 13% and Framingham risk score is 7%. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient with a history of smoking has a FRAX score over 8.4% and should be offered osteoporosis screening with a DEXA scan. Normally, osteoporosis screening does not start in biological females until age 65; however, patients who are younger than 65 with increased risk of fractures should have their risk measured by a clinical risk assessment tool, such as FRAX. Patients should begin screening if their score is > 8.4%.   

Osteoporosis screening is an important part of the well-patient assessment. The goal of the FRAX clinical assessment tool is to risk-stratify how likely a patient is to have a major osteoporotic fracture in the next 10 years. Values above 8.4% indicate that the patient has a higher risk than the reference cohort (White women 65 years of age and older), and the patient should not wait until 65 to be screened. Factors taken into account when calculating the FRAX score include previous fracture history, parental fracture history, low body weight, smoking, glucocorticoid use, rheumatoid arthritis, secondary osteoporosis, alcohol consumption, and prior bone mineral density score of the femoral neck, if available. Follow-up intervals for the DEXA scan are dependent on the findings of the initial test as well as patient risk factors, but most screening guidelines recommend that a DEXA scan should not be repeated more frequently than every two years.  

Option Analysis

✅ DEXA scan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HPV/Pap co-test:
Incorrect: HPV/Pap co-testing is recommended every five years for women aged 30-65 years. This patient is currently up-to-date on her cervical cancer screening.
❌ Mammography:
Incorrect: Mammography is recommended either annually or biennially depending on the guideline used. The decision regarding screening frequency should include shared decision making with the patient. This patient had a normal mammogram six months ago and would not be due for another mammogram at this time regardless of the guideline used.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: The interval for colorectal cancer screening with colonoscopy is 10 years. This patient is up-to-date on colorectal cancer screening.
❌ Low-dose chest CT:
Incorrect: Lung cancer screening using low-dose chest CT is recommended for adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20 pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. This patient does not meet the pack-year duration or the time since quitting to have lung cancer screening done.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for one week of abnormal vaginal discharge. The patient noticed an increased amount of watery discharge as well as a prominent odor from the vaginal area after intercourse. The patient is sexually active with one biologically male partner. For contraception, the patient has a copper intrauterine device. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, blood pressure is 116/78 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a thin, grayish-white, watery discharge with a vaginal pH of 4.8. There is no cervical motion tenderness. Saline microscopy of a vaginal sample shows more than 20% of the cell type seen in the image below. A positive whiff test is noted with KOH preparation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?



Image by Dr. Roshan Nasimudeen with Department of Pathology, Government Medical College, Kozikode is licensed under Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge, an abnormal vaginal odor, greater than 20% clue cells on microscopy, vaginal pH above 4.5, and a positive whiff test on KOH preparation consistent with a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Copper intrauterine devices are a risk factor for developing bacterial vaginosis.  

Bacterial vaginosis occurs when there is an imbalance of normal flora in the vagina, resulting in overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria, such as Gardnerella vaginalis and Prevotella species, and a loss of Lactobacillus species. Although it is not considered a sexually transmitted infection, sexual practices are often linked to the occurrence of bacterial vaginosis. Identified risk factors include having a new sexual partner, multiple sexual partners, not using condoms, douching, infection with HSV-2, and having an intrauterine device. Characteristic symptoms include a thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge and an abnormal “fishy” odor from the vagina that may be more prominent after sexual intercourse or during menses. Patients may also be asymptomatic.



Option Analysis

✅ Bacterial vaginosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vaginal candidiasis:
Incorrect: Vaginal candidiasis is a common infection of the vagina caused by overgrowth of yeast. Patients will often have a thick, white discharge and budding yeast or pseudohyphae on microscopy. This patient has a thin, grayish-white discharge and clue cells on microscopy, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.
❌ Chlamydia infection:
Incorrect: Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis can cause cervicitis and present with a variety of discharge types. Chlamydia trachomatis is an intracellular organism and is not visible by standard saline microscopy. This patient’s vaginal sample has clue cells (caused by Gardnerella vaginalis adhering to vaginal epithelial cells) consistent with bacterial vaginosis. 
❌ Gonorrhea infection:
Incorrect: Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae can cause cervicitis and present with a variety of types of vaginal discharge; however, this patient’s clue cells on microscopy are more consistent with a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. 
❌ Trichomonas infection:
Incorrect: Infection with Trichomonas vaginalis typically causes a yellow or green discharge and the flagellated, motile protozoa can be seen on wet mount preparation. This patient has a thin, grayish-white discharge and clue cells on microscopy, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman is evaluated for acute vaginal bleeding following vaginal delivery 2 hours ago at 37 weeks of gestation. The pregnancy was uneventful. The patient has chronic hypertension and was treated with nifedipine throughout pregnancy. Uterine massage is initiated, and 1 unit of packed red blood cells is administered. The physician decides to administer uterotonic agents. Which of the following uterotonic agents must be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Postpartum hemorrhage is one of the most common obstetric complications associated with significant morbidity and mortality. It is defined as acute blood loss of 500 ml after vaginal delivery (or 1L after cesarean section).

Ergonovine is a uterotonic agent used to manage postpartum hemorrhage (unlike oxytocin, ergonovine cannot be used for stimulating labor). Although the mechanism of action of ergonovine is poorly understood, it is thought to stimulate contractions of uterine smooth muscles and vascular smooth muscles.

Because of its vasoconstrictive properties, ergonovine is associated with hypertension and is, therefore, contraindicated in patients with underlying hypertension. It can also induce vasospasm of coronary arteries, leading to angina. Finally, ergonovine can lead to other side effects like headache, nausea, and vomiting.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ergonovine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oxytocin:
Incorrect: This patient can take oxytocin as there are no contraindications for its use in this patient.  
❌ Carboprost:
Incorrect: Carboprost is a synthetic prostaglandin analog that can be used to stimulate uterine contractions. Its use is contraindicated in patients with asthma, as it induces bronchospasm.  
❌ Tranexamic acid:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic medication used as a second-line agent to treat postpartum hemorrhage. It has no absolute contraindications but must be used cautiously in patients with a prior history of venous hypercoagulability due to the increased risk of venous thromboembolism.  
❌ Misoprostol:
Incorrect: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E2 analog and is used in the management of postpartum hemorrhage. It has no absolute contraindications and can be used in this patient.

questions.text: A 36-year-old gravida 3 para 2 woman at 33 weeks gestation comes to the obstetrician to evaluate uterine contractions. The contractions are regular and occuring every five minutes. The pregnancy has been complicated by polyhydramnios. She has a history of diabetes mellitus, for which she is currently taking insulin. Group B streptococcal culture was negative three days ago. On exam, the cervix is 3 cm dilated and effaced. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in preterm labor, which is defined as labor onset before the age of 37 weeks of gestation. Tocolytics are medications that inhibit labor contractions from delaying labor and are administered to provide time for corticosteroid administration to stimulate fetal lung maturation.

Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker and is most commonly used as an anti-hypertensive agent, but it is also used as a tocolytic. Blockade of calcium channels of the smooth muscle of the uterus diminishes the ability of the calcium calmodulin activation of myosin light chain kinases, resulting in inhibition of the contraction of the uterine smooth muscles.

Side effects of nifedipine include vasodilation, which may cause flushing, dizziness, and hypotension.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Administer nifedipine and glucocorticoids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer indomethacin and glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Although indomethacin is one of the most commonly used tocolytics, it is contraindicated after the 32nd week of gestation due to an increased risk of premature closure of ductus arteriosus.  
❌ Administer terbutaline and glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is another tocolytic; however, it can lead to hyperglycemia and should be avoided in this patient with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus.  
❌ No intervention is needed:
Incorrect: This patient is in preterm labor, which is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Tocolytics are used to delay labor in patients with preterm labor before the age of 34 weeks of gestation.  
❌ Administer oxytocin and glucocorticoid:
Incorrect: Oxytocin induces labor and will increase the likelihood of preterm delivery in this patient.

questions.text: A 27-year-old G1P1 woman is evaluated for vaginal bleeding immediately following a spontaneous vaginal delivery of a baby girl at 37 weeks gestation. This is the patient's first delivery, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. The placenta is delivered, and on inspection, it is noted to have velamentous vessels present. The patient has no previous medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 107/67 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination of the perineum does not reveal evidence of trauma to the vaginal tissue, and no hematomas are present. There is no evidence of trauma to the cervix. On bimanual examination, the uterus is firm. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on further clinical evaluation?

choices.text: Echogenic material within the endometrial cavity on ultrasound
Petechial rash in the axillary region
Low platelet count and low fibrinogen level
Well-defined, solid, hypoechoic mass an ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of immediate postpartum hemorrhage. Physical examination shows that there is no evidence of vaginal or cervical trauma, hematomas, or atony. Examination of the delivered part of the placenta shows velamentous vessels, which is a finding associated with retained placenta. This condition results from abnormal cord insertion in which the umbilical vessels diverge as they traverse between the amnion and chorion before reaching the placenta. In patients with retained placenta/tissue, placental membranes/tissue may be felt in the endometrial wall. On ultrasound, retained placental membranes and tissue will show echogenic or hyperechoic material within the endometrial cavity.

Velamentous cord insertion is a risk factor for retained placenta. Preterm birth, prior c-section, and preeclampsia are also risk factors for retained placenta.

The physical exam for patients with primary postpartum hemorrhage should immediately focus on controlling bleeding and determining the cause. The four T’s can be used to help remember the causes of immediate postpartum hemorrhage: uterine tone, trauma, retained tissue, and coagulopathy. Importantly, the placenta should also be inspected to assess for any factors that might suggest retained tissue as seen in this case.

A table outlining the incidence of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by cause can be found below. A note that higher rates of PPH have been reported in people of color. Remember, race is not a biological construct that makes an individual physiologically at increased risk of PPH; rather, racism has biological consequences. Thus the disparity in rates of PPH has been attributed to disparities in quality of care.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Echogenic material within the endometrial cavity on ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Petechial rash in the axillary region:
Incorrect: A petechial rash in the axillary region is suggestive of an amniotic fluid embolism, which presents with findings similar to that of an acute pulmonary embolism (e.g. shortness of breath, hypoxia, tachycardia). This patient does not have any pulmonary symptoms and has bleeding most likely secondary to retained tissue.  
❌ Low platelet count and low fibrinogen level:
Incorrect: A low platelet count and low fibrinogen level are suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation. Clinical manifestations of this condition include bleeding from IV insertion sites as well as spontaneous bleeding in other body cavities. This patient with postpartum bleeding and velamentous placental vessels likely has bleeding from retained tissue that will appear as echogenic material within the endometrial cavity on ultrasound.  
❌ Well-defined, solid, hypoechoic mass an ultrasound:
Incorrect: A well-defined, solid, hypoechoic, round mass on ultrasound would be consistent with a fibroid, not retained products of conception, which appear as hyperechoic heterogeneous material on ultrasound.  
❌ An echogenic endometrial stripe:
Incorrect: Uterine atony can be confirmed with the finding of an echogenic endometrial stripe on ultrasound. However, on a bimanual exam, this patient has a firm contracted uterus; therefore, atony is not likely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for fertility planning. The patient tells the physician she and her partner are planning to have a child. She has a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures; the last episode occurred six months ago. She is currently taking carbamazepine. Which of the following is the most appropriate management to initiate in this patient before her pregnancy?

choices.text: Start the patient on a high dose of folic acid daily
Start the patient on standard folic acid daily
Stop carbamazepine now and throughout pregnancy
Switch the patient to valproic acid

questions.solution:
This patient is taking carbamazepine and is planning to get pregnant. The AEDs most known to carry teratogenic effects are carbamazepine, phenytoin, and valproic acid.    

Carbamazepine use during pregnancy is associated with congenital malformations, including cleft lip and palate and neural tube defects (e.g. spina bifida). These findings can also be seen in patients taking phenytoin during pregnancy. In addition, gestational phenytoin use can lead to fetal hydantoin syndrome, characterized by midfacial hypoplasia, microcephaly, cleft lip and palate, digital hypoplasia, as well as intellectual and behavioral abnormalities. Valproic acid can lead to congenital cardiac defects, neural tube defects, cleft lip and palate, intellectual disability, and behavioral problems.    

The precise mechanism by which these medications induce these teratogenic effects is not entirely understood; however, studies suggest AEDs cause folate deficiency and increase the number of oxidative metabolites in the fetus.    

The use of AEDs in pregnancy includes a carefully balanced decision considering the increased risk of teratogenicity and seizure recurrence. It is recommended to continue using an AED in pregnancy, but the patient must be given a high dose of folic acid (4mg) before and throughout pregnancy to decrease this risk. The exception to this recommendation is valproic acid, which carries severe teratogenic effects.   

Option Analysis

✅ Start the patient on a high dose of folic acid daily:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Start the patient on standard folic acid daily:
Incorrect: All women planning to get pregnant should start using the regular dose of folic acid, which is 0.4 mg. However, patients with an increased risk of folate deficiency like this patient taking carbamazepine should take a high dose (4mg) of folic acid. 
❌ Stop carbamazepine now and throughout pregnancy:
Incorrect: Stopping the use of antiepileptic medication carries an increased risk of recurrent seizures and can result in adverse effects on the fetus and the mother. Stopping the patient’s anti-epileptic medication is inappropriate.  
❌ Switch the patient to valproic acid :
Incorrect: Valproic acid is the most teratogenic antiepileptic medication, and its use is contraindicated during pregnancy. 
❌ No intervention is needed :
Incorrect: Carbamazepine is a teratogenic medication, and a high dose of folic acid is needed to decrease the risk of the fetus developing congenital malformations.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of severe left-sided pelvic pain that started suddenly two hours ago while she was at the gym. She has had nausea and vomiting since the onset of the pain. She is not sexually active and has never been pregnant. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 142/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, she appears uncomfortable due to pain. Abdominal examination reveals moderate tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Serum hCG is negative. Ultrasound reveals a left ovary that is 5.5 cm in size with a twisted pedicle and diminished blood flow. Which of the following, if present, would be the greatest risk factor for this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset acute pelvic pain and ultrasound findings of an enlarged ovary with abnormal blood flow and a twisted pedicle; she has adnexal torsion. Factors that cause an increase in the size of the ovary, such as ovarian stimulation from infertility treatments, place patients at increased risk for torsion.  

Adnexal torsion is a cause of acute pelvic pain that requires emergent surgery to reduce the risk of loss of function of the ovary. Torsion occurs when the ovary twists over its supporting ligaments, compromising blood flow. Patients commonly present with sudden onset severe pelvic pain, with or without nausea and vomiting. With chronic or delayed torsion, the ovary can become necrotic, leading to fever and peritonitis. Adnexal torsion is more common when the size of the ovary is increased above 5 cm. Therefore, cysts and neoplasms are frequent causes. The condition is most likely to occur in women of reproductive age, and pregnancy is an independent risk factor.  Patients undergoing infertility treatments and those with polycystic ovarian syndrome are also at increased risk of ovarian torsion.  




Option Analysis

✅ Infertility treatment:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nulliparity :
Incorrect: Pregnancy is a risk factor for ovarian torsion; nulliparity does not increase the risk.  
❌ Sedentary lifestyle :
Incorrect: A sedentary lifestyle is not a risk factor for ovarian torsion. In fact, strenuous exercise can precipitate it due to increased movement of the ovary within the pelvis. 
❌ Premature ovarian insufficiency :
Incorrect: Premature ovarian insufficiency occurs when the ovaries lose their normal function earlier than expected. Ovarian torsion is more likely to occur during reproductive years.  Premature ovarian insufficiency would decrease, not increase, the risk of torsion.
❌ Use of oral contraceptive pills :
Incorrect: Oral contraceptive pills can reduce the occurrence of ovarian cysts, thereby reducing the risk of ovarian torsion.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of pelvic pain. She has had pain with intercourse and during bowel movements, especially during her menstrual periods, for the last six months and is now having pelvic pain daily. She is sexually active with one biologically male partner, and they have been unsuccessful at conceiving a child despite one year of unprotected intercourse. Her last menstrual period was three weeks ago. Her family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Chaperoned pelvic examination reveals tenderness during vaginal palpation and immobility of the cervix, without adnexal masses. Serum hCG is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pelvic pain, cyclic dyspareunia and dyschezia (pain with bowel movements), along with pain on vaginal examination and cervical immobility. Given a negative pregnancy test, the next step in management is a pelvic ultrasound to evaluate for radiographic evidence of endometriosis or other pelvic pathology. Infertility can occur as a result of endometriosis and is likely a factor in this patient’s inability to conceive.    

A stable patient presenting with pelvic pain should first be evaluated for pregnancy. After pregnancy has been ruled out, the history and physical will guide the next best step in management.  A patient presenting with a classic history of the 4 “Ds” of endometriosis: dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia, and dysuria should be evaluated with pelvic ultrasound. Endometriosis is a condition where tissue that normally lines the uterine cavity is found elsewhere in the body. The symptoms may be cyclic or exacerbated by menses. After a thorough examination and a negative pregnancy test, imaging with transvaginal ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for nodular lesions representing ectopic endometrial tissue.  These lesions may occur on the ovary, rectovaginal septum, bladder, or distant locations. Although direct surgical visualization of the ectopic tissue foci is the gold standard for diagnosis, a presumptive diagnosis of endometriosis can be made when the clinical and imaging findings correlate with the condition.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: An MRI may be necessary for surgical planning or in diagnostically complex cases of endometriosis, but a pelvic ultrasound should be the initial diagnostic imaging study.   
❌ Serum CA 125 level:
Incorrect: Although serum CA 125 levels may be elevated in patients with endometriosis, the test is non-specific, and it is not indicated in the workup of suspected endometriosis. Following a pregnancy test, pelvic ultrasound is the next best step. 
❌ Exploratory laparoscopy :
Incorrect: Direct visualization of endometrial tissue outside of the uterine cavity is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis; however, the diagnosis can be presumed based on clinical and imaging findings, avoiding the risks of surgery. 
❌  Initiate letrozole:
Incorrect: Treatment with aromatase inhibitors is typically reserved for patients with severe, refractory pain secondary to endometriosis. A formal diagnosis of endometriosis can be achieved with direct visualization or with imaging and should be established before initiating therapy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the student health clinic for evaluation of one week of mild to moderate pelvic pain. The pain is worse during intercourse and is associated with vaginal spotting after intercourse. The patient has also noted bleeding between periods. She has been sexually active with three biologically male partners over the last month. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. Mild generalized pelvic tenderness is noted on abdominal palpation without rebound or guarding. Chaperoned pelvic examination reveals mucopurulent cervical discharge with cervical motion tenderness on bimanual examination. Urine hCG test is negative. Which of the following is necessary to diagnose the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: No additional tests are required to make the diagnosis

questions.solution:
This patient has multiple sexual partners and is presenting with acute pelvic pain, abnormal vaginal bleeding, mucopurulent cervical discharge, and cervical motion tenderness on examination; she has pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Pelvic inflammatory disease can be diagnosed clinically based on the history, symptoms, and examination findings. Treatment should be initiated based on the clinical impression. Laboratory testing should accompany the clinical diagnosis to identify a causative organism and help guide treatment, but it is not required to make the diagnosis.    

Biologically female patients with acute pelvic pain present a diagnostic challenge given the array of conditions that may cause the pain.  A systematic approach helps to narrow down the most likely etiology, starting with assessing the stability of the patient, followed by pregnancy testing. Pregnant patients with pelvic pain may have an ectopic pregnancy or be experiencing early pregnancy loss. A pelvic ultrasound is the next step in management for these patients. An adnexal mass, with or without adnexal torsion may present with unilateral pelvic pain, abdominal distention, and fullness or tenderness of the adnexa. An ultrasound is also the best initial diagnostic tool for these patients. Endometriosis is best diagnosed with imaging or laparoscopically.    

Occasionally a patient with pelvic pain may not require formal testing for diagnosis, as in the case of primary dysmenorrhea, which can be diagnosed clinically if a patient presents with symptoms of cyclic pelvic pain that began 6-12 months after menarche and abdominal and bimanual examinations are normal. Patients with pelvic inflammatory disease may also be diagnosed without imaging, but laboratory testing should be performed to guide treatment. Intimate partner violence and sexual assault should always be considered in patients presenting with pelvic pain, and the workup for this is dependent on the presenting factors and severity.    

P.S. If you or someone you know are a victim of sexual assault, you can call RAINN National Sexual Assault Telephone Hotline at 800.656.HOPE (4673) or visit rainn.org to be connected with a trained staff member from a sexual assault service provider in your area.  

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. You can also go to thehotline.org/get/help to chat live with an assistance provider. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope For Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources.  

Option Analysis

✅ No additional tests are required to make the diagnosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT):
Incorrect: A contrast-enhanced CT can be helpful when the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is unclear or when there is concern for complications or other conditions such as appendicitis, abscess, or nephrolithiasis. Imaging is not required to make a diagnosis of uncomplicated PID.  
❌ Nucleic acid amplification:
Incorrect: Nucleic acid amplification to identify the causative organism should be performed as part of the management of pelvic inflammatory disease, but it is not required to make the diagnosis or initiate treatment. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound :
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound is indicated for cases of pelvic pain of unknown etiology, especially when an adnexal mass, adnexal torsion, endometriosis, or pregnancy is suspected. Ultrasound can be used to detect complications of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) such as tubo-ovarian abscess. However, imaging is not required to diagnose uncomplicated PID, which in this case is likely based on this patient’s presentation and examination findings. 
❌  Laparoscopy :
Incorrect: Laparoscopy can confirm a diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease but has poor sensitivity, is invasive, and not typically required to manage the condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office after a positive home pregnancy test, which she took after missing her period. The patient has not had any recent vaginal bleeding or abdominal cramping. Menarche was at age 12 years, and she reports having a regular 28-day menstrual cycle. Past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient does not take any medications. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a small, mobile, nontender uterus. A transvaginal ultrasound confirms a 7-week fetus. The patient describes her wish to terminate the pregnancy and opts for medical abortion. Which of the following is the most appropriate abortive agent for this patient?
questions.solution:
This young woman is in the first trimester of her pregnancy and desires medical abortion. Mifepristone, a progesterone receptor antagonist (antiprogestin), is the most appropriate medical option for first-trimester abortion in this patient.

Antiprogestins act as competitive inhibitors of progestins at progesterone receptors. Mifepristone is given orally in combination with a prostaglandin analog, such as misoprostol or gemeprost because it can sensitize the uterus to the action of prostaglandins. This combination is used as a medical alternative to surgical termination of pregnancy and is >95% effective during the first 50 days of pregnancy. Side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances, vaginal bleeding, and rarely, serious infection, sepsis, and even death caused by an atypical infection, such as Clostridium sordellii.

Ulipristal, another antiprogestin, is used for emergency contraception within five days or 120 hours after unprotected sexual intercourse. Side effects include headaches, tiredness, and gastrointestinal disturbances.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Levonorgestrel pill:
Incorrect: The levonorgestrel pill is a readily available form of emergency contraception that prevents pregnancy by delaying ovulation. It is, however, not effective in the termination of pregnancy.  
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can be used to manage septic abortion, usually present with a fever, abdominal pain, purulent vaginal discharge, and tender boggy uterus. It is not practical for first-trimester elective pregnancy termination.  
❌ Oxytocin:
Incorrect: Oxytocin is ineffective in stimulating uterine contractions and expelling the products of conception during the first and second trimester of pregnancy. There are only a few oxytocin receptors during this stage of pregnancy.  
✅ Mifepristone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Before FDA approval of mifepristone, methotrexate (50 mg/m2) followed by vaginal misoprostol (800 mcg) three to seven days later was used for medication abortion. It is, however, rarely used today for abortion.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 24 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. Her first pregnancy was complicated by neonatal abstinence syndrome due to a history of opiate use disorder. She has not used opiates for a year. Her vital signs are within normal limits, and her current pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Physical examination and routine prenatal screening tests have revealed no abnormalities. She has screened negative for tobacco, alcohol, and substance use at this visit using a questionnaire. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/74 mmHg. On physical examination, she is awake and alert and in no distress. What is the most appropriate approach to substance use screening during her prenatal care?

choices.text: Routine urine drug screening at each prenatal visit
Random urine drug screening prior to delivery
Random urine drug screen at this visit

questions.solution:
While this patient has a history of opiate use disorder, her current pregnancy has been uncomplicated, her physical examination is unremarkable, and she screens negative for current substance use. Thus, the periodic use of a substance use screening questionnaire is appropriate throughout her pregnancy.

Risks associated with untreated opioid use disorders in pregnancy include poor prenatal care, fetal growth restriction, placental abruption, preterm labor, intrauterine passage of meconium, and fetal demise. Universal screening of all patients is important, along with education about the risks of substance use in pregnancy. There are a number of validated tools, including questionnaires, which can be used for screening. These questionnaires are meant to assess the patient's level of use and risks associated with the pregnancy; they also open the door for a conversation aimed at providing education and support. These tools should be utilized at the first prenatal visit and periodically during the pregnancy.

Laboratory testing (such as urine drug testing) is another available method of screening for substance use. However, there are limitations to testing, including false positive and false negative results. Furthermore, a positive result could lead to potential legal consequences for the mother and child. Therefore, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) prefers the use of validated screening tools, such as questionnaires, and cautions that the use of drug testing should only be performed after informing the patient of the potential legal consequences and obtaining consent.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Periodic substance use screening questionnaires:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Routine urine drug screening at each prenatal visit:
Incorrect: Routine urine drug screening is controversial due to the limitations of testing (e.g. false positives) and significant legal implications. As such, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists prefers the use of validated screening tools (e.g. questionnaires).  
❌ No further screening is necessary:
Incorrect: Regular substance use screening is recommended for all patients throughout pregnancy. Ongoing assessment, even if just via a questionnaire, is important for early identification of relapse in patients with a history of substance use.  
❌ Random urine drug screening prior to delivery:
Incorrect: Random urine drug screening prior to delivery is controversial due to the limitations of testing (e.g. false positives) and significant legal and ethical implications; therefore, urine drug screening should only be done if there is a clinical reason and with informed consent. Periodic screening throughout the pregnancy with a validated screening tool, such as a questionnaire, is the preferred method of follow-up.  
❌ Random urine drug screen at this visit:
Incorrect: Random urine drug screening is controversial due to the limitations of testing (e.g. false positives) and significant legal implications. As such, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists prefers the use of validated screening tools (e.g. questionnaires).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G1P0 at 10 weeks gestation, presents to the obstetrician for her initial prenatal checkup. She has no significant past medical history. She consumes approximately three glasses of wine daily with occasional episodes of binge-drinking on weekends. She does not use tobacco or other recreational substances. Currently, she does not want to stop drinking alcohol. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mmHg. Her physical examination reveals no abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide patient education on the risks of alcohol

questions.solution:
This patient has screened positive for alcohol use during the initial prenatal visit. The next step is to provide education on the risks associated with alcohol use during pregnancy.

Alcohol is considered teratogenic, and its use in pregnancy can lead to growth deformities, facial abnormalities, central nervous system impairment, behavioral disorders, and impaired intellectual development. Providing information on these risks may enhance a patient’s willingness to abstain from alcohol. If the patient is motivated to quit, then assisting the patient in implementing a plan to quit and providing additional support resources will improve her chances.

A multidisciplinary team of social service providers, behavioral counseling services, and substance abuse specialists can be beneficial, particularly if the patient has previously had difficulty quitting or demonstrates evidence of dependence. These support mechanisms should remain in place throughout the patient’s pregnancy and postpartum period. If a patient develops withdrawal symptoms, medical support should be provided.  

Option Analysis

✅ Provide patient education on the risks of alcohol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Refer for behavioral counseling:
Incorrect: A referral for behavioral counseling is beneficial for patients who have expressed a desire to quit. If patients are not motivated to quit, the first step in providing motivation for quitting includes patient education on the risks associated with alcohol use in pregnancy.  
❌ Obtain blood alcohol level:
Incorrect: The patient has already divulged current alcohol use during this pregnancy. A blood alcohol assessment will not provide additional useful information to guide management.  
❌ Prescribe oral naltrexone:
Incorrect: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that can be used in the management of moderate or severe alcohol use disorder. There is not enough information at this time to determine if this patient knows about the risks of alcohol use in pregnancy. Additionally, naltrexone is not recommended in pregnancy.  
❌ Prescribe oral diazepam:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines are used to manage symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, which is not demonstrated in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: A 40-year-old G2P1 woman at 28 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrics clinic for routine follow-up. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and advanced chronic kidney disease. Her renal function and urine protein levels have been stable throughout the pregnancy. Current medications include labetalol, vitamin D, and a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), heart rate is 96/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/70. On physical examination, the patient appears pale. The abdomen is gravid and appropriate for gestational age with normal fetal heart sounds present. Serum hemoglobin is 8.6 g/dL with low serum iron levels and MCV of 85 f/L. Which of the following laboratory results is consistent with the most likely type of anemia in this patient?

choices.text: HIgh serum total iron binding capacity

questions.solution:
This pregnant patient with a history of hypertension and advanced chronic kidney disease has normocytic anemia. The findings of a normal MCV, low serum iron, and the presence of advanced kidney disease make anemia of chronic disease the most likely cause of anemia in this patient. A high serum ferritin would be expected with this condition.  

The mean corpuscular volume (MCV) should be used to guide the workup in patients with anemia in pregnancy. It can be used to differentiate between microcytic (<80 fL), normocytic (80-100 fL), and macrocytic (>100 fL) anemia. Pregnant patients with microcytic anemia are most likely to have iron deficiency anemia. Pregnant patients with normocytic anemia and chronic medical conditions are most likely to have anemia of chronic disease. In mixed deficiency anemia, both iron deficiency and vitamin B12 or folate deficiency can also lead to a normal MCV. Pregnant patients with macrocytic anemia are most likely to have B12/folate deficiency.  

Anemia of chronic disease develops in patients with significant medical comorbidities or prolonged inflammation. It is common in patients with advanced renal disease as well as in patients with autoimmune conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus. Chronic inflammation results in upregulated hepcidin levels, which inhibit iron release from macrophages and intestinal absorption of iron. Patients have low circulating iron but sufficient storage of iron, leading to low serum iron levels, low total iron-binding capacity, low to normal transferrin saturation (TSAT), and normal to high ferritin levels (as ferritin is a proinflammatory marker). Treatment is aimed at controlling the underlying disease or cause of inflammation.   

Option Analysis

✅ High ferritin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HIgh serum total iron binding capacity:
Incorrect: A low serum total iron-binding capacity is seen with anemia of chronic disease, which is the most likely cause of anemia in this patient with chronic kidney disease and normocytic anemia.`
❌ HIgh transferrin-saturation:
Incorrect: A low to normal transferrin saturation (TSAT) is seen with anemia of chronic disease, which is the most likely cause of anemia in this patient with chronic kidney disease and normocytic anemia.`
❌ Low folate level:
Incorrect: A low folate level generally results in macrocytic anemia. This patient has a normal MCV. Folate deficiency is unlikely in patients taking prenatal vitamins and without malabsorption.
❌ Low B12 level:
Incorrect: Low B12 generally results in macrocytic anemia. This patient has a normal MCV. Vitamin B12 deficiency is unlikely in patients taking prenatal vitamins and without malabsorption.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents to the health clinic requesting that a long-acting, reversible form of contraception be started at this visit. She has been sexually active with two male partners in the last month, using condoms some of the time. She has had an increase in vaginal discharge, but she thinks it is related to her menstrual cycle, which started 5 days ago. She has no chronic medical conditions and does not use tobacco products. She is a swimmer on the college swim team, and they are beginning their season in three months. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 116/72 mmHg, and BMI is 23 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. She is awake and alert and in no distress. Chaperoned pelvic examination reveals thick vaginal discharge but no cervical motion or pelvic tenderness. Motile protozoa are seen on a wet mount, and a pregnancy test is negative. In addition to sexually transmitted infection testing and treatment, which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe a combined oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
This patient is requesting a long-acting, reversible form of contraception but has evidence of an active vaginal infection with trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. Given these factors, and the fact that she does not have contraindications to a hormonally-based contraception method, prescribing a combined hormonal contraceptive pill is the best choice of the options presented.

The diagnostic workup required when recommending reversible contraception varies depending on patient factors. Recent blood pressure and BMI should be reviewed for all patients, as hypertension can be a contraindication to hormone-based contraceptives, and an elevated BMI may reduce the effectiveness of hormone-based contraceptives, as well as place the patient at increased risk for thromboembolic events. Further workup to consider when recommending reversible contraception includes a pregnancy test if there is doubt regarding pregnancy status or when an intrauterine device is being inserted; testing for sexually transmitted infections if there are symptoms or high-risk factors; and a pelvic ultrasound if there is a concern for a complicated pelvic infection, malignancy of pelvic organs (e.g. abnormal uterine bleeding), or uterine anomalies.

Patient factors to consider when recommending reversible contraception include the ability to regularly access healthcare (for injections or prescriptions), willingness to have a procedure (IUD insertion), timing for when they would like to return to fertility, as well as tolerance for the side effects of the different methods. Reliability is another important consideration, as some methods lose considerable effectiveness if not used correctly, such as taking hormonal pills at the same time every day and coordinating both sexual partners for the withdrawal method and fertility awareness method.

Option Analysis

✅ Prescribe a combined oral contraceptive pill:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order a pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: A pelvic ultrasound can be considered in the management of sexually transmitted infections or contraceptive planning when there are suspected complications of infection, abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, or abnormalities noted on physical examination. This patient does not have concerning features; therefore, a pelvic ultrasound is not indicated.  
❌ Insert an intrauterine device:
Incorrect: An intrauterine device should not be inserted during active infection with a sexually transmitted infection (STI).  This patient’s history and physical examination are highly concerning for an STI and insertion of an IUD is contraindicated at this time.  
❌ Begin depot medroxyprogesterone acetate:
Incorrect: Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate is an injectable progestin that provides reliable, hormone-based contraception, but it is associated with frequent episodes of irregular vaginal bleeding, even up to a year from initiation.  Frequent episodes of unpredictable vaginal bleeding would likely be disruptive to this patient who will be swimming regularly, making an oral contraceptive pill a better option as it will regulate the patient’s cycle more quickly.  
❌ Recommend withdrawal method:
Incorrect: The withdrawal method of contraception entails withholding ejaculation during penetration; it is not long-acting and does not have high reliability. Given that this patient does not have the same sexual partner regularly and desires a long-acting form of contraception, the withdrawal method would not be the best form of contraception.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a primary care clinic for a routine health check-up. She has a history of diabetes type 2 and HIV, for which she is not on treatment due to not having had insurance coverage. In a review of systems, she mentions having irregular menstrual cycles. Her family history is unremarkable. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and consumes alcohol socially. She became sexually active at age 20 and is currently sexually active with one partner and uses barrier protection.  She hasn’t had a pap smear in over 8 years, and inquires about screening options. Which of the following elements of her history places her in the highest-risk category for cervical cancer requiring increased frequency of surveillance?

choices.text: Age of onset of sexual activity

questions.solution:
This patient presents for a routine clinic visit and is due for cervical cancer screening. Her HIV status places her at an elevated risk of developing cervical cancer, necessitating increased frequency of surveillance.  

Cervical cancer is associated with various risk factors. The primary risk factor is persistent infection with high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV), which is transmitted sexually. Other factors that can increase the risk of developing this disease include a history of smoking, multiple sexual partners, early onset sexual activity, and a history of other sexually transmitted infections (STIs), such as chlamydia or HIV. In addition, patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., HIV infection, immunosuppressants) have a significantly increased risk, since the body's ability to fight off HPV infections is impaired.    

Women in the high-risk category, particularly those with HIV or other immunosuppressive conditions, require a tailored approach to cervical cancer screening. For high-risk patients, screening should occur more frequently and may utilize different screening techniques. For women with HIV, HPV testing alone is not recommended, and either a pap smear with cytology alone or co testing with cytology and HPV testing is recommended. Routine colposcopy may be performed with the initial cervical cytology examination. By adjusting screening protocols based on individual risk factors, healthcare providers can ensure early detection and prompt treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ HIV infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Irregular menstrual cycles:
Incorrect: Irregular menstrual cycles may be a symptom of various health issues; however, it is not directly correlated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.  
❌ Age of onset of sexual activity:
Incorrect: Early age of onset of sexual activity increases a patient's risk of cervical cancer. However, this patient became sexually active at the age of 20 years old, which is not considered early.
❌ Social alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Moderate alcohol consumption is not strongly linked to cervical cancer and would not warrant frequent screening. 
❌ Uncontrolled diabetes:
Incorrect: Uncontrolled diabetes can lead to a variety of health complications, it is not a direct risk factor for cervical cancer and would not lead to a change in the usual surveillance recommendations.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, presents to her obstetrician for her first prenatal visit at 8 weeks of gestation. She reports mild nausea but no vomiting, and otherwise has no symptoms to report. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago, and she has had no vaginal bleeding, discharge, or significant cramping. Her medical history and family history are unremarkable. She has been in a monogamous relationship with her partner who is the father for over 5 years. She is taking prenatal vitamins and has no known drug allergies. Vital signs are within normal limits. BMI is 24. The physical examination is unremarkable. Beta hCG pregnancy test is positive. In addition to complete blood count and blood typing, which of the following should be performed at this stage in the pregnancy?

choices.text: Glucose tolerance test and thyroid function test
Rh factor, antibody testing, and infectious disease screening tests
Genetic counseling and detailed family history analysis
Cervical length measurement via transvaginal ultrasound

questions.solution:
This pregnant patient, currently in the 8th week of gestation, is coming in for her initial antepartum care visit. At this visit, baseline blood work should be collected, including complete blood count (CBC), blood type, Rh factor and antibody testing, and infectious disease screening tests.   

The CBC is a fundamental component of prenatal care as it helps identify anemia, which is common during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and iron requirements. Identifying the patient's blood type is necessary. Identifying the presence of Rhesus (Rh) factor and antibodies is also necessary at this visit to prevent Rh incompatibility, a condition where the mother's immune system can produce antibodies against the fetus's blood cells if the fetus is Rh-positive and the mother is Rh-negative. This can lead to serious complications, such as hemolytic disease of the newborn.    

Infectious disease screening, including testing for HIV, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and syphilis should be performed at the initial visit. Testing for immunity to rubella and varicella should also be performed. Additionally, chlamydia and gonorrhea should be screened for in women under the age of 25 and in older women with risk factors. These tests help in the early detection and management of infections that can adversely affect pregnancy outcomes by leading to vertical transmission to the fetus and/or complications during delivery.    

At the first antenatal care visit, Patients can be offered non-invasive prenatal testing, or NIPT, which checks for fetal cell-free DNA in the maternal blood. If this or other tests or family history raise concern for genetic anomalies, chorionic villus sampling can be done between 10 and 14 weeks.  

Option Analysis

❌ Glucose tolerance test and thyroid function test:
Incorrect: Glucose tolerance testing for gestational diabetes is usually performed between 24 and 28 weeks unless there are significant risk factors, which this patient does not have. Additionally, thyroid function tests are only indicated if there are symptoms of or a history suggestive of thyroid dysfunction.
❌ Chlamydia and gonorrhea screening tests:
Incorrect: Screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea is recommended in all pregnant patients who are < 25 years of age and in those who are ≥ 25 years of age with risk factors for sexually transmitted infections. This patient is 27 and has no risk factors for STIs.
✅ Rh factor, antibody testing, and infectious disease screening tests:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Genetic counseling and detailed family history analysis:
Incorrect: Referral for genetic counseling is not appropriate for this patient as she has no noted risk factors, such as a family history of genetic disorders, abnormal prenatal screening results, or personal or obstetric history suggesting a higher risk for genetic anomalies.
❌ Cervical length measurement via transvaginal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Cervical length measurement via transvaginal ultrasound is not a routine part of the initial prenatal workup in the first trimester for low-risk pregnancies. It is typically reserved for women with a history of preterm birth or other risk factors indicating a potential for cervical insufficiency.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 12 weeks of gestation, presents to her obstetrician for her first prenatal visit. She has a history of chronic hypertension, diagnosed five years ago, that was managed with lisinopril, which was switched to labetalol prior to conception. She reports no headaches, visual changes, or abdominal pain. Her previous pregnancy, three years ago, was uncomplicated and resulted in a vaginal delivery at term. She takes a daily prenatal vitamin. Blood pressure today is 122/76 mmHg and pulse is 72/min. BMI is 24.9 kg/m2. Physical examination, including pelvic exam, is unremarkable. The first trimester ultrasound confirms a single intrauterine pregnancy. Fetal heart rate is 142/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
In pregnant women with a history of chronic hypertension, low-dose aspirin should be initiated after 12 weeks of gestation to reduce the risk of preeclampsia.   

Antepartum care in the first trimester focuses on maximizing the health of the mother; assessing for high-risk conditions; performing universal lab screening and genetic counseling; and providing guidance on lifestyle choices that are safe for the developing fetus, including dietary practices, over the counter medicines, and environmental exposures. Important high-risk conditions to evaluate for include anxiety and depression, intimate partner violence, diabetes, infectious diseases, and hypertension.  

Pregnant patients who have a history of chronic hypertension are at increased risk of preeclampsia. Preeclampsia typically occurs after 20 weeks of gestation and can lead to issues such as placental abruption, preterm birth, and fetal growth restriction. Low-dose aspirin reduces the incidence of preeclampsia in women who are at increased risk. Aspirin works by reducing blood vessel constriction and platelet aggregation. It should ideally be started in pregnant patients with chronic hypertension between 12 and 28 weeks of gestation.    

If you or someone you know needs this, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. You can also go to thehotline.org/get/help to chat live with an assistance provider. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope For Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources.  

Option Analysis

❌ Add a second antihypertensive agent:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is well-controlled on her current regimen; therefore, adding another agent is not indicated.
✅ Start low-dose aspirin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Refer for genetic counseling:
Incorrect: Genetic counseling is indicated when there are risk factors present, such as family history of genetic disorders, abnormal prenatal screening results, or history of previous pregnancies with genetic abnormalities. This patient does not have risk factors for genetic abnormalities and, therefore, does not need genetic counseling.
❌ Perform early glucose tolerance test:
Incorrect: An early glucose tolerance test can be considered for patients with risk factors for gestational diabetes, which this patient does not have.
❌ Increase the labetalol dose:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is well-controlled on her current regimen; therefore, increasing the dose of labetalol is not indicated.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the office with dull pelvic pain for the past three days. She reports frequent bloating prior to her menses that subsides within a few days of the onset of menstruation. The bloating has persisted throughout her last 2 cycles. She does not have early satiety, urinary symptoms, hirsutism, vaginal bleeding or discharge. Medical history is significant for ovarian cystectomy of a benign cystic teratoma. Family history is non-contributory. She has not been sexually active for the past 6 months. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals right lower abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. Pelvic examination reveals a 10 cm firm, mobile mass on the right. Pelvic ultrasound shows an 11 cm solid right ovarian mass with internal vascularity and no ascites. Laboratory findings include an elevated LDH level of 850 U/L. AFP, hCG, CA-125, Inhibin A, Inhibin B, estradiol and testosterone levels are within normal limits. Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely to be seen, given the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of pelvic pain and bloating in a 22-year-old woman, a solid ovarian mass with internal vascularity on ultrasound, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, points strongly towards a diagnosis of dysgerminoma. The "fried egg" appearance is a hallmark feature of dysgerminomas. It refers to the tumor cells being large, with clear cytoplasm and central, rounded nuclei. The clear cytoplasm surrounding the nucleus resembles the white of a fried egg, while the nucleus itself resembles the yolk. Lymphocytic infiltration, also characteristic of dysgerminomas, further aids in confirming the diagnosis.

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. It typically presents in adolescent and young women as a unilateral solid ovarian mass but may be bilateral in 10% to 20% of cases. It is occasionally associated with gonadal dysgenesis. While LDH is elevated, other tumor markers are not typically elevated. Therefore, the presence of normal levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), CA-125, inhibin A, inhibin B, estradiol, and testosterone, further supports a diagnosis of dysgerminoma in this patient. In addition, the patient lacks symptoms suggestive of hormonal imbalances, such as virilization and irregular bleeding, that are often seen with other types of tumors.

When a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of an ovarian neoplasm, the main objective is to determine if it is benign and can be managed expectantly or malignant, requiring more immediate intervention. Ultrasound findings that are consistent with malignancy include a complex mass with septations, solid components, increased doppler flow, and the presence of ascites. Tumor markers may help make the diagnosis and distinguish among the various types of ovarian cancer, but are not definitive. In the end, a definitive diagnosis can only be made with pathologic examination.
 

Dysgerminoma characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes. Clear cytoplasm and a centrally placed nucleus, with a “fried egg” appearance. H&E Stain.
Image Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Option Analysis

❌ Psammoma bodies:
Incorrect: Psammoma bodies are concentric calcifications found in certain tumors such as papillary serous carcinoma of the ovary (epithelial ovarian cancer). They are not characteristic of dysgerminomas. This 22-year-old patient with a normal CA-125 tumor marker is not likely to have epithelial ovarian cancer.  
❌ Schiller-Duval bodies:
Incorrect: Schiller-Duval bodies, which are papillary structures with central blood vessels, are characteristic of yolk sac tumors, which are a type of germ cell tumor. Although possible in this young age group, given the normal AFP level, this diagnosis is less likely. This 22-year-old patient is more likely to have dysgerminoma and would have pathology showing a fried egg appearance.  
❌ Call-Exner bodies:
Incorrect: Call-Exner bodies are small fluid-filled follicle-like structures found in granulosa cell tumors, a type of sex cord-stromal tumor. They are not associated with dysgerminomas. The absence of elevated inhibin and estrogen levels, common in granulosa cell tumors, as well as the absence of hyperestrogenism symptoms, such as irregular bleeding, makes this diagnosis less likely.  
✅ Fried-egg appearance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Reinke crystals:
Incorrect: Reinke crystals are rod-shaped crystalline inclusions present in Leydig cells of Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors, a type of sex cord-stromal tumor. They are not associated with dysgerminomas. The absence of elevated inhibin, AFP, estradiol, and testosterone, and clinical evidence of virilization makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with abdominal bloating, early satiety, and an 8 pound weight loss over the past 4 months. She also has alternating diarrhea and constipation, urinary frequency, and diffuse abdominal pain for the past 2 months. She does not have vaginal bleeding or dysuria. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes controlled by diet and hypertension controlled with chlorthalidone. She is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol. Her family history is significant for a mother who died of breast cancer at 69. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness and a fluid wave on percussion. Pelvic examination reveals a fixed 12 cm irregularly shaped right sided mass, an irregular 5 cm mobile left sided mass, cul-de-sac nodularity and a cystocele. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a 12 cm mass on the right, a 6 cm mass on the left, and the presence of ascites. Both masses are complex with solid and cystic components. CA-125 level is elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Biopsy of the ovarian masses and neoadjuvant chemotherapy
Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and omentectomy
Exploratory laparotomy, surgical staging, and maximal cytoreductive surgery
Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2
MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient who presents with abdominal bloating, abdominal pain, early satiety, weight loss, urinary frequency, alternating bowel habits, and physical exam findings of bilateral irregular pelvic masses, cul-de-sac nodularity, ascites, and a cystocele, likely has a diagnosis of advanced epithelial ovarian cancer. An elevated CA-125 level further supports this diagnosis. The most appropriate next step in the management of advanced ovarian cancer is to perform an exploratory laparotomy, surgical staging, and maximal cytoreductive surgery.

The first ovarian cancer surgical objective is to determine accurate FIGO staging. Accurate staging helps to determine prognosis and guides treatment decisions. The second objective is to perform maximal cytoreduction or debulking, removing as much cancer tissue as possible. Patients with minimal residual disease after surgery, preferably only microscopic, or at least with gross disease 2 cm or less in diameter, will have higher survival rates. To achieve these surgical goals, various procedures are performed, including peritoneal washings, careful examination of the abdomen and pelvis to identify all sites of cancer spread, biopsy of suspicious areas and adhesions, infracolic omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, selective lymphadenectomy of pelvic and paraaortic nodes, and excision of all possible tumor masses.

Following surgery, this patient with advanced ovarian cancer should be treated with adjuvant chemotherapy, likely a combination of paclitaxel and carboplatin. Maximal cytoreductive surgery followed by chemotherapy will give her the best chance for prolonged survival. Survival rates in ovarian cancer are determined by disease stage at diagnosis, and in patients with advanced stage disease, by the amount of residual tumor remaining after cytoreductive surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Biopsy of the ovarian masses and neoadjuvant chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Biopsy and neoadjuvant chemotherapy would not be considered standard first-line management of this patient with likely advanced ovarian cancer. Biopsy without first attempting staging and cytoreduction would usually be reserved for patients who are medically unfit for surgery. Based on the medical history, this patient is fit for surgery. Cytoreductive surgery followed by chemotherapy will give her the best chance of long-term survival.  
❌ Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and omentectomy:
Incorrect: Performing only a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and omentectomy would be an incomplete surgical procedure for this patient with likely advanced epithelial ovarian cancer. This surgery omits other important surgical components needed for complete FIGO staging. Optimal management also requires maximal cytoreduction.  
✅ Exploratory laparotomy, surgical staging, and maximal cytoreductive surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2:
Incorrect: Although BRCA mutations can increase ovarian cancer risk, BRCA testing is not the most appropriate next step in management. Patients with suspected advanced ovarian cancer first need surgical evaluation followed by treatment with chemotherapy. Genetic counseling and testing may be performed later, especially with a family history of breast cancer, and would be important information for other cancer-free family members considering testing.  
❌ MRI of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient has a history and physical examination suggestive of advanced ovarian cancer. She already had an ultrasound, which is the recommended first-line imaging modality, with findings consistent with a malignant ovarian mass. MRI may be useful in cases where the ultrasound findings are indeterminate. Surgical evaluation should be performed on this postmenopausal woman with suspicious ovarian masses.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation for over 1-year of worsening hot flashes and amenorrhea. She reports that the hot flashes during the day and night have significantly impacted her quality of life and disrupted her life. She has frequently had to call out of work due to feeling exhausted after not sleeping at night. During the day she has had to miss meetings at work because of her hot flashes. Her medical history is significant for a total hysterectomy performed 5 years ago for benign fibroids. She has no personal or family history of cardiovascular disease, venous thromboembolism, or breast cancer. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She is open to taking any type of medication that will help. Vital signs are within normal limits. BMI is 24 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Lifestyle modifications and re-evaluation in 6 months

questions.solution:
This patient is having significant vasomotor menopausal symptoms (hot flashes and night sweats) that are significantly interfering with her normal functioning. She has a history of a total hysterectomy for a benign condition. Therefore, the best treatment for this woman without contraindications to estrogen use is transdermal estrogen (oral estrogen would also be appropriate). Progesterone is not needed since she has had a hysterectomy.

Management of menopausal symptoms requires an individualized approach that addresses the type and severity of symptoms, the patient’s desire for intervention, and the risks and benefits of treatment. The 2 major types of treatment options for menopausal symptoms include hormonal therapy (menopause hormone therapy; MHT), and non-hormonal therapy. Lifestyle interventions like sleep hygiene, exercise, and stress management should be discussed with all women. Women with a history of breast cancer, coronary heart disease (CHD), a previous venous thromboembolic (VTE) event or stroke, active liver disease, high-risk endometrial cancer, or transient ischemic attack are not candidates for MHT.

The primary goal of MHT is to treat vasomotor symptoms. MHT includes unopposed estrogen in women who have had a hysterectomy and combined estrogen-progestin therapy for women with an intact uterus and the need for progestin to prevent estrogen-associated endometrial hyperplasia. Oral progesterone prevents endometrial growth, which mitigates the risk of hyperplasia and progression to cancer. Patients with a history of a hysterectomy do not need progesterone therapy and transdermal estrogen or oral estrogen are often used to treat vasomotor symptoms in these patients.

Non-hormonal pharmacologic options, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), gabapentin, and clonidine, are alternative treatments that can be effective for managing vasomotor symptoms. They can be used in women who cannot tolerate or have contradictions to or do not want to use hormone therapy. They can also be used in combination with MHT. A progestin-containing IUD can manage abnormal bleeding, but will not address systemic symptoms. Topical vaginal estrogen therapy can be used to treat symptoms of GSM.  

Option Analysis

❌ Oral estrogen and progesterone:
Incorrect: When used in combination with estrogen therapy, progesterone prevents endometrial hyperplasia and future development of cancer in women who have an intact uterus and are being treated with estrogen therapy for menopausal symptoms. Progesterone is not needed for this patient who has had a hysterectomy.  
✅ Transdermal estrogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lifestyle modifications and re-evaluation in 6 months:
Incorrect: Certain modifications may alleviate mild menopausal symptoms; however, this patient's symptoms, especially her vasomotor symptoms, are debilitating and interfering with her normal functioning. Transdermal estrogen is the best treatment option listed to treat menopausal symptoms in this patient who has had a hysterectomy.  
❌ Transdermal estrogen and oral progesterone:
Incorrect: When used in combination with estrogen therapy, progesterone prevents endometrial hyperplasia and future development of cancer in women who have an intact uterus and are being treated with estrogen therapy for menopausal symptoms. Progesterone is not needed for this patient who has had a hysterectomy.  
❌ Gabapentin:
Incorrect: Gabapentin is effective for treatment of hot flashes in some women and may be considered in women who cannot take or prefer not to take MHT. MHT however, is the most effective treatment for hot flashes and should be used in patients with significant symptoms and disruption of her usual activities.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with three hours of severe left pelvic pain that came suddenly. The patient has never experienced this type of pain before. She describes it as intermittent with waves of worsening pain followed by a temporary decrease in the pain. Ibuprofen has not helped relieve the pain. She has no past medical history and does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/96 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. The left lower quadrant is tender to palpation with guarding but without abdominal rigidity or rebound tenderness. Beta hCG is negative. Which of the following should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This woman of reproductive age presents with sudden onset left intermittent pelvic pain. She has left lower quadrant abdominal tenderness to palpation, guarding on exam, and a negative beta hCG. Adnexal torsion should be suspected and a transvaginal (pelvic) ultrasound should be performed next.  

Adnexal torsion refers to twisting of the ovary and fallopian tube, either completely or partially, leading to obstruction of blood supply. Adnexal torsion can lead to significant compression of ovarian blood supply and cause venous obstruction and eventually arterial obstruction. As such, adnexal torsion is a surgical emergency as untreated torsion can lead to necrosis of the ovary. Patients generally present with sudden onset severe abdominal/pelvic pain, which can be intermittent.  

When adnexal torsion is suspected, a transvaginal (pelvic) ultrasound should be ordered. An asymmetrically enlarged ovary may be seen and a whirlpool sign (twisted pedicle) may also be seen. Ultrasound imaging can use Doppler technology to assess vascular flow within the ovarian pedicle. Absent doppler flow indicating adnexal torsion.  A presumptive diagnosis can be made in patients with acute pelvic pain and transvaginal ultrasound showing an adnexal mass with an appearance consistent with torsion (e.g. whirlpool sign). Definitive diagnosis can be made with surgical laparoscopy revealing a torsed ovary, and treatment with detorsion can be performed.  



Figure 1. Ultrasound imaging showing the “whirlpool sign,” indicating a twisted pedicle.  

Courtesy of obgyn.onlinelibrary.wiley.com 

Option Analysis
