✅ Transvaginal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transabdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: While transabdominal ultrasound can potentially visualize an adnexal or ovarian disorder, transvaginal ultrasound is much more helpful because of its location directly next to the adnexa. In addition, visualization of adnexa on transabdominal ultrasound can be limited by patient factors such as obesity, as seen in this patient, or obscuring bowel gas. 
❌ CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast:
Incorrect: While CT could show an asymmetrically enlarged ovary, it would not assess Doppler flow or other ultrasonographic findings specific for adnexal torsion (e.g. whirlpool sign). In addition, this would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation. Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred study for suspected adnexal torsion.
❌ CT abdomen/pelvis without contrast:
Incorrect: While CT could show an asymmetrically enlarged ovary, it would not assess Doppler flow. It is more expensive, takes longer, and would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation. Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred study for suspected adnexal torsion.
❌ MRI abdomen with contrast:
Incorrect: While MRI could show an asymmetrically enlarged ovary and help to classify ovarian masses, it would not assess Doppler flow. In addition, this would significantly delay diagnosis and treatment. Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic test for adnexal torsion.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the primary care office due to heavy menstrual bleeding. Her periods have been getting progressively heavier and more prolonged over the past nine months, sometimes lasting up to ten days and requiring her to use several menstrual pads per hour. She also has a feeling of fullness in her pelvic region. She is sexually active with one male partner. Her last period was two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. Chaperoned pelvic examination reveals an enlarged uterus with an irregular contour by palpation. Pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is concerning for a uterine leiomyoma, given the patient’s history of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic fullness; and the enlarged, irregular uterus palpated on examination. The first step in the evaluation of suspected uterine leiomyoma is a pelvic ultrasound.

Uterine leiomyomas can vary widely in size and location in or on the uterus. Due to this variability, accurately diagnosing them may require a combination of imaging techniques. Pelvic ultrasound should always be the first step in the diagnostic workup. It may not detect all tumors; therefore, if the pelvic ultrasound is unrevealing or inconclusive, additional visualization methods may include sonohysterogram or hysteroscopy. A sonohysterogram is performed by injecting a small amount of saline into the uterine cavity during a transvaginal ultrasound, opening the endometrial cavity to allow inspection of the contours of the endometrium. The procedure is especially useful in cases of pedunculated submucosal leiomyomas. A hysteroscopy (see graphic below) consists of inserting a camera into the endometrial cavity, along with saline to inspect the inner lining of the uterus. This method can be used to visually diagnose and treat submucosal leiomyomas. Magnetic resonance imaging is typically performed ahead of surgical planning in complex cases, or when there is continued diagnostic uncertainty. Laboratory testing can be performed to determine if there is pregnancy or anemia. Endometrial biopsy should be performed when there is concern for malignancy.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hysteroscopy:
Incorrect: A hysteroscopy involves inserting a camera into the endometrial cavity and infusing saline to inspect the inner lining of the uterus. It can be used to visually diagnose and treat submucosal leiomyomas. However, this patient has not yet had a pelvic ultrasound, which is the initial step in the diagnostic workup of a suspected uterine leiomyoma.  
❌ Sonohysterogram:
Incorrect: A sonohysterogram is performed by injecting a small amount of saline into the uterine cavity during a transvaginal ultrasound to open up the endometrial cavity and inspect the contours of the endometrium. It is useful in cases of a suspected pedunculated leiomyoma when a pelvic ultrasound does not detect the lesion. However, a standard pelvic ultrasound is the first step in the workup.  
❌ Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging:
Incorrect: Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can provide a more detailed evaluation of the uterus in cases where the pelvic ultrasound is unrevealing, non-diagnostic, or for surgical planning in complex cases. However, a pelvic ultrasound should be the first step before considering MRI.  
❌ Pelvic computed tomography:
Incorrect: A pelvic computed tomography (CT) scan can provide additional information about pelvic organs when a pelvic ultrasound is inconclusive or unrevealing and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is contraindicated. However, it is not the preferred method for pelvic imaging due to its limited detail of pelvic soft tissues and the risks associated with radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 18 weeks of gestation comes to the office for routine prenatal care. She feels well and has no concerns at today’s visit. She has no significant medical or surgical history. She is taking a prenatal vitamin. She does not drink alcohol or use recreational substances and feels safe at home. Blood testing from her first trimester visit shows that she is Rh-negative without antibodies. Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. She has gained an appropriate amount of weight. Fetal heart rate is 155/min on Doppler ultrasound. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following should be done during this visit?

choices.text: Oral glucose tolerance test for gestational diabetes screening

questions.solution:
This patient is currently in her 18th week of gestation and presenting for routine, second-trimester care. At this stage in her pregnancy, she should have an obstetrical ultrasound to evaluate for cervical length, placental location, and fetal anatomy.

An obstetric ultrasound should be performed between the 18th and 22nd weeks of pregnancy. Cervical length less than 25 mm increases the risk of premature birth. In such cases, vaginal progesterone may be recommended for patients with a history of preterm deliveries and a current singleton pregnancy. The location of the placenta should be determined, and the patient should be evaluated for placenta previa and vasa previa. A comprehensive fetal anatomy assessment is crucial for planning and decision-making, including providing specialized care and selecting the most suitable facility for delivery if any fetal anomalies are identified.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Obstetric ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral glucose tolerance test for gestational diabetes screening:
Incorrect: Screening for gestational diabetes is recommended for all pregnant women, regardless of prior diabetes history, between 24 and 28 weeks of gestation.  
❌ Rh antibody testing:
Incorrect: Rh typing and antibody screening is routinely performed at the first prenatal visit. In patients like this one who are Rh-negative without antibodies, the antibody screen should be repeated at 28 weeks of gestation, not at 18 weeks, and again at delivery.  
❌ Fetal echocardiogram:
Incorrect: While a fetal echocardiogram should be performed in pregnancies that are high risk for congenital heart defects (eg family history of heart defect, maternal diabetes, abnormal findings on a routine ultrasound), it is not a standard part of routine prenatal care at 18 weeks of gestation.  
❌ Tdap vaccination:
Incorrect: The recommended timing for the Tdap vaccine in pregnancy is typically between 27 and 36 weeks of gestation, not at 18 weeks. The primary purpose of administering the Tdap vaccine during this latter period is to protect the newborn from pertussis (whooping cough) by transferring maternal antibodies across the placenta.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 9-month history of anterior pelvic pain. The pain is dull and aching. She reports a constant sensation of pressure in the same area and that sexual intercourse with her husband has become painful. The pain is more noticeable when her bladder is full and is relieved with urination. She also has urinary frequency, urgency and nocturia. She does not have dysuria, gross hematuria, bowel habit changes, abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge. Her past medical history is unremarkable. She had one normal spontaneous vaginal delivery 2 years ago after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals suprapubic tenderness. Pelvic examination shows a 7 cm mobile uterus. There is no uterine, adnexal or costovertebral angle tenderness or masses. hCG is and urinalysis is negative. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would support the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Bulging of the anterior vaginal wall

questions.solution:
This 41-year-old patient who presents with chronic pelvic pain and pressure, dyspareunia, urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, and worsening symptoms with bladder filling and improved symptoms with voiding, likely has interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome. The finding of anterior vaginal wall tenderness on pelvic examination would further support this diagnosis, as the bladder is in close proximity to the anterior vaginal wall. Therefore, bladder inflammation can lead to tenderness in this area.  

Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition characterized by bladder, urethral, and pelvic pain, as well as urinary symptoms, of greater than 6 weeks duration. The typical patient is a biologic female over the age of 40, who perceives the symptoms to be originating from the bladder. The exact etiology is unknown, but it is thought to involve either a defect in urothelium protective components or mast cell activation. There may be associations with other pain syndromes such as irritable bowel syndrome and pelvic floor myalgia. Interstitial cystitis pain is triggered by bladder filling and may be noted as pain in the lower abdomen, pelvis, and back. Pelvic examination may reveal anterior vaginal wall or urethral tenderness, as well as pelvic floor tenderness.  

Diagnosis is based on a thorough history, physical examination, and exclusion of other potential causes of the patient’s symptoms, such as recurrent urinary tract infection, urethral diverticulum, endometriosis, and neoplasia. Laboratory studies should include urinalysis and culture. As there is no consensus on cystoscopic or urodynamic diagnostic criteria, diagnosis remains clinical. However, Hunner ulcers, though rarely present, if found on cystoscopy, would be considered diagnostic.


 Hunner's ulcer seen in interstitial cystitis by cystoscopy Red lesion surrounded by small vessels that radiate from a central scar  

Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Option Analysis

❌ Nodularity of the rectovaginal septum:
Incorrect: Rectovaginal septum nodularity is a characteristic finding in endometriosis. This patient has urinary symptoms typical of interstitial cystitis. Both can present with pelvic pain. 
❌ Bulging of the anterior vaginal wall:
Incorrect: Bulging of the anterior vaginal wall would suggest a cystocele, which is a prolapse of the bladder into the vagina. Although a cystocele may cause pelvic pressure, urinary symptoms such as pain that improves with urination are more typical of interstitial cystitis and not  cystocele.
✅ Anterior vaginal wall tenderness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive Carnett Test:
Incorrect: A positive Carnett test, where tenderness increases or does not decrease with tensing of abdominal muscles, suggests an abdominal wall source of pain, rather than a visceral source. This patient likely has interstitial cystitis or bladder pain syndrome. As the bladder is part of the viscera, she would not have a positive test.
❌ Cervical motion tenderness:
Incorrect: Cervical motion tenderness indicates irritation or inflammation of the cervix and surrounding tissue. It is typically associated with pelvic inflammatory disease. This patient has urinary symptoms suggestive of interstitial cystitis and not pelvic inflammatory disease.

questions.text: A 42-year-old G6P5 woman has persistent heavy vaginal bleeding after delivering a healthy baby girl weighing 6.8 pounds. The placenta is delivered intact. Past medical history is significant for asthma controlled with inhalers and hypertension currently treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure is 136/72 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination is significant for a soft, boggy, non contracted uterus and vaginal bleeding without evidence of cervical or vaginal lacerations. Uterine massage is performed and IV oxytocin and tranexamic acid are administered. The patient continues to have vaginal bleeding and a soft boggy uterus. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of grand multiparity (≥5 births) presents with vaginal bleeding following delivery and physical exam findings of a soft, boggy uterus indicate uterine atony. She is hemodynamically stable; therefore, management should proceed in a stepwise fashion. Since initial management with vaginal massage, oxytocin, and tranexamic acid have failed to control the bleeding, additional uterotonic agents should be prescribed. Misoprostol is an appropriate uterotonic agent for this patient who has a history of asthma.    

Management of uterine atony involves a combination of pharmacological, nonsurgical, and surgical interventions. Oxytocin is the first-line uterotonic agent used in postpartum hemorrhage. It should be administered in combination with tranexamic acid in patients who are stable but fail to respond to uterine massage. If these measures are ineffective, additional uterotonics such as misoprostol, methylergonovine, or carboprost tromethamine should be given. However, contraindications for the individual uterotonic agents should be considered.  

If medical management fails, nonsurgical interventions such as intrauterine balloon tamponade and vacuum-induced intrauterine tamponade, or packing are indicated. If these interventions fail to achieve hemostasis, more invasive procedures like uterine artery embolization or ligation, and uterine compression sutures should be considered. Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment but should be reserved for life-threatening hemorrhages unresponsive to all other interventions. For unstable patients, these interventions may be used in parallel instead of in the stepwise fashion that is appropriate for stable patients.  

Option Analysis

✅ Misoprostol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Carboprost tromethamine:
Incorrect:. Although carboprost tromethamine is an effective uterotonic agent, it is contraindicated in this patient due to her history of asthma. Carboprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, can induce bronchoconstriction and worsen asthma symptoms.
❌ Methylergonovine:
Incorrect:  Although methylergonovine is an effective uterotonic agent, it is contraindicated in this patient due to her history of hypertension. Methylergonovine, an ergot alkaloid, is a vasoconstrictive agent that is contraindicated in patients with hypertensive disorders due to the increased risk of hypertensive emergencies.
❌ Intrauterine balloon tamponade:
Incorrect: While intrauterine balloon tamponade may be indicated in patients with refractory postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony, it is typically considered in stable patients like this one only after uterine massage and pharmacologic interventions have failed. In this case, other uterotonic agents like misoprostol, should be tried before progressing to the intrauterine balloon tamponade.
❌ Hysterectomy:
Incorrect: Hysterectomy is a last resort treatment for uncontrollable postpartum hemorrhage. This irreversible surgical procedure should be reserved for life-threatening situations when less invasive medical, nonsurgical, and surgical interventions have failed.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 4, presents to the clinic for her six-week postpartum visit and requests sterilization. She is currently using the progesterone-only pill for contraception. Past medical history is notable for four uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal deliveries. She has no history of gynecologic abnormalities or prior surgery. Her family history is notable for ovarian cancer in her mother, diagnosed at age 65. BMI is 26 kg/m2 and the physical exam is unremarkable, with the uterus fully involuted. Comprehensive counseling is provided regarding permanent sterilization, and the patient expresses her clear desire for sterilization. Which of the following would be the best procedure/technique to recommend for this patient?

choices.text: Complete bilateral salpingectomy through a mini-laparotomy

questions.solution:
Once a patient and provider decide to proceed with sterilization, it is important to choose the best technique in order to optimize the patient’s outcome. Patients who are at least six weeks postpartum typically should undergo a laparoscopic bilateral complete salpingectomy. This method is preferred because it has the lowest failure rate and reduces the risk of developing ovarian cancer in the future. For these reasons, it is becoming the sterilization procedure of choice.  

The first step in choosing a technique for permanent sterilization is to determine the general surgical approach (i.e. open vs. laparoscopic). Additional patient factors and surgeon preferences can then guide the use of specific techniques. Postpartum procedures are performed at the time of cesarean via laparotomy or after vaginal delivery through a mini-laparotomy at the umbilicus, while interval procedures are typically performed laparoscopically at least six weeks after delivery.  



Option Analysis

✅ Laparoscopic complete bilateral salpingectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Complete bilateral salpingectomy through a mini-laparotomy:
Incorrect: In the U.S., mini-laparotomies are primarily used for sterilization procedures that are performed immediately following delivery (i.e. before hospital discharge). Laparoscopy is generally preferred over mini-laparotomies for interval procedures.
❌ Pomeroy method:
Incorrect: The Pomeroy method is a partial salpingectomy technique traditionally used in postpartum tubal ligations that are performed through an infraumbilical mini-laparotomy.  Laparoscopy is generally preferred over mini-laparotomies for interval procedures.
❌ Parkland method:
Incorrect: The Parkland method is a partial salpingectomy technique traditionally used in postpartum tubal ligations performed through an infraumbilical mini-laparotomy. Laparoscopy is generally preferred over mini-laparotomies for interval procedures.
❌ Laparoscopic occlusion with mechanical device:
Incorrect: While this is a reasonable option for this patient, it is not the best option. Complete bilateral salpingectomy is associated with a reduced risk of ovarian cancer. Given this patient’s family history, a complete salpingectomy would be the better option.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents for evaluation of primary amenorrhea. Past medical history is non-contributory. Family history is notable for hypothyroidism in her mother. The patient is a high school honors student who is active on the cross-country team; eats a healthy diet; is not sexually active; and does not use alcohol, tobacco, or other recreational drugs. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 114/78 mmHg, and body mass index is 17.1 kg/m2. On exam, the patient lacks breast and pubic hair development. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. Labs are obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of amenorrhea in this patient? 

 Laboratory value     Result add normals    
 Urine    
 Urine pregnancy test     negative   
 Serum chemistries    
 Follicle-stimulating hormone     4 IU/L    
 Luteinizing hormone     3 IU/L    
 Estradiol     low    
 Prolactin     14 ng/mL     
 Thyroid-stimulating hormone     2.4 mU/L
questions.solution:
Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menses by age 15 in a patient with normal growth and secondary sex characteristics or by the age of 13 in a patient without secondary sex characteristics. This patient has no signs of pubertal development, indicating that the issue is likely due to an abnormality in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis (as opposed to an anatomic issue). The patient’s low follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) < 5 IU/L and low estradiol levels indicates that the issue is localized to the hypothalamus or pituitary. The combination of normal prolactin plus a history consistent with potential energy deficiency (low BMI in a runner) indicates the issue is most likely functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) with suppression of the hypothalamus.       

When evaluating an adolescent with amenorrhea, the first step is to rule out pregnancy with a urine pregnancy test. Next, the history and physical should assess the patient’s pubertal development. Absence of development means there is an absence of sex hormones and localizes the problem to the HPG axis. Next FSH and estradiol levels should be assessed. Because estrogen suppresses FSH, knowing the estradiol concentration is necessary for proper interpretation of the FSH. Hyperprolactinemia and hypothyroidism should also be ruled out by checking prolactin and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).        

High FSH values in the setting of low estrogen indicate gonadal dysfunction: the pituitary is “screaming” at the ovaries/gonads by secreting excessive amounts of FSH; however, the gonads are unable to respond. For these patients, the next step is to order a chromosome analysis, which can differentiate primary ovarian insufficiency (46,XX) from Turner syndrome (45,X0) and pure gonadal dysgenesis (46,XY), also known as Swyer syndrome.        

On the other hand, a low FSH with low estradiol, as seen in this patient, indicates that either the hypothalamus or pituitary is not producing hormones to stimulate the ovaries. In these situations, the most common causes of primary amenorrhea will be a transient constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP), which resolves spontaneously with time; and FHA, which is a self-preserving pathologic suppression of GnRH in times of low energy resources. FHA is seen most commonly in patients with eating disorders and those who participate in certain types of excessive athletic activities. If the patient also has anosmia (inability to smell), suspect Kallman syndrome in which a genetic mutation results in the inhibition of olfactory and GnRH-producing neurons.    



Option Analysis

✅ Hypothalamic suppression:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Pituitary dysfunction:
Incorrect: The most common pituitary cause of primary amenorrhea is hyperprolactinemia caused by a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma; however, the prolactin in this patient is normal. Hypothalamic suppression is one of the most common causes of primary amenorrhea and fits with the patient’s history and laboratory findings. 
❌ Gonadal dysfunction:
Incorrect: Patients with gonadal dysfunction will have elevated FSH levels (i.e. > 20 IU/L, and often > 40 IU/L) and low estrogen levels. This patient has both low FSH and estrogen levels. In gonadal dysfunction, the brain is “screaming” at the gonads via elevated FSH to produce follicles and sex hormones; however, the gonads are unable to respond. This category includes patients with primary ovarian insufficiency, Turner syndrome, and pure gonadal dysgenesis (also known as Swyer syndrome). 
❌ Müllerian anomaly:
Incorrect: These patients will have typical pubertal development and normal hormone levels. They will have abnormalities, such as lack of a uterus, identified on the pelvic exam and ultrasound. 
❌ Chromosomal abnormality:
Incorrect: The chromosomal abnormalities leading to primary amenorrhea include Turner syndrome and Swyer syndrome (which both result in gonadal dysfunction [i.e. high FSH and low estradiol]) as well as androgen insensitivity syndrome (which presents with thelarche without adrenarche and elevated testosterone levels). This patient lacks both thelarche and adrenarche and has a low FSH, indicating that hypothalamic dysfunction may be the underlying cause of primary amenorrhea in this patient.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, presents with heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB), dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia. Menses are regular, occurring once every 25 to 26 days and lasting 8 days, with no intermenstrual bleeding. The patient soaks through one pad per hour for the first 3 days of her cycle, and she rates cramping on her heaviest bleeding days as 9 on a 10-point scale. Her past medical history is significant for 3 prior uncomplicated cesarean births with tubal sterilization during her last birth. Vital signs are within normal limits, and body mass index is 22 kg/m2. Pelvic exam shows a 10-week-sized boggy uterus with smooth contours that is mildly tender to palpation. No discrete masses are palpable, and the adnexa are nontender. A urine pregnancy test is negative, and serum bloodwork shows mild anemia. A pelvic ultrasound is ordered. Which of the following findings would confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Circular anechoic structures within the myometrium without posterior shadowing
A large, circular hypoechoic structure within the myometrium with posterior shadowing

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms consistent with adenomyosis, including a history of heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB), dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and an enlarged, boggy uterus with smooth contours on examination. A pelvic ultrasound demonstrating circular, anechoic structures within the myometrium without posterior shadowing would confirm the diagnosis.       

Adenomyosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, which can be clinically diagnosed based on imaging. Pelvic ultrasound is the primary imaging modality used to evaluate patients with abnormal uterine bleeding. An MRI can also be obtained if there is diagnostic uncertainty. Direct and indirect evidence of adenomyosis can be seen with both modalities. Direct evidence refers to direct visualization of ectopic endometrial tissue within the myometrium and includes the presence of myometrial cysts and echogenic subendometrial lines radiating into the myometrium. Myometrial cysts appear as small anechoic circular structures within the myometrium. Indirect sonographic features are those features that reflect myometrial changes occurring secondary to adenomyosis and include a globular uterus, asymmetrical myometrial thickening, and an irregular endo-myometrial junctional zone.    

Option Analysis

✅ Circular anechoic structures within the myometrium without posterior shadowing:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ A large, circular hypoechoic structure within the myometrium with posterior shadowing :
Incorrect: This description is consistent with a uterine leiomyoma. A large leiomyoma typically results in an enlarged uterus with an irregular contour. 
❌ Asymmetrical, irregular endometrial thickening:
Incorrect: This finding would be most suggestive of an endometrial polyp, endometrial hyperplasia, or malignancy. This patient lacks risk factors for hyperplasia/malignancy, and polyps do not enlarge the uterus. 
❌ Symmetrical, homogeneous endometrial thickening:
Incorrect: This finding would be most concerning for endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy, an estrogen-driven process that results in diffuse, symmetrical endometrial growth. This patient lacks risk factors for endometrial malignancy (irregular/anovulatory cycles, obesity, age > 45). 
❌ Symmetrical, homogeneous myometrial thickening:
Incorrect: Myometrial thickening in adenomyosis tends to be heterogeneous and asymmetrical, with more thickening of the posterior compared to the anterior myometrial wall.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, aborta 1, presents with heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) and severe dysmenorrhea. Menses are regular, occurring once every 26 days, lasting 8 to 9 days, with no intermenstrual bleeding. She is interested in having another child but wants to wait at least one more year before attempting conception. Past medical history is notable for an asymptomatic (i.e., missed) early pregnancy loss, treated with dilation and curettage, followed by two pregnancies that resulted in spontaneous vaginal births at term. Her most recent pregnancy, 2 years ago, was complicated by a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She was treated with enoxaparin during her pregnancy and for the first 8 weeks postpartum. She currently takes no medication, and her family history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits, and body mass index is 25 kg/m2. Pelvic exam reveals a diffusely enlarged, globular uterus with a smooth contour and no palpable masses. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Pelvic ultrasound shows heterogeneity in the myometrial echotexture, thickening of the posterior myometrial wall, and echogenic subendometrial lines radiating into the myometrium; no discrete masses are seen. In addition to offering pelvic floor physical therapy and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with adenomyosis, which refers to the presence of ectopic endometrial glands within the myometrium. She has a history of DVT, which is a contraindication to the use of estrogen; therefore a progestin-only option, such as LNG-IUD, is the most appropriate initial treatment that will retain her fertility.       

Adenomyosis is a benign condition, so expectant management is appropriate in asymptomatic patients or in those who do not desire intervention. In symptomatic patients with adenomyosis who are not actively trying to conceive, NSAIDs during menses with or without pelvic floor physical therapy should be offered. Additionally, because endometrial glandular growth is stimulated by estrogen, suppressing estrogen levels reduces symptoms associated with adenomyosis. Endometrial suppression can be accomplished using either combined estrogen-progestin or progestin-only contraceptives, which are both considered first-line treatments for adenomyosis.       

If initial treatments are inadequate, the next step is to offer a GnRH analog or a uterine artery embolization (UAE). Both GnRH agonists and antagonists work by disrupting the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis, leading to menopausal estrogen levels. This often results in significant symptomatic relief, though it also leads to significant bone loss and menopausal symptoms, limiting the use and tolerability of these agents. A UAE is an interventional radiology procedure that reduces uterine blood flow leading to necrosis of the ectopic endometrial tissue. However, it is not recommended for patients who wish to retain their fertility due to a lack of safety data on pregnancy following UAE. If neither GnRH analogs nor UAE is effective or acceptable to the patient, a hysterectomy is considered definitive management.  

Option Analysis

✅ Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (LNG-IUD):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Combined hormonal oral contraceptive pills (COCPs):
Incorrect: COPCs are typically an appropriate first-line treatment for adenomyosis. However, this patient has a history of hormonally related DVT, which is a contraindication to estrogen therapy. A progestin-only option is indicated. 
❌ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist :
Incorrect: GnRH agonists are second-line agents that interrupt the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, which suppresses ovarian estrogen production. Although effective, they also lead to bone loss and menopausal symptoms, which limit their use. 
❌ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist:
Incorrect: GnRH antagonists are second-line agents that interrupt the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, which suppresses ovarian estrogen production. Although effective, they lead to bone loss and menopausal symptoms, which limit their use. 
❌ Uterine artery embolization (UAE):
Incorrect: UAE can be an effective second-line treatment for people with an inadequate response to medical management, which this patient has not yet attempted. Additionally, the procedure is not recommended for people who wish to retain fertility.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old primigravid woman, at 36 weeks of gestational age, presents to Labor and Delivery triage with severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain and a headache that has been getting progressively worse over the last 12 hours. She also has mild nausea without vomiting and feels generally unwell. Past medical history is noncontributory, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mmHg. On exam, the lungs are clear to auscultation, severe tenderness is noted in the right upper quadrant and epigastric regions, and patellar reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. The fetal heart rate pattern is reassuring, and there are no contractions on maternal-fetal cardiotocographic monitoring. Labs results are shown in the table below.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Serum chemistry    
 Hemoglobin      10.5 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     6,100/µL    
 Platelet count     90,000/µL    
 Sodium      143 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride      95 mEq/L    
 Creatinine (Cr)     1.3 mg/dL    
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)     84 IU/L    
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)     98 IU/L    
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)     750 IU/L    
 Urinalysis   
 Color     Clear    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     negative    
 Blood     negative    
 Protein     negative    
 Leukocyte esterase     negative    
 Nitrites     negative
questions.solution:
Based on the presence of right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ≥ 600 IU/L, AST and ALT > twice the upper limit of normal, and platelets < 100,000/µL, this patient can be diagnosed with HELLP syndrome. The combination of all three lab findings differentiates HELLP syndrome from preeclampsia with severe features. Although not required for the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome, this patient also has elevated blood pressure, a headache, and hyperreflexia, all of which support the diagnosis of a severe pregnancy-induced hypertensive disorder.

Patients presenting with hypertension in pregnancy after 20 weeks of gestational age should undergo a thorough evaluation to assess the severity of disease and determine the correct diagnosis. The components of the evaluation and the reason to assess each component are detailed in the table above.

Option Analysis

✅ HELLP syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Preeclampsia with severe features:
Incorrect: Preeclampsia with severe features is characterized by new-onset severe-range blood pressures (≥ 160 systolic and/or ≥ 110 diastolic) alone or mild-range blood pressures (≥ 140 systolic and/or ≥ 90 diastolic) after 20 weeks of gestational age with at least one warning symptom or specific lab finding. However, if a patient also meets criteria for HELLP syndrome, as is the case in this vignette, the patient is diagnosed with HELLP because it is more specific. 
❌ Gestational hypertension with severe features:
Incorrect: If a patient has any severe features, they are diagnosed with preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome. Proteinuria may or may not be present in preeclampsia with severe features, and HELLP syndrome is diagnosed primarily based on laboratory findings. “Gestational hypertension with severe features” is not an accepted diagnosis. 
❌ Preeclampsia without severe features:
Incorrect: Preeclampsia without severe features is characterized by new onset mild-range blood pressures (≥ 140 systolic and/or ≥ 90 diastolic) after 20 weeks of gestational age with proteinuria but without severe-range pressures, warning symptoms, or specific lab findings. This patient has right upper quadrant pain and an elevated LDH, AST, ALT, and thrombocytopenia, which are all severe features. The presence of these lab findings indicates HELLP syndrome. 
❌ Eclampsia:
Incorrect: Eclampsia is characterized by the presence of new-onset seizures after 20 weeks of gestation that are not attributable to other causes. Many patients with eclampsia present with associated elevations in blood pressure, proteinuria, and/or other hypertension-related lab abnormalities. Although this patient has severe disease, a headache, and hyperreflexia on exam, she has not had a seizure and, therefore, does not meet criteria for eclampsia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G3P2, presents to the clinic with vaginal bleeding. The bleeding started as light, intermittent spotting four weeks ago, but eight hours ago, it became much heavier. It is not associated with abdominal or pelvic pain. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago, and a home pregnancy test confirmed that she is pregnant. She initially disregarded the bleeding because she had similar, light bleeding with her previous pregnancies. Both previous pregnancies resulted in the birth of healthy, full-term babies. She reports nausea and vomiting that is more severe than what she experienced with her previous pregnancies. Past medical and surgical histories are unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. No fetal heart tones are detected. Pelvic examination reveals a 12 cm, non-tender uterus, and bilateral 5 cm smooth adnexal masses. Which of the following ultrasound findings would be consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Empty extrauterine sac with a hyperechoic ring
Thickened heterogeneous endometrium with mixed echogenic material
Gestational sac > 25 mm and no fetal cardiac activity
Complex, heterogeneous intrauterine mass containing multiple small cysts

questions.solution:
This 32-year-old pregnant patient who presents with painless vaginal bleeding and hyperemesis without fetal cardiac activity and with pelvic examination findings of a non-tender uterus that is larger than expected by dates with bilateral adnexal masses (consistent with ovarian theca-lutein cysts) likely has a molar pregnancy. The pelvic ultrasound finding of a complex, heterogeneous intrauterine mass containing multiple small cysts supports this diagnosis. The cysts result from the swelling of chorionic villi. Phrases used to characterize a molar pregnancy are “bunch of grapes,” “snowstorm appearance,” or “honeycombed uterus.”    

Molar pregnancy, also known as hydatidiform mole, results from the abnormal growth of hCG producing trophoblastic tissue. This leads to significantly elevated hCG levels (>100,000 milli-international units/mL). Although definitive diagnosis requires histopathologic examination of evacuated uterine contents, ultrasound can be a useful diagnostic modality. Besides intrauterine findings consistent with a molar pregnancy, the presence of thin-walled multilocular cysts, suggestive of theca-lutein cysts, in the ovaries further supports the diagnosis. The most common type, which is complete mole, will have no fetal tissue present. A partial mole can contain fetal tissue, but it will typically be non-viable.    

The most common symptom of a molar pregnancy is vaginal bleeding. It may be light spotting or heavy and is often painless. Other signs and symptoms include nausea and vomiting more severe than usual morning sickness, pre-eclampsia, and a uterus larger than dates. In addition, high levels of hCG can overstimulate the ovaries to produce theca-lutein cysts and the thyroid gland to overproduce thyroxine.



Transvaginal ultrasonography showing a molar pregnancy   

Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

Option Analysis

❌ Empty extrauterine sac with a hyperechoic ring:
Incorrect: This ultrasound finding suggests a diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy since the empty gestational sac is located outside of the uterus. A patient with a uterus larger than dates, adnexal masses, and painless bleeding more likely has a molar pregnancy. 
❌ Thickened heterogeneous endometrium with mixed echogenic material:
Incorrect: The ultrasound findings of hyperechoic or mixed echogenic material in the uterine cavity suggest retained products of conception, which would be seen in a patient with an incomplete miscarriage. This patient's painless vaginal bleeding and pelvic examination findings better support a diagnosis of molar pregnancy. 
❌ Gestational sac > 25 mm and no fetal cardiac activity:
Incorrect: The ultrasound findings of a gestational sac > 25 mm and no fetal cardiac activity suggests a missed miscarriage, an early pregnancy loss that has not yet been expelled from the uterus. This patient more likely has a molar pregnancy. 
❌ Endometrial lining < 15 mm :
Incorrect: In a reproductive age woman, this ultrasound finding represents normal uterine lining in a uterus that does not contain a pregnancy. In this case, it would be consistent with a completed miscarriage, with expulsion of all products of conception. This patient did not report passage of tissue and more likely has a molar pregnancy. 
✅ Complex, heterogeneous intrauterine mass containing multiple small cysts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman presents to Labor & Delivery (L&D) at 41 weeks of estimated gestational age (EGA) with regular, painful contractions for the past 2 hours. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and past medical history is non-contributory. Vital signs are stable and within normal limits. On exam, the cervix is 3 cm dilated, 50% effaced, with the fetus palpable at -3 cm station, with intact fetal membranes. A bedside ultrasound confirms that the fetus is in a vertex presentation with adequate amniotic fluid. A non-stress test (NST) demonstrates contractions every 2 to 4 minutes, a baseline fetal heart rate of 150 with moderate variability, two accelerations, and no decelerations. The patient walks for 2 hours, and on repeat exam, the cervix has progressed to 5 cm dilated, 50% effaced, and -2 cm station. She is admitted to the hospital and contractions continue every 2 to 3 minutes. An epidural is placed per the patient’s request. Four hours later, the cervix is unchanged, though the fetal heart rate pattern remains reassuring. The patient inquires about the need for a cesarean delivery (CD). Which of the following should be discussed with the patient?

choices.text: Labor is progressing normally and expectant management is appropriate.
Labor is prolonged and observation is recommended for an additional 12 hours.
Cesarean delivery will be necessary if the cervix does not change after 2 more hours
Cesarean delivery will be necessary if the contractions are inadequate; therefore, an intrauterine pressure catheter (IUPC) should be placed now.
She meets criteria for arrest of dilation and cesarean delivery is recommended now.

questions.solution:
This patient is admitted to the hospital in labor, which is defined as regular uterine contractions that cause cervical change. She is in the latent phase of labor, defined as labor before achieving 6 cm of dilation. This phase of labor can be long, especially in nulliparous patients, like the one in the vignette. Latent labor is considered prolonged if it lasts > 20 hours in nulliparous patients or > 14 hours in multiparous patients. This patient has only been contracting for approximately 8 hours and, therefore, is progressing normally. Expectant management is appropriate. It is important to note that the risks of a prolonged latent phase are minimal for both the pregnant person and the fetus, so cesarean delivery is not appropriate for the sole indication of a prolonged latent phase.

If latent labor is prolonged, expectant management is appropriate with consideration of amniotomy or augmentation of labor with oxytocin. Additionally, therapeutic rest is an option, which involves administering an opioid or benzodiazepine to allow the patient a chance to rest and improve her stamina before a potentially long labor.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Labor is progressing normally and expectant management is appropriate. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Labor is prolonged and observation is recommended for an additional 12 hours. :
Incorrect: This patient is in latent labor, which is defined as regular contractions causing cervical change at less than 6 cm dilation. It is considered prolonged when it lasts > 20 hours in a nulliparous patient or > 14 hours in a multiparous patient. This patient is nulliparous and has only been in labor for 8 hours, which is considered normal. 
❌ Cesarean delivery will be necessary if the cervix does not change after 2 more hours :
Incorrect: CD is recommended for arrest in the active phase of the 1st stage of labor when there is no dilation despite 6 hours of contractions, regardless of the adequacy of contractions. At 5 cm, this patient is still in the latent phase of labor, and CD is not recommended in the latent phase. 
❌ Cesarean delivery will be necessary if the contractions are inadequate; therefore, an intrauterine pressure catheter (IUPC) should be placed now. :
Incorrect: CD is recommended for arrest in the active phase of the 1st stage of labor when there is no dilation despite 4 hours of adequate contractions, which requires an IUPC to determine. At 5 cm, however, this patient is still in the latent phase of labor, and CD is not recommended in the latent phase. 
❌ She meets criteria for arrest of dilation and cesarean delivery is recommended now. :
Incorrect: At < 6 cm of dilation, this patient is in the latent phase of labor, which may last up to 20 hours in a nulliparous patient before it is considered prolonged. Furthermore, CD is not appropriate for prolonged labor in the latent phase.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 10-month history of persistent pruritus in the vulvar area. She reports that the itching worsens at night, and that the need to scratch can feel “uncontrollable” at times. She has tried multiple over-the-counter antifungal creams without relief. There are no other areas of skin irritation. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, you observe areas of well-demarcated, erythematous, thickened skin with exaggerated skin lines (giving a bark-like appearance) on the vulva. There are also some excoriated areas. No vaginal discharge is present. Based on the patient's history and physical examination findings, which of the following is most likely to be associated with her condition?

choices.text: History of asthma and allergic rhinitis
History of multiple sexual partners and unprotected intercourse

questions.solution:
This patient presents with intense vulvar itching, which is worse at night, and evidence of lichenification on physical examination that is suggestive of lichen simplex chronicus. This condition is commonly associated with atopic conditions, such as asthma and allergic rhinitis.        

Lichen simplex chronicus is a benign vulvar condition that results from chronic, habitual scratching or rubbing. It is characterized by an “itch-scratch cycle” that can become uncontrollable. Symptoms are often more noticeable at night, and can be exacerbated by heat, sweating, and stress. It is associated with conditions that promote irritation or pruritus of the vulvar area which may initiate the itch-scratch cycle, such as atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, and psoriasis.        

Over time, the skin becomes thickened and leathery, a process referred to as lichenification. Physical examination may demonstrate erythematous, bark-like plaques with associated excoriations. Management requires breaking the itch-scratch cycle with counseling about avoiding nighttime scratching, and using antihistamines and medium to high-potency topical corticosteroids.    

Option Analysis

✅ History of asthma and allergic rhinitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent change in laundry detergent:
Incorrect: While contact dermatitis due to new laundry detergents can potentially lead to lichen simplex chronicus, such exposure would have occurred prior to the onset of symptoms, not more recently. 
❌ Recent antibiotic use :
Incorrect: While antibiotic use can lead to conditions like candidiasis due to alteration of the normal flora, this patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with a more chronic condition, such as lichen simplex chronicus. 
❌ History of multiple sexual partners and unprotected intercourse :
Incorrect: This choice might suggest a sexually transmitted infection or other conditions related to sexual activity, which could cause vulvar symptoms. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with lichen simplex chronicus, which is not directly related to sexual activity. 
❌ History of herpes simplex:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex typically presents with episodic painful blisters or ulcers rather than the chronic, intense itching and the distinctive thickened, bark-like skin seen in lichen simplex chronicus.

questions.text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding and pelvic pain for the past week. The bleeding is light to moderate, and the pain is experienced as severe cramping and achiness deep within the pelvis. Previously, when she was menstruating regularly, this patient’s cycles were heavy and painful. Review of systems is notable for constipation. Past medical history is significant for mild hypertension, managed with nifedipine. Her last cervical cancer screening was 3 months ago and showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US) with negative human papillomavirus (HPV) testing. The patient reports that both her mother and older sister had hysterectomies in their 40s for heavy bleeding and pelvic pain. Vital signs are stable, and body mass index (BMI) is 29 kg/m2. On exam, the uterus has an irregular contour, is mildly enlarged, and is tender to palpation. No adnexal masses are appreciated, and the cervix and vagina appear grossly normal. Which of the following should be performed next to confirm the most likely underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with postmenopausal bleeding and a prior history of heavy menstrual bleeding and with the physical exam findings of an enlarged uterus with an irregular contour. The most likely diagnosis is uterine leiomyomas or uterine fibroids. A pelvic ultrasound is the best next step in the evaluation. A pelvic ultrasound will be able to confirm the presence of uterine fibroids while simultaneously assessing the endometrial thickness, which can help exclude endometrial cancer.

The pathophysiology of fibroids is complex and likely to involve genetic, hormonal, and environmental factors. After menopause, smaller fibroids often shrink and disappear, and these patients are frequently asymptomatic. Sometimes, however, fibroids can degenerate, causing acute pain and bleeding as the fibroid breaks down. Uterine tenderness, peritoneal signs, and a low-grade fever may also be present. Symptoms are typically self-limited and resolve within several days to weeks.    

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Endometrial biopsy:
Incorrect: The purpose of an endometrial biopsy is to rule out malignancy. A tender uterus with an irregular contour in a recently menopausal patient with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding most likely represents uterine fibroids, which are typically benign and best identified on ultrasound.  
❌ Sonohysterogram:
Incorrect: A sonohysterogram is best used to identify intracavitary lesions, such as endometrial polyps and submucosal leiomyomas. This patient’s enlarged uterus with an irregular contour suggests intramural or subserosal uterine fibroids, therefore, a regular pelvic ultrasound is more appropriate. 
❌ Colposcopy:
Incorrect: Colposcopy is recommended if the immediate risk of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3+ is > 4%, which generally includes patients with a positive HPV screen or more advanced abnormalities on cytology. Patients with ASC-US and a negative HPV screen should undergo repeat co-testing in 3 years.  
❌ Pelvic MRI:
Incorrect: In general, an ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice for the female reproductive organs. A pelvic MRI may be used as a follow-up study for better characterization of specific findings or to assist with surgical planning, but they are often unnecessary.

questions.text: A heterosexual, cis-gendered couple presents to the office for an infertility evaluation. They report no conception despite having regular intercourse 3 to 5 times weekly for the past 12 months. The woman is 34 years old, gravida 1, para 0, with regular menstrual cycles that come once every 28 to 29 days. She has no dysmenorrhea, heavy menstrual or intermenstrual bleeding. She had one prior spontaneous conception 14 years ago with a different partner that was electively terminated with a dilation and curettage. She has a history of normal cervical screening tests. She has no history of pelvic infections or intraabdominal surgeries. Her exam is unremarkable. Her partner is a 35-year-old man with no prior children, no significant medical history, and no history of genital infection, surgery, or trauma. Review of symptoms is significant for occasional dull, aching left-sided scrotal pain that improves with lying flat. Which of the following tests will most likely be abnormal and indicate the cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
This couple presents with infertility, which is defined as no conception in couples having regular, unprotected intercourse within 12 months for females < 35 or within 6 months for females ≥ 35. The male patient has occasional dull, aching left-sided scrotal pain that improves when he lies flat, suggesting a varicocele. Semen analysis would most likely be abnormal in this patient indicating the cause of infertility.

Male factor infertility is present in up to 50% of infertile heterosexual couples and always requires consideration during an infertility evaluation. In this vignette, the male partner has symptoms suggestive of a varicocele. Varicoceles are dilations of the pampiniform plexus of the spermatic veins that can affect semen production, and they are associated with an increased risk of infertility. They are more common on the left side due to scrotal venous anatomy, and they typically present with scrotal fullness and dull aching pain that is worse with standing and improves when recumbent. Other common causes of male factor infertility include genital infections, surgery or trauma, and exposure to toxins (eg, chemotherapy, radiation).

When evaluating couples with infertility, it is helpful to remember that conception requires 5 components:

  1. Viable oocytes
  2. Ovulation
  3. Patent fallopian tubes
  4. Receptive endometrial cavity
  5. An adequate number of healthy sperm
The history should systematically assess each of these components for findings that suggest an anomaly that could lead to infertility. Specific findings associated with each of these components are detailed in the table below.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Semen analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) :
Incorrect: An HSG is used to assess tubal patency in the female partner. Tubal disease would be suggested by a history of pelvic infection, prior tubal surgery, or a history consistent with endometriosis or pelvic adhesions, none of which are present in this patient. 
❌ Anti-müllarian hormone (AMH):
Incorrect: AMH is used to assess ovarian reserve in the female partner, which does not confirm the cause of infertility but rather predicts a female’s response to ovarian stimulation. The most significant finding in this vignette is a suspected varicocele, which points to male factor infertility. 
❌ Mid-luteal phase progesterone:
Incorrect: A normal mid-luteal phase progesterone is used to confirm ovulation. Anovulation is more likely in patients with irregular menstrual cycles or other evidence of hormonal or metabolic dysfunction (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, thyroid disease), which is not seen in this patient.  
❌ Saline-infusion sonography (SIS) :
Incorrect: SIS is used to assess the uterus and endometrial cavity. Intracavitary defects, such as polyps and submucosal leiomyomas, would be suggested by irregular or heavy menstrual bleeding, which this patient lacks. Uterine synechiae may also be seen on SIS but would be an extremely uncommon finding after a single D&C in a non-infected uterus.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, with chronic hypertension (CHTN) presents to the obstetrics acute care clinic at 28 weeks of gestation with a severe headache that started that morning without improvement with acetaminophen. She has no visual changes, shortness of breath, right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, contractions, loss of fluid, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. She takes oral labetalol for her CHTN and a prenatal vitamin. Thus far the pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 182/98 mmHg. The abdomen is gravid and non-tender. After two doses of IV labetalol, blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. A non-stress test is reactive and reassuring. Lab results from her initial visit at 8 weeks of gestation and repeat labs obtained today are shown in the table below. A limited obstetric ultrasound shows a single viable fetus in the vertex presentation. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Table 1.   
 Laboratory value     1st Trimester Results     28 Week Results    
 Serum chemistry    
 Hemoglobin      12.2  g/dL     10.9  g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     6,100/mm3     5,700/mm3    
 Platelet count     195,000/mm3     155,000/mm3    
 Potassium      4.0 mEq/L     4.1 mEq/L    
 Creatinine (Cr)     0.9 mg/dL     1.2 mg/dL    
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)     20 IU/L     18 IU/L    
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)     19 IU/L     21 IU/L    
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)     300 IU/L     288 IU/L    
 Urinalysis    
 Protein to creatinine ratio      No calculation     0.3

choices.text: Corticosteroids and inpatient monitoring until delivery at no later than 34 weeks of gestation
Magnesium sulfate and immediate induction of labor
Magnesium sulfate and immediate cesarean delivery
Corticosteroids and outpatient follow-up with delivery at 34 weeks
Increased labetalol dose and outpatient follow-up with delivery at 37 weeks

questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic hypertension (CHTN) with superimposed preeclampsia with severe features. She has known chronic hypertension, which is defined as a blood pressure ≥ 140 systolic and/or ≥ 90 diastolic on at least 2 occasions, at least 4 hours apart, prior to 20 weeks of gestation. She has new onset proteinuria, which meets criteria for superimposed preeclampsia. She also has several severe features, including severe range blood pressure (defined as ≥ 160 systolic and/or ≥ 110 diastolic), severe headache, and creatinine > 1.1 mg/dL. She should be treated with IV antihypertensive agents, and receive a course of corticosteroids for fetal maturation. She should be monitored as an inpatient and delivered at 34 weeks (or sooner if the patient or fetus becomes unstable) with intrapartum magnesium sulfate.        

The acute management of hypertensive patients in pregnancy involves placing an IV, controlling severe-range blood pressures with IV antihypertensive agents, and close monitoring of maternal vital signs and fetal well-being. Further management then depends on the gestational age and clinical stability of the patient and the fetus.        

Unstable patients require magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis and immediate delivery regardless of gestational age, as unstable disease can lead to severe complications, including seizure, stroke, placental abruption, and/or death. In this vignette, the patient’s blood pressure responded to the IV labetalol. At only 28 weeks of gestation, she should only be delivered if she is acutely unstable. However, patients with severe features can deteriorate rapidly and, therefore, should be admitted to the hospital for close monitoring until delivery. This includes daily labs, daily antenatal fetal surveillance, and serial growth ultrasounds.         

Management of chronic hypertension in pregnancy is reviewed in the table below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Corticosteroids and inpatient monitoring until delivery at no later than 34 weeks of gestation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnesium sulfate and immediate induction of labor :
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate and immediate delivery are indicated when patients do not respond to initial stabilizing interventions, unlike the patient in the vignette. Because she is < 34 weeks of gestation and responded to labetalol, careful observation is preferred. 
❌ Magnesium sulfate and immediate cesarean delivery:
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate and immediate delivery are indicated when patients do not respond to initial stabilizing interventions, unlike the patient in the vignette. Additionally, vaginal delivery is typically preferred, though cesarean birth may be appropriate in critically unstable patients. 
❌ Corticosteroids and outpatient follow-up with delivery at 34 weeks :
Incorrect: Patients with severe features, like the one in the vignette, can deteriorate rapidly and should be monitored as inpatients until delivery.  
❌ Increased labetalol dose and outpatient follow-up with delivery at 37 weeks:
Incorrect: Patients with severe features, like the one in the vignette, can deteriorate rapidly and should be monitored as inpatients until delivery, which should occur no later than 34 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, presents for a routine antenatal appointment at 23 weeks of gestation. She has no loss of fluid or vaginal bleeding and has been feeling regular fetal movement over the past 2 weeks. Her pregnancy is notable for a blood pressure of 150/105 mmHg at her initial appointment at 8 weeks of gestation, and a BP of 126/90 at her last appointment 4 weeks ago. A chart review shows that her past medical history is significant for dysmenorrhea secondary to endometriosis. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Her pre-pregnancy body mass index was 23 kg/m2, and her weight gain has been appropriate. Clinically, she appears well. Fetal heart rate is in the 150s on a handheld Doppler device. Given this patient’s blood pressure readings, which of the following should be assessed because, if present, it would alter the diagnosis and management?
questions.solution:
This patient meets criteria for chronic hypertension (CHTN) in pregnancy, which is diagnosed in pregnant patients who have at least 2 blood pressure (BP) readings ≥ 140 mmHg systolic and/or ≥ 90 mmHg diastolic obtained at least 4 hours apart prior to 20 weeks of gestation. Patients with CHTN are at high risk for developing superimposed preeclampsia and should be assessed regularly for severe features of the disease that represent end-organ damage. These features include new onset headaches unrelieved by medication, vision changes, right upper quadrant and/or epigastric pain, and evidence of pulmonary edema (e.g. dyspnea, shortness of breath, and crackles on exam).        

Additional severe features that can be identified on laboratory testing include platelets < 100,000/mm3, creatinine > 1.1 mg/dL (or doubled from baseline), and liver function tests twice the upper limit of normal. Although not a severe feature, new onset or worsening proteinuria in the setting of CHTN is consistent with superimposed preeclampsia, which can occur either with or without severe features.       

Patients with CHTN are also at increased risk for stroke, renal insufficiency, myocardial infarction, placental abruption, gestational diabetes, indicated preterm birth, cesarean birth, and postpartum hemorrhage. Therefore, it is prudent to ask patients if they are experiencing any neurologic changes, chest pain, decreased urinary output, contractions, or vaginal bleeding.   

Option Analysis

✅ New headaches:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral edema:
Incorrect: Edema is common in preeclampsia. However, it is not a diagnostic feature. It is more important to assess for signs and symptoms, including new headaches, that would alter the diagnosis from chronic hypertension (CHTN) to CHTN with superimposed preeclampsia, because management would change. 
❌ Pelvic tenderness:
Incorrect: Pelvic tenderness could be seen with endometriosis. However, priority should be given to assessing this patient with chronic hypertension in pregnancy for signs and symptoms consistent with superimposed preeclampsia, which would change management if present.  
❌ Difficulty sleeping:
Incorrect: Although difficulty sleeping is a common symptom in pregnancy, it is more important to assess this patient for signs and symptoms like new headaches, that would alter the diagnosis from chronic hypertension (CHTN) to CHTN with superimposed preeclampsia. 
❌ Fatigue:
Incorrect: Although fatigue is a common symptom in pregnancy, it is more important to assess the patient for signs and symptoms like new headaches, that would alter the diagnosis from chronic hypertension (CHTN) to CHTN with superimposed preeclampsia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, with chronic hypertension (CHTN) presents to the clinic for a routine antenatal visit at 33 weeks of gestation. She is asymptomatic and without concerns. She was diagnosed with CHTN at her initial antenatal visit and was started on oral labetalol and low-dose daily aspirin. Baseline testing in the first trimester included a normal complete blood count (CBC), normal comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), and 300 mg of urine total protein (UTP) on a sample collected over 24 hours. She started antenatal fetal surveillance last week, which showed a reactive and reassuring non-stress test. A recent growth ultrasound showed a single viable fetus in the vertex presentation. Repeat labs were obtained today. After reviewing her blood pressure and new lab results, the patient is told that she should be induced no later than 37 0/7 weeks of gestation. Which of the following sets of findings would support this recommendation?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic hypertension requiring medication, for which delivery is typically recommended between 37 and 39+6 weeks of gestation. However, the recommendation for this patient is delivery no later than 37+0 weeks EGA, which is consistent with a diagnosis of superimposed preeclampsia without severe features. Findings consistent with this diagnosis include new onset or significant worsening baseline proteinuria without severe features. Because this patient had 300 mg of protein in her baseline 24 hour urine, a sudden increase of proteinuria to 600 mg without severe features, would meet criteria for superimposed preeclampsia for which induction no later than 37 0/7 weeks of gestation is appropriate.        

Even in the absence of new onset or worsening proteinuria, the presence of a single severe feature is consistent with the diagnosis of superimposed preeclampsia with severe features. Severe features include:   
  •  BP ≥ 160 systolic and/or 110 mmHg diastolic  
  •  Platelets < 100,000/mm3  
  •  Creatinine > 1.1 mg/dL or doubling from baseline   
  •  Liver function tests > 2x the upper limit of normal and/or severe, persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain  
  •  Pulmonary edema  
  •  New onset headache unresponsive to medications  
  •  Visual symptoms  
Patients with CHTN and superimposed preeclampsia with severe features should be monitored as inpatients and delivered no later than 34 weeks of gestation.  

 

Option Analysis

❌  BP (mmHg)     24 Urine protein (mg)     Platelets (per mm3)     Creatinine (mg/dL)     134/80     300     145,000     0.7    :
Incorrect: These findings do not meet criteria for superimposed preeclampsia because this 24 urine protein is not increased from baseline and no severe features are indicated. Therefore, with these findings, delivery may still be appropriate between 37 and 39+6 weeks of gestation. 
✅  BP (mmHg)     24 Urine protein (mg)     Platelets (per mm3)     Creatinine (mg/dL)     144/90   600 105,000 1.0 :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  BP (mmHg)     24 Urine protein (mg)     Platelets (per mm3)     Creatinine (mg/dL)     148/84 280 95,000 0.8 :
Incorrect: Platelet count < 100,000/mm3 is considered a severe feature. Patients with any severe feature have superimposed preeclampsia with severe features, and delivery is recommended at 34 weeks of gestation. 
❌  BP (mmHg)     24 Urine protein (mg)     Platelets (per mm3)     Creatinine (mg/dL)     138/94    290 115,000 1.3 :
Incorrect: Creatinine of > 1.1 mg/dL (or doubling of baseline creatinine if abnormal at baseline) is considered a severe feature. Patients with any severe feature have superimposed preeclampsia with severe features, and delivery is recommended at 34 weeks of gestation. 
❌  BP (mmHg)     24 Urine protein (mg)     Platelets (per mm3)     Creatinine (mg/dL)     148/112   275 125,000 0.9 :
Incorrect: A blood pressure ≥ 160 systolic and/or 110 diastolic is considered a severe feature. Patients with any severe feature have superimposed preeclampsia with severe features, and delivery is recommended at 34 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, with known chronic hypertension, presents for an initial antenatal visit at 20 weeks of gestation. She has no headaches, vision changes, shortness of breath, right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, contractions, loss of fluid, or vaginal bleeding. Past medical history is notable for 3 spontaneous vaginal deliveries. She was diagnosed with gestational hypertension during her second pregnancy 6 years ago, and her blood pressure did not return to the normal range postpartum. She is taking nifedipine and a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mmHg. Physical exam shows appropriate fundal height of 20 cm and weight is within normal limits. Physical exam is unremarkable. Baseline complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), urine protein to creatinine (P/C) ratio, and anatomy ultrasound are ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate management at this time?

choices.text: Continue nifedipine, start aspirin (ASA), order electrocardiogram (ECG)
Switch nifedipine to labetalol, start ASA, order an ECG
Discontinue nifedipine with follow-up BP check in 1 to 2 weeks
Discontinue nifedipine, start ASA, order an ECG

questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic hypertension (CHTN) in pregnancy. Antihypertensive treatment is indicated to keep BP below 140 systolic and 90 diastolic. Preferred agents include labetalol, nifedipine, and methyldopa; hydrochlorothiazide is an acceptable alternative in patients with good control who are already taking it. Because patients with CHTN in pregnancy are at high risk of developing superimposed preeclampsia, a daily low-dose aspirin, ideally started before 16 weeks, is indicated to reduce the risk of superimposed preeclampsia. Some benefit is still likely when ASA is started before 28 weeks. Additionally, a baseline electrocardiogram (ECG) should be obtained in patients with CHTN to assess cardiac status.         

This patient has good BP control with nifedipine which is safe to continue. Antihypertensive agents should not be discontinued in asymptomatic patients with normal blood pressure in the mid-trimester. It is important to remember that due to physiologic changes in pregnancy, the BP naturally decreases until it reaches a nadir around the midpoint of pregnancy before it increases again in the second half of pregnancy. Despite this apparent normalization of BP, treatment with antihypertensive agents should be continued to reduce the risk of adverse outcomes.        

In addition to ECG, baseline labs should be obtained, including CBC, CMP, and urine P/C ratio, which can then be compared to labs obtained at a later date.    



Option Analysis

✅ Continue nifedipine, start aspirin (ASA), order electrocardiogram (ECG):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Switch nifedipine to labetalol:
Incorrect: Nifedipine is one of the preferred antihypertensive agents in pregnancy. This patient is well-controlled on it, and therefore no change is necessary. Starting ASA is indicated to reduce the patient’s risk of superimposed preeclampsia, and a baseline ECG is indicated to assess cardiac status. 
❌ Switch nifedipine to labetalol, start ASA, order an ECG :
Incorrect: While ASA and ECG are appropriate, nifedipine is a safe antihypertensive agent in pregnancy and this patient has good control on it, so it should not be switched.  
❌ Discontinue nifedipine with follow-up BP check in 1 to 2 weeks:
Incorrect: This patient has well-controlled chronic hypertension and should continue nifedipine to maintain normal blood pressure. There is a physiologic drop in BP around 20 weeks, but it is important to continue antihypertensive therapy unless patients become hypotensive. 
❌ Discontinue nifedipine, start ASA, order an ECG:
Incorrect: This patient has well-controlled chronic hypertension, and while ASA and ECG are appropriate to order, she should continue nifedipine to maintain normal blood pressure and reduce her risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, presents for an anatomy ultrasound at 20-weeks of gestation. The ultrasound shows an anatomically normal fetus; however, the edge of the placenta overlies the internal cervical os and there is a marginal cord insertion. The patient is put on pelvic rest and remains asymptomatic. She undergoes a repeat ultrasound at 32 weeks, and after reviewing the findings, the physician recommends inpatient monitoring, corticosteroids, and a C-section between 34 and 37 weeks. Which of the following transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) findings would be consistent with this management plan?

choices.text: Placental edge 25 mm from the os and umbilical vessels 15 mm from the os
Placental edge 15 mm from the os and umbilical vessels 25 mm from the os
Placental edge 5 mm from the os and umbilical vessels 25 mm from the os
Placenta overlying the os and umbilical vessels not seen on TVUS
Placental edge 25 mm from the os and umbilical vessels not seen on TVUS

questions.solution:
Abnormal placentation is diagnosed on ultrasound. In this vignette, the patient’s 20-week ultrasound showed a placenta previa (i.e., the placenta was lying directly over the internal cervical os) with marginal cord insertion (which is a risk factor for vasa previa). The proposed management plan in the vignette is recommended for stable patients with vasa previa, which is diagnosed when unprotected fetal blood vessels cross, or are within 20 mm of the internal cervical os. Which would be the most likely finding on this patient’s 32-week ultrasound.        

It is possible for a placenta previa or low-lying placenta to “move” away from the internal os as the lower uterine segment develops later in pregnancy. Therefore, it is important to monitor all patients with placenta previa or low-lying placenta with serial ultrasounds to look for resolution. However, as the placenta moves away from the os, the umbilical vessels can be “left behind,” resulting in a new vasa previa and higher fetal risks. Bleeding from a vasa previa can result in rapid fetal exsanguination, so these patients should be monitored as inpatients starting around 30 to 34 weeks, receive corticosteroids for fetal maturation, and undergo C-sections between 34 and 37 weeks.        

Diagnosis and management of stable patients with placenta and vasa previa are detailed in the table below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Placental edge 25 mm from the os and umbilical vessels 15 mm from the os:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Placental edge 15 mm from the os and umbilical vessels 25 mm from the os:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a low-lying placenta. Clinically stable patients with a low-lying placenta that is ≥ 11 mm from the internal cervical os should be followed as outpatients and can undergo a carefully monitored trial of labor at term.  
❌ Placental edge 5 mm from the os and umbilical vessels 25 mm from the os:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a low-lying placenta. Clinically stable patients with placenta previa or low-lying placenta that is ≤ 10 mm from the internal cervical os should be followed as outpatients until a scheduled C-section between 36 and 37 6/7 weeks.  
❌ Placenta overlying the os and umbilical vessels not seen on TVUS:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a placenta previa. Clinically stable patients with placenta previa or low-lying placenta that is ≤ 10 mm from the internal cervical os should be followed as outpatients until a scheduled C-section between 36 and 37 6/7 weeks.  
❌ Placental edge 25 mm from the os and umbilical vessels not seen on TVUS:
Incorrect: These findings are normal. Once a patient’s findings are normal, they can be managed with routine antenatal care.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 4, at 32 weeks of gestation presents to labor and delivery triage with vaginal spotting that began 1 hour ago. She has no contractions, no loss of fluid, and normal fetal movement. Her pregnancy is complicated by placenta previa diagnosed at 20 weeks on an anatomy ultrasound. Her medical history is notable for two uncomplicated vaginal deliveries, one prior C-section for breech presentation, and a vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mmHg. A sterile speculum exam (SSE) shows a small amount of blood in the vaginal vault but no active bleeding and the cervix appears parous and closed. A non-stress test (NST) shows a reactive and reassuring fetal heart rate pattern with a baseline in the 140s and moderate variability. There are no decelerations, and a single small uterine contraction is noted that the patient did not feel. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge home with pelvic rest and return precautions

questions.solution:
This patient is at 32 weeks of gestation and presenting with a placenta previa diagnosed at 20 weeks.
