One of the lesions is unroofed and swabbed for further testing. Serum antibody bloodwork is pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Image sourced from Kohn M. Herpes simplex (HSV) in emergency medicine. Accessed March 6, 2024. http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/783113-overview

choices.text: Wait for results of lesion and serum testing to start acyclovir

questions.solution:
This pregnant woman at 31 weeks’ gestation presents with an active outbreak of genital herpes. HSV testing for the active lesions is pending as is serum antibody testing. While awaiting results, this patient should be treated now with acyclovir or valacyclovir to prevent harm to the fetus and provide symptomatic relief to the mother.    

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection during pregnancy can result in neonatal chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and skin lesions or even disseminated disease if transmitted during the intrapartum period. Therefore, active HSV outbreaks during pregnancy should be treated promptly with acyclovir or valacyclovir.     

For patients with a history of HSV with positive antibodies or those with active HSV, suppressive antiviral medications should begin at 36 weeks of gestation and be continued to delivery. In addition, a sterile speculum examination should be performed at the time of labor to prevent transmission. If, at the time of delivery, active lesions are present or if the patient has had recent prodromal symptoms, a C-section is recommended to reduce the risk of transmission to the newborn via passage through the vaginal canal. The pediatrics team should also be contacted in cases of potential neonatal HSV infection.   

Option Analysis

✅ Start acyclovir now:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Start acyclovir at 36 weeks’ gestation:
Incorrect: While suppressive therapy should be started at 36 weeks’ gestation for pregnant patients with HSV to help prevent outbreaks of genital herpes near the time of delivery, this patient should also be treated now for her current outbreak. 
❌ Start acyclovir at 33 weeks’ gestation:
Incorrect: While suppressive therapy should be started at 36 weeks’ gestation for pregnant patients with HSV to help prevent an outbreak of herpes simplex near the time of delivery, this patient should also be treated now for her current outbreak. 
❌ Recommend C-section delivery:
Incorrect: If a patient has an active herpes simplex lesion on speculum exam at time of delivery or has a history of HSV infection and prodromal symptoms at this time of delivery, then C section is recommended. However, it is currently too early to definitively decide on C-section. This patient should first be treated for this current outbreak. 
❌ Wait for results of lesion and serum testing to start acyclovir:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of active genital herpes infection. Waiting to treat would be inappropriate given the risks to the fetus. The patient should be treated with acyclovir now for the current outbreak.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 39 weeks of estimated gestational age (EGA), presents after a large gush of fluid passed from the patient’s vagina one hour ago. She has continued to leak clear fluid since that time, but has no contractions, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. Her first delivery was a full-term birth 2 years ago. She also has a history of herpes simplex virus (HSV), type 2, managed with prophylactic valacyclovir. Records show that routine antenatal screenings, including a pap test for this pregnancy, have all been normal. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. On exam, the abdomen is gravid and non-tender. A pelvic exam shows gross pooling of clear fluid on the speculum, and the cervix is visually dilated 3 cm. A non-stress test (NST) has a baseline of 150/min, moderate variability, 2 accelerations, and no contractions. Which of the following clinical findings would be a contraindication to induction of labor?

choices.text: A purple pulsating mass in the cervical canal
First delivery was standard cesarean birth
Single deepest vertical pocket of 1.2 cm on ultrasound
Two Short variable decelerations on NST

questions.solution:
Patients presenting for induction of labor (IOL) must be assessed for the presence of contraindications before initiating the procedure. In the setting of ruptured membranes, a pulsating purple mass within the cervix is an umbilical cord prolapse, which is an obstetric emergency and an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery and IOL. In this situation, the fetus must be manually elevated off the cervix and the patient taken for emergency cesarean.

IOL refers to the use of mechanical processes (e.g., mechanical dilation, artificial rupture of membranes [AROM]), and pharmacologic agents (e.g., prostaglandins, oxytocin) to mimic labor. Although regarded as safe, IOL does increase the risk of obstetric complications compared to spontaneous labor. The risks include tachysystole, non-reassuring fetal monitoring, cesarean birth, placental abruption, uterine rupture, intrapartum intraamniotic infection, and umbilical cord prolapse. For these reasons, it is important to be familiar with appropriate indications and contraindications for IOL (detailed in the table below) to minimize the risks associated with the procedure.
   

Option Analysis

✅ A purple pulsating mass in the cervical canal:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Visible Oral HSV lesions :
Incorrect: Visible Genital HSV lesions or prodromal symptoms, would be a contraindication for IOL, but the presence of oral HSV lesions would not be a contraindication 
❌ First delivery was standard cesarean birth:
Incorrect: A history of a full-thickness uterine incision that extends through the strong upper contractile fibers of the uterus is a contraindication to vaginal birth due to the increased risk of uterine rupture associated with labor contractions. However, the incision in a standard, low transverse cesarean birth (LTCB) is made in the lower uterine segment and is at lower risk of rupture than prior high-vertical incisions, and therefore, is not a contraindication to IOL. 
❌ Single deepest vertical pocket of 1.2 cm on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Oligohydramnios, defined as a single DVP of < 2 cm, at term is an indication, rather than a contraindication, for IOL. 
❌ Two Short variable decelerations on NST:
Incorrect: Non-reassuring fetal monitoring is a contraindication to IOL. However, the NST in the vignette is reassuring with its normal baseline, moderate variability, and 2 accelerations. Variable decelerations typically indicate cord compression and are common in patients with ruptured membranes. Variable decelerations become concerning when they are deep, long, and recurrent, especially in association with reduced variability, none of which is present in this vignette.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman, G1P0, presents to the obstetrician/gynecology office to establish care at 12 weeks of gestational age. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled type 2 diabetes, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and repaired Tetralogy of Fallot. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Bedside ultrasound reveals a single viable intrauterine pregnancy with a fetal heart rate of 160 bpm. One of the patient's concerns today is about pain management in labor. Which of the following carries the highest risk for this patient for general or neuraxial anesthesia?

choices.text: History of nausea and vomiting in the first trimester

questions.solution:
This patient’s pregnancy is considered high-risk by several measures including repaired Teratology of Fallot, advanced maternal age, and pre-gestational diabetes. However, only Tetralogy of Fallot increases the risk of morbidity related to obstetrical anesthesia. An important part of this patient’s care includes a prenatal consultation with an anesthesiologist to create a pain management plan for labor and delivery.

All patients whose peripartum anesthesia care may be challenging, or who are known to be at risk for significant morbidity related to obstetrical anesthesia, should have an anesthesia consultation to aid in providing quality patient care surrounding birth. High-risk conditions for complications with obstetrical anesthesia include cardiac diseases such as cardiomyopathy, and congenital or acquired disorders like repaired Tetralogy of Fallot; hematological abnormalities such as immune or gestational thrombocytopenia; and patients who do not want blood transfusions, such as Jehovah’s witnesses. Other high-risk conditions include spinal, muscular, and neurological diseases such as prior spinal cord injuries; prior vertebral surgeries; arterial-venous malformations; aneurysms; and Chiari malformations. Other diseases that may increase the risk of obstetrical anesthetic complications are those that can cause abnormal coagulation including chronic renal insufficiency and liver diseases such as hepatitis or cirrhosis.

Additional risk factors for anesthesia complications include an anticipated difficult airway, obstructive sleep apnea, body mass index greater than 50 kg/m2, myasthenia gravis, dwarfism, and history of solid organ transplantation.

Option Analysis

✅ Repaired Tetralogy of Fallot:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Type 2 diabetes:
Incorrect: Pre-gestational diabetes such as type 2 diabetes, even if it is well controlled, is a high-risk complication in pregnancy. However, pre-gestational diabetes does not increase the chances of obstetrical anesthetic complications.
❌ Age >35 years:
Incorrect: Advanced maternal age alone is considered a high-risk pregnancy; however, it does not increase the chances of obstetrical anesthetic complications.
❌ Primiparous status:
Incorrect: Primiparous status does not lead to an increase in morbidity or mortality related to obstetrical anesthesia.
❌ History of nausea and vomiting in the first trimester:
Incorrect: A history of nausea and vomiting in the first trimester of pregnancy does not increase the chances of complications if obstetrical anesthesia is given.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, G1P0, at 39 weeks gestational age presents to labor and delivery with regular, painful contractions. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Past medical history is significant for asthma. Vitals are within normal limits. Over a two-hour triage, the cervix changes from 2 cm to 4 cm dilation, and the patient is admitted to the hospital in labor. The birth plan outlines the patient's fervent desire to avoid pharmacological interventions that involve needles, due to an intense fear of needles. Her doula helps with relaxation techniques along with aromatherapy. Shortly after admission, the patient notes a large gush of fluid, and testing confirms the rupture of membranes. On recheck, the cervix remains at 4 cm. After rupture of membranes, the contractions significantly increase in intensity, and she requests pharmacological pain management. Which of the following is the best pain management strategy at this time?
questions.solution:
The patient is in active labor, with painful contractions and cervical changes, and is requesting pharmacological pain management. Her birth plan outlines a desire only to use options that do not involve a needle for administration; therefore, nitrous oxide is the best choice for pharmacological pain management currently. Nitrous oxide is self-administered using a mouthpiece or facemask, making it a good option for patients who have a fear of needles.

There are many additional benefits of nitrous oxide use. Patients have control over the administered amount and timing, maternal movement is maintained, additional monitoring is not required, and the effect quickly wears off once the mask is removed. The main adverse effects are nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and drowsiness. Of note, it can also be used during repair of vaginal lacerations after delivery.      Pharmacological pain management options in labor include systemic opiate analgesia, nitrous oxide, regional anesthesia such as epidural or spinal/intrathecal analgesia, and local anesthesia such as a pudendal block. Unless a patient has a contraindication, it is important to discuss all options with the patient.

Non-pharmacological pain management options included massage, movement, immersion in water during the first stage of labor, acupuncture, relaxation, aromatherapy, and hypnotherapy. Some patients choose to hire a birth doula, or professional labor coach, to provide one-on-one support during labor. This can be helpful, especially in patients who want to avoid pharmacological interventions.

A patient’s desires may change throughout labor. The provider should consider requests for pharmacological pain medication during labor, even if the patient’s initial plan were to avoid them. Maternal request for pain medication is a sufficient indication for pain medications regardless of initial intent.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Nitrous oxide:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intrathecal injection:
Incorrect: An intrathecal injection is a single injection into the intrathecal space that provides rapid onset of a dense sensory block; however, the effects last only a few hours and are therefore better suited for C-section deliveries. This patient requires pain management for an anticipated vaginal delivery, which may occur many hours from the initiation of pain management. This patient also wishes to avoid needles if possible.
❌ Continued relaxation techniques and aromatherapy:
Incorrect: Continuing relaxation techniques and aromatherapy is a good option in a patient who is not requesting pharmacological pain management. This patient requests pharmacological pain management, and maternal request is sufficient for administering pain medication, regardless of the initial birth plan. However, nitrous oxide is a reasonable option that allows this patient to continue with her birth plan if desired.
❌ Pudendal nerve block:
Incorrect: A pudendal nerve is generally used in the second stage of labor as the fetus descends. The patient is currently in the first stage of labor; therefore, a pudendal nerve block is not indicated. In addition, this would involve a needle which the patient has specifically requested not to be used.
❌ Immersion in water:
Incorrect: Immersion in water during the first stage of labor is an appropriate non-pharmacologic pain management option. However, this patient is requesting a pharmacological option, therefore water immersion is not the best option. Nitrous oxide is a reasonable pharmacologic option that allows this patient to continue with her birth plan if desired.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old primigravid woman presents for a routine antenatal appointment at 12 weeks estimated gestational age. She has no symptoms today other than feeling more tired than usual. The patient has a history of heavy menstrual bleeding related to a small uterine fibroid. She is a history professor and does not use alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drugs. She is of Egyptian descent. Vital signs are within normal limits. The physical exam shows the uterus is enlarged to a 13-week size, the cervical os is closed, and there is normal physiologic discharge present. There is no pallor, jaundice, or hepatosplenomegaly. The results of first-trimester antenatal screening labs are shown in the table below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin      10.3 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      31 %     
 Leukocyte count      6,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      213,000/mm3     
 Mean corpuscular volume      76 fL     
 Serum ferritin      normal     
 Total-iron-binding capacity      normal     
 Hemoglobin electrophoresis      normal

choices.text: Genetic testing for sickle cell disease

questions.solution:
Pregnant patients with a normal hemoglobin electrophoresis, such as in the vignette, should still undergo genetic testing for alpha-thalassemia if they are of Southeast Asian, African, West Indian, or Mediterranean descent due to higher rates of alpha-globin mutations in these populations. Although hemoglobin electrophoresis is a good screening test for beta-thalassemias and sickle cell disease, it is often normal in carrier forms of alpha-thalassemia.       

As the normal form of adult hemoglobin, hemoglobin A (HbA) is made up of 2 alpha-globin and 2 beta-globin chains. Each person has four alpha-globin genes. If one of these genes is abnormal, the patient has alpha-thalassemia minima, and if two are abnormal, they have alpha-thalassemia minor, also known as alpha-thalassemia trait. Although these conditions are typically asymptomatic, in both situations, pregnant patients should be referred for genetic counseling to assess their risk of having an affected child and to review options for additional testing. Iron supplementation should be avoided in patients with alpha-thalassemia mutations unless they also have evidence of coexisting iron deficiency. Since these recommendations differ from routine care, genetic testing is indicated in high-risk individuals.   

Option Analysis

✅ Genetic testing for alpha-thalassemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Genetic testing for beta-thalassemia:
Incorrect: Genetic testing for beta-thalassemia is indicated when the condition is suggested by an abnormal hemoglobin electrophoresis, including decreased or absent HbA and increased HbA2 and HbF, which is not the case in the vignette. 
❌ Genetic testing for sickle cell disease:
Incorrect: Genetic testing for sickle cell disease is indicated when the condition is suggested by hemoglobin electrophoresis demonstrating the presence of HbS, which is not seen in the vignette. 
❌ Genetic counseling:
Incorrect: Genetic counseling is indicated in patients with genetic abnormalities that have first been confirmed on genetic testing, which is not the case in the vignette. 
❌ Routine care:
Incorrect: This patient is at increased risk for carrying an alpha-thalassemia mutation based on her ancestry. Therefore, despite normal hemoglobin electrophoresis findings, genetic testing for alpha-thalassemia is indicated to determine if she is a silent carrier, which would warrant genetic counseling and avoidance of iron supplementation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman presents to the labor and delivery unit at 16 weeks estimated gestational age with progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past three days. The patient recently immigrated to the U.S. from Thailand and has not received prenatal care. She has had a significant increase in lower extremity swelling recently. She has no chest pain, cough, fever, or calf pain. Past medical history is notable for alpha-thalassemia for which she has received periodic blood transfusions. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 144/86 mmHg. Bibasilar crackles are noted on lung auscultation bilaterally. There is 3+ pitting edema in the lower extremities bilaterally to the knees. Neurologic and obstetric exams are normal. The fetal heart rate is 120/min. Which of the following complications is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Based on the patient's history of alpha-thalassemia requiring transfusions, she most likely has alpha-thalassemia major. She is presenting with signs of fluid overload (e.g., hypertension, pulmonary edema, peripheral edema) and is likely carrying a fetus with alpha-thalassemia major. The fetus should be evaluated for hydrops fetalis as the patient may be experiencing mirror syndrome.        

Alpha-thalassemia major is a hemoglobinopathy caused by deletion of all 4 alpha-globin chain genes that leads to severe anemia and hypoxia. Individuals with the condition are transfusion-dependent their entire lives, starting in the antenatal period. Severe fetal anemia can lead to hydrops fetalis, which is the abnormal accumulation of fluid in the skin and/or abdominal, pleural, and pericardial cavities. The fetus with alpha-thalassemia major usually develops hydrops fetalis in the second trimester, which progresses to fetal death if intrauterine blood transfusions are not initiated.       

Mirror syndrome can be seen in any pregnancy complicated by hydrops fetalis. It is when the maternal condition “mirrors” that of the fluid-overloaded fetus, resulting in hypertension, peripheral edema, and progressive shortness of breath due to pulmonary edema, as seen in the vignette.   

Option Analysis

✅ Hydrops fetalis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fetal polycythemia:
Incorrect: This patient has alpha-thalassemia, and therefore, the fetus is at risk for fetal anemia rather than fetal polycythemia. 
❌ Maternal pneumonia:
Incorrect: The patient is afebrile and has no significant cough, making pneumonia less likely. Her symptoms suggest fluid overload, which can be seen with mirror syndrome in patients carrying a hydropic fetus, which is the most likely complication in this case. 
❌ Preeclampsia:
Incorrect: Preeclampsia is not diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestational age. This patient’s hypertension is likely secondary to fluid overload, which can be seen in mirror syndrome in patients carrying a hydropic fetus. 
❌ Lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) :
Incorrect: Although patients with alpha-thalassemia major are at increased risk for DVT, a lower extremity DVT typically causes unilateral, rather than bilateral, lower extremity swelling. The patient's history of alpha-thalassemia and fluid overload makes a hydropic fetus more likely.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, G3P2002, presents via telehealth for an obstetric appointment. She reports a positive home pregnancy test yesterday and is currently at 6 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA) by her last menstrual period. The patient desires an elective abortion. She reports no bleeding, cramping, or pelvic pain. Her past medical history is significant for a history of mild anemia and two prior cesarean deliveries, the most recent of which was 9 months ago. She takes no medications. The patient desires the most effective regimen that will allow her to avoid an invasive procedure. After counseling, what is the best next step?
questions.solution:
In this vignette, the patient is generally healthy, early in pregnancy, desires an elective abortion, and prefers to avoid an invasive procedure. In an asymptomatic patient seen via telemedicine, a report of a positive home pregnancy test is sufficient for confirming the pregnancy. Therefore, recommending a medication abortion with mifepristone and misoprostol is the most appropriate next step for this patient.       

Patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy (e.g., bleeding, pain) or those at higher risk (e.g., patients with an intrauterine device, history of tubal surgery) should undergo an ultrasound. Additionally, for patients seen in the office, it is often appropriate to confirm the pregnancy with a urine pregnancy test and order a type and screen; however, abortion care should not be delayed for these additional evaluations. Some states have additional requirements, such as mandatory ultrasounds, waiting periods, and parental involvement, which are not generally based on medical recommendations and create additional barriers for people desiring abortion.        

Counseling about abortion management options should be viewed as an opportunity to review a patient's values, preferences, and experiences in an open and safe environment. Generally, patient preference should guide decision-making.   



Option Analysis

✅ Mifepristone and misoprostol:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Transvaginal ultrasound:
Incorrect: While a transvaginal ultrasound can confirm an intrauterine pregnancy, it is not medically necessary prior to a medication abortion in asymptomatic individuals. Mifepristone and misoprostol can be prescribed, after counseling, based on a positive home pregnancy test and known last menstrual period. 
❌ Pregnancy test in the office:
Incorrect: While an in-office pregnancy test can confirm a pregnancy, a patient-reported positive home pregnancy test is sufficient for confirmation, particularly in a telemedicine setting. 
❌ Type and screen:
Incorrect: At only 6 weeks EGA, fetal blood volume is minimal, making Rh sensitization unlikely in a Rh-negative patient. A type and screen is not required and would delay access to a medication abortion, for which she is otherwise a good candidate. 
❌ Uterine aspiration :
Incorrect: Uterine aspiration is the preferred method for a procedure abortion. Since the patient wishes to avoid an invasive procedure, a medication abortion is the preferred option.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, and severe nausea and vomiting. The patient has a history of irregular menstrual cycles, and the first day of her most recent menstrual period was 10 weeks ago. She began bleeding five days ago and thought it was her regular period. The nausea and vomiting have been worsening over the past week, and today the pelvic pain increased, and she began passing grape-like clusters of tissue. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 136/90 mmHg. On exam, the uterus is enlarged, and bilateral adnexal masses are palpated. Quantitative human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is 250,000 IU/mL. Pelvic ultrasound shows an intrauterine mass with diffuse anechoic spaces, and no gestational sac. Large multilocular adnexal cysts are noted bilaterally. Which of the following would be the most likely finding on cytogenetic analysis of an intrauterine specimen?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with a positive hCG pregnancy test with an extremely high hCG level, vaginal bleeding, passage of grape-like vesicles, and bilateral adnexal masses. Pelvic ultrasound shows a heterogenous intrauterine mass with diffuse anechoic spaces indicating a complete hydatidiform mole. Approximately 90% of these pregnancies have a 46,XX karyotype, with all nuclear DNA of paternal origin.

Molar pregnancies are non-viable, benign growths resulting from abnormal fertilization that leads to the unregulated proliferation of trophoblastic tissue and the subsequent production of excessive hCG. The trophoblastic hyperplasia produces hydropic placental villi which, when sloughed off, leads to the passage of “grape-like vesicles.” 

Common symptoms of hydatidiform moles are vaginal bleeding in the first trimester, uterine size greater than expected for gestational age, pelvic pain or pressure due to rapid enlargement of the uterus, and abnormally high HCG. When the hCG level is above 100,000 IU/L, patients can develop hyperemesis gravidarum, clinical hyperthyroidism, very early-onset preeclampsia, and theca lutein cysts (multiloculated, often bilateral, ovarian cysts that develop from luteinized follicles).

On ultrasound, a complete mole appears as a heterogeneous intrauterine mass with diffuse anechoic spaces or a snowstorm appearance, while a partial mole will often have fetal parts and an enlarged cystic placenta. Characteristics differentiating complete from partial moles are detailed in the table above.
   

Option Analysis

✅ 46,XX:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 46,YY:
Incorrect: This patient’s findings suggest a complete molar pregnancy. Although 46,YY is theoretically possible, this result is not seen clinically, likely because these embryos are not viable enough to implant. Complete moles have either a 46,XX or 46,XY karyotype.
❌ 69,XXY:
Incorrect: This is a triploid karyotype that may be seen in partial molar pregnancies. However, the ultrasound findings and extremely high hCG level in this vignette suggest this is a complete, rather than partial, mole. Complete moles have a diploid karyotype.
❌ 69,XXX:
Incorrect: This is a triploid karyotype that may be seen in partial molar pregnancies. However, the ultrasound findings and extremely high hCG level in this vignette suggest this is a complete, rather than partial, mole. Complete moles have a diploid karyotype.
❌ 47,XXY:
Incorrect: This represents a trisomy, which is a diploid karyotype plus a third copy of a single chromosome, in this case, the sex chromosome. A 47,XXY karyotype causes Kleinfelter syndrome. The vignette describes a complete molar pregnancy, which has either a 46,XX or 46,XY karyotype.

questions.text: A 33-year-old gravida 2, para 2 woman presents to the clinic to discuss recent laboratory and imaging results. Two months ago, she underwent suction dilation and curettage (D&C) for an abnormal pregnancy. The pathology report showed widespread hydropic villi, severe trophoblastic atypia, and a 46,XX karyotype. Since the D&C, she has been getting weekly human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels drawn which have been slowly increasing over the past two weeks. Family history is notable for endometrial cancer diagnosed in her mother at age 72. Vital signs are unremarkable, and body mass index is 22 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. On pelvic exam, the vagina and cervix appear normal, but the uterus is enlarged. Heart, lung, abdominal, and neurologic exams are unremarkable. Recent pelvic ultrasound showed a 4 cm heterogeneous mass within the uterine cavity, and chest radiograph is normal. Risk assessment using the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria finds that the patient has low-risk disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Single agent induction chemotherapy followed by multi-agent chemotherapy

questions.solution:
The patient’s pathology findings from D&C are consistent with a complete hydatidiform mole. Patients with molar pregnancies are at risk of developing gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). If the post-D&C hCG levels remain elevated, patients meet criteria for GTN. Low-risk GTN typically responds well to single-agent chemotherapy, which is the recommended initial treatment for this patient.

GTN is the malignant proliferation and spread of trophoblastic tissue. It is diagnosed by the persistence of hCG following a pregnancy event and occurs most often after molar pregnancies. Once diagnosed, the patient is assigned a stage and a risk score based on the initial evaluation results. In general, low-risk features include a younger age at presentation, a shorter time interval between the causative pregnancy and diagnosis of GTN, smaller primary tumor size, lower pre-treatment hCG levels, and no or few metastases.

The most common forms of GTN, including invasive moles and choriocarcinoma, are highly sensitive to chemotherapy. For this reason, low-risk disease is usually treated with single-agent chemotherapy. An overview of the appropriate management for low- and high-risk disease is presented in the table above.

Option Analysis

✅ Single-agent chemotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multi-agent chemotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. Multi-agent chemotherapy is typically reserved for patients with high-risk, rather than low-risk, disease.
❌ Single agent induction chemotherapy followed by multi-agent chemotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. This regimen is typically reserved for patients with ultra-high-risk disease, which is typically characterized by extensive metastasis.
❌ Repeat dilation and curettage:
Incorrect: After evacuation of a complete hydatidiform mole, rising hCG levels confirm a diagnosis of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Unlike most neoplasms, diagnosis does not require histologic confirmation, so a repeat D&C is not indicated. GTN typically responds well to chemotherapy.
❌ Hysterectomy:
Incorrect: Hysterectomy is typically reserved for patients with lower-risk placental site trophoblastic tumor or epithelioid trophoblastic tumor, which are extremely rare forms of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) that are usually diagnosed after non-molar pregnancies. This patient likely has an invasive mole or choriocarcinoma, which are much more common.

questions.text: A 27-year-old G2P2 woman presents to the obstetrical office with 6 weeks of depressed mood, weight gain, hypersomnia, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. The patient delivered a healthy term infant 3 months ago via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She reports feeling emotionally overwhelmed and experiencing little interest or pleasure in daily activities. She has not had thoughts of self-harm or harming the infant. The patient takes loratadine for seasonal allergies and reports no alcohol or other recreational substance use. Vital signs are within normal limits, and a chaperoned physical examination is unremarkable. A diagnosis is made. The patient requests a treatment that is safe during breastfeeding and does not require additional appointments due to time constraints. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with perinatal depression and requests a management option that is safe during breastfeeding and does not require additional appointments. The preferred option for pharmacotherapy is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as sertraline. Psychotherapy, including cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT), is also a first-line option for those without barriers such as time constraints.       

Treatment for perinatal depression is individualized through shared decision-making, taking into account the patient’s needs and whether they are currently pregnant or lactating. A holistic approach to physical and mental health includes education regarding treatment options and the importance of self-care, such as adequate sleep, exercise, and balanced nutrition. Both psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy are effective first-line treatments, and their combined use may offer additional benefits.       

SSRIs are the preferred option for pharmacotherapy. Sertraline is often favored, but escitalopram is an appropriate alternative. Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine, can also be used. For moderate-to-severe perinatal depression that begins in the third trimester or within 4 weeks postpartum, two additional options include brexanalone and zuranolone. Brexanalone is an intravenous medication requiring inpatient administration during the 60-hour infusion, while zuranolone can be taken orally for 14 days.   

Option Analysis

✅ Sertraline:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cognitive behavior therapy (CBT):
Incorrect: Although CBT is an effective first-line treatment for perinatal depression, it involves regular appointments, which does not align with this patient’s preferences. 
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines are sometimes used for acute anxiety symptoms outside of pregnancy but are recommended sparingly for perinatal anxiety and only as a temporary measure until psychotherapy, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) take effect. They are not indicated for perinatal depression. 
❌ Brexanalone :
Incorrect: Brexanalone is an intravenous medication requiring a 60-hour infusion with inpatient monitoring. It is not suitable for this patient due to time constraints. 
❌ Interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT):
Incorrect: Although IPT is an effective first-line treatment for perinatal depression, it requires multiple sessions, which does not meet this patient’s preferences.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, presents for a routine antenatal appointment at 41 0/7 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA). The patient reports no contractions, loss of fluid, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. This pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and the patient has received all appropriate routine care. Past medical history is notable for two prior uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal deliveries. The only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/74 mmHg. The patient appears well; the abdomen is non-tender with a symphysis-fundal height of 41 cm. A non-stress test (NST) shows a baseline heart rate of 120/min, moderate variability, 3 accelerations, and no decelerations. The single deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid is 3.4 cm. The patient is counseled on options regarding timing of birth, and she expresses a strong desire to wait as long as is safely possible for spontaneous labor before proceeding to induction of labor (IOL). Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: A. Antenatal fetal surveillance 2 to 3 times per week until spontaneous labor begins
B. Antenatal fetal surveillance 2 to 3 times per week, with IOL by 41 6/7 weeks EGA if still pregnant
C. Antenatal fetal surveillance 2 to 3 times per week, with IOL by 42 6/7 weeks EGA if still pregnant
D. Antenatal fetal surveillance 2 to 3 times per week, with IOL by 43 6/7 weeks EGA if still pregnant

questions.solution:
This 30-year-old low-risk patient at 41 weeks EGA wishes to wait for spontaneous labor as long as it is safe to do so. The risk of obstetric and neonatal complications increases significantly after 41 weeks EGA, although nearly 99% of individuals begin spontaneous labor by 42 weeks EGA. While it is common in practice to recommend elective IOL at or before 42 weeks EGA, it is also reasonable to offer expectant management to low-risk patients who desire natural labor up through 42 6/7 weeks EGA. This approach is appropriate when patients receive thorough counseling, maintain regular antenatal visits, and undergo antenatal fetal surveillance testing two to three times per week.        

Delivery is recommended by 42 weeks and 6 days of gestation, as pregnancies at or beyond 43 weeks are associated with an unacceptably high risk of stillbirth. Delivery is also recommended if any maternal or fetal findings deviate from normal — for example, elevated blood pressure, a non-reactive non-stress test (NST), or an abnormal amniotic fluid volume.       

Elective IOL is appropriate at any point beyond 39 0/7 weeks EGA. Therefore, clear communication and continual reassessment of the patient’s status and desires are essential when expectantly managing a patient who has reached 39 weeks’ gestation.   

Option Analysis

❌ A. Antenatal fetal surveillance 2 to 3 times per week until spontaneous labor begins :
Incorrect: Delivery is mandated by 42 weeks and 6 days of gestation, as pregnancies at or beyond 43 weeks are associated with an unacceptably high risk of stillbirth. 99% of individuals will begin spontaneous labor by 42 weeks EGA. 
❌ B. Antenatal fetal surveillance 2 to 3 times per week, with IOL by 41 6/7 weeks EGA if still pregnant :
Incorrect: It is common to offer IOL by 41 to 42 weeks; however, evidence and professional guidelines note it is reasonable to continue expectant management through 42 6/7 weeks for patients who receive appropriate counseling, regular antenatal visits, and antenatal fetal surveillance testing two to three times per week. 
✅ C. Antenatal fetal surveillance 2 to 3 times per week, with IOL by 42 6/7 weeks EGA if still pregnant :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ D. Antenatal fetal surveillance 2 to 3 times per week, with IOL by 43 6/7 weeks EGA if still pregnant :
Incorrect: Delivery is absolutely recommended by 42 weeks and 6 days of gestation, as pregnancies at or beyond 43 weeks are associated with an unacceptably high risk of stillbirth. 
❌ E. IOL now :
Incorrect: Patients with risk factors for stillbirth typically begin antenatal fetal surveillance in the third trimester (e.g. 32 weeks) and should be delivered by 39 to 40 weeks’ gestation. These risk factors include advanced maternal age; use of assisted reproductive technology (e.g. IVF); history of a prior stillbirth; and most other maternal, fetal, and placental complications of pregnancy – none of which are present in this case.

questions.text: A 33-year-old G2P0010 woman at 10 weeks’ gestation (confirmed by ultrasound) presents to the obstetrician’s office to establish care. Past medical history is significant for bipolar disorder treated with lithium and poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus. Obstetric history includes one spontaneous abortion at 14 weeks following an abnormal nuchal translucency scan and chorionic villus sampling that revealed fetal chromosomal abnormalities. After appropriate counseling, the patient desires fetal aneuploidy screening with cell-free DNA testing. Which of the following factors in the patient’s history confers the highest risk for a positive screen?
questions.solution:
The greatest risk factor for a positive fetal aneuploidy screen in this 33-year-old patient is a prior pregnancy with documented chromosomal abnormalities. Other risk factors include maternal age ≥35, a history of early pregnancy loss, and a personal history of chromosomal abnormality.       

Fetal aneuploidy screening involves non-invasive testing that assesses the risk of chromosomal abnormalities present in a fetus. Many pregnancies affected by aneuploidy are nonviable and end in miscarriage. When a pregnancy affected by aneuploidy results in a live birth, it may lead to congenital birth defects, intellectual disability, failure to thrive, infertility, and a shortened lifespan. Fetal aneuploidy screening should be offered to all patients during their pregnancy, but it is optional and may be declined after counseling.       

The most common autosomal aneuploidies in live-born infants are trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), and trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome). The most common sex-chromosome aneuploidies are 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) and 45,X (Turner syndrome).    

Option Analysis

✅ Prior chromosomal abnormality:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Although the risk of chromosomal abnormalities increases with maternal age, “advanced maternal age” is defined as 35 years or older at delivery. At 33 years, this patient’s age-related risk remains lower than the recurrence risk after a prior pregnancy with a documented chromosomal abnormality.  
❌ Current lithium use:
Incorrect: Lithium exposure in the first trimester increases the risk of cardiac defects, specifically the Ebstein anomaly. However, this is not caused by a chromosomal abnormality, so it would not result in a positive cell-free DNA test, which screens for trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome), and select sex chromosome aneuploidies.  
❌ Poorly controlled type 1 diabetes:
Incorrect: Maternal hyperglycemia raises the risk of complex cardiac defects, central nervous system (CNS) anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, spina bifida), and skeletal malformations (e.g., sacral agenesis). However, these are not chromosomal abnormalities and would not be identified on this patient’s fetal aneuploidy screening. Cell-free DNA testing screens for trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome), and select sex chromosome aneuploidies. 
❌ Gravidity and parity status:
Incorrect: Gravidity and parity do not impact the risk of fetal chromosomal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 37-year-old G2P1 woman at 11 weeks’ gestation presents to the obstetrical office to establish care and discuss fetal aneuploidy screening. The patient’s prior pregnancy resulted in a full-term, healthy vaginal delivery 10 years ago. Otherwise, the patient has no other significant past medical history. Because of a phobia of needles, the patient declines maternal serum screening and opts for a nuchal translucency (NT) scan. The NT measurement is above the 99th percentile for crown-rump-length, which is confirmed on subsequent comprehensive ultrasonography. Further amniocentesis or other genetic testing is declined. Which of the following would be the most common autosomal chromosomal abnormality associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
This 37-year-old patient presents at 11 weeks’ gestation with a nuchal translucency (NT) scan above the 99th percentile. The NT scan measures the fluid-filled space normally seen along the dorsal aspect of the fetal neck. An increased NT measurement (≥3 mm or >99th percentile for crown-rump-length) is associated with fetal aneuploidy and certain structural abnormalities. The most common viable autosomal chromosomal aneuploidies are trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome), and trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome). 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) is the most common sex-chromosome aneuploidy, while 45,X (Turner syndrome) is the only viable monosomy. Although all of these aneuploidies can present with an increased NT, trisomy 21 is the most common.       

When used alone, NT screening has poor sensitivity and specificity. If the NT measurement is normal, patients should be counseled about the residual risk of aneuploidy and may consider additional screening options. If NT measurement is increased, referral for genetic counseling, a comprehensive ultrasound examination for structural abnormalities, and a discussion about further screening or confirmatory diagnostic testing are indicated.    

Option Analysis

✅ Trisomy 21:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 47,XXY:
Incorrect: This patient’s NT scan demonstrates an increased NT measurement, which is associated with fetal aneuploidy. 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) is the most common sex-chromosome aneuploidy; it is not an autosomal aneuploidy.  
❌ 45,X:
Incorrect: This patient’s NT scan demonstrates an increased NT measurement, which is associated with fetal aneuploidy. 45, X (Turner syndrome) is the only viable monosomy. However, it is a sex chromosome aneuploidy, not an autosomal aneuploidy.  
❌ Trisomy 18:
Incorrect: This patient’s NT scan demonstrates an increased NT measurement, which is associated with fetal aneuploidy. While Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) is an autosomal aneuploidy, it is not as common as trisomy 21. 
❌ Trisomy 13:
Incorrect: This patient’s NT scan demonstrates an increased NT measurement, which is associated with fetal aneuploidy. While trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is an autosomal aneuploidy, it is not as common as trisomy 21.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 7 weeks’ gestation presents to the emergency department with progressively worsening nausea and vomiting for one week. The patient reports vomiting 9 times in the past 24 hours and an inability to tolerate oral intake. There is no abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, or abnormal discharge. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The patient has irregular menstrual cycles and had trouble with conception. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 104/70 mmHg. On examination, the abdomen is non-tender to palpation, and the uterine fundus is palpable higher than expected for gestational age. The fetal heart rate (FHR) is detected in the 130s/min in the right lower quadrant and in the 170s/min in the left lower quadrant. Which of the following medications, if used at the time of conception, would increase the likelihood for the condition explaining the fetal heart rate findings?
questions.solution:
This vignette’s findings—including two distinct heartbeats, severe nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy, and a uterine size greater than expected for gestational age—are suggestive of a multifetal gestation. Among the choices listed, clomiphene citrate is associated with this condition.

One of the greatest risk factors for multifetal gestation is conception via assisted reproductive technology (ART), such as ovulation induction (OI) followed by intrauterine insemination (IUI) or in vitro fertilization (IVF). In 2017, over 25% of pregnancies conceived with ART resulted in twin gestation, and 0.9% were higher-order multiples. Clomiphene citrate and letrozole are the two most common oral agents for OI with IUI, and both are associated with increased rates of multifetal gestation. Professional guidelines currently recommend limiting the number of embryos transferred based on age and embryo quality to reduce the risk of multiples with IVF; most patients undergoing IVF in the U.S. now receive single embryo transfers.

Other risk factors for multifetal gestation include family history, advanced maternal age, and increased parity.

Option Analysis

✅ Clomiphene citrate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Progesterone supplementation:
Incorrect: Progesterone supports the luteal phase during assisted reproductive technology (ART) cycles. If pregnancy occurs, it is continued until 10 to 12 weeks’ gestation, when the placenta is established and produces sufficient progesterone to sustain the pregnancy. Progesterone is not associated with an increased rate of multifetal gestation.
❌ High-dose folic acid supplementation:
Incorrect: High-dose folic acid is recommended for individuals at increased risk of open neural tube defects (NTD), such as those with a family or personal history of NTD, malabsorption disorders, or use of antiepileptic medications that inhibit folate metabolism. Its use is not associated with an increased rate of multifetal gestation.
❌ Daily aspirin:
Incorrect: The patient likely has a multifetal gestation. Daily aspirin is recommended for patients with multifetal gestations to reduce the risk of pre-eclampsia. But it is not known to increase the likelihood of multifetal gestation itself.
❌ Insulin:
Incorrect: The patient likely has a multifetal gestation. Insulin does not significantly increase the likelihood of this condition.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, presents for a routine antenatal appointment at 32 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA). The twin pregnancy has been uncomplicated. History is notable for two prior uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal deliveries at term, with neonates weighing 3800 g and 3900 g, respectively. The patient takes prenatal vitamins and a daily aspirin. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. The abdomen is non-tender, and the symphysis-fundal height is 33 cm. Ultrasound shows that Baby A (the presenting twin) is in a breech presentation with a fetal heart rate (FHR) of 140/min and an estimated fetal weight (EFW) at the 23<sup>rd</sup> percentile for EGA; Baby B is in a vertex presentation with a FHR of 150/min and an EFW at the 20<sup>th</sup> percentile for EGA (14% discordance). A triangular wedge of hyperechoic material is present at the base of a thick intertwined membrane. What is the most appropriate delivery plan to discuss with this patient based on today’s findings?

choices.text: C-section is indicated at 32 to 34 weeks EGA
C-section is indicated at 34 to 37 6/7 weeks EGA
Induction of labor or elective c-section is appropriate at 34 to 37 6/7 weeks EGA
C-section is indicated at 38 to 38 6/7 weeks EGA
Induction of labor or elective c-section is appropriate at 38 to 38 6/7 weeks EGA

questions.solution:
This 36-year-old patient presents with a twin pregnancy at 32 weeks EGA with twin A in breech position. A twin gestation and a lambda (λ) sign on ultrasound indicate a dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) pregnancy, meaning that each fetus has its own amniotic sac and placenta. In these cases, delivery should occur between 38 and 38 6/7 weeks EGA. Twin gestations with separate amniotic cavities (i.e., DCDA and monochorionic diamniotic [MCDA] gestations) can be delivered vaginally in two situations:

  1. Both fetuses present in a cephalic presentation, OR
  2. The presenting fetus is cephalic, and the second twin is both non-cephalic and no more than 20% larger than the presenting fetus (i.e., < 20% discordance). 

This recommendation is based on the minimal risk of fetal head entrapment during breech extraction of the second fetus, as the cervix and maternal pelvis have already accommodated the first twin. A cesarean delivery (c-section) is recommended when the presenting fetus is in a breech presentation, as seen in the vignette, and when the second twin is non-cephalic and significantly larger than the first.

Also, even patients with multifetal gestations who are candidates for a labor trial should be offered an elective c-section and counseled on the risks and benefits of both approaches. Monoamniotic gestations should be delivered via c-section due to the elevated risk of cord entanglement during delivery. Higher-order multiples should also be delivered by c-section given the complexity of these cases.
   

Option Analysis

❌ C-section is indicated at 32 to 34 weeks EGA:
Incorrect: This management plan is appropriate for patients with monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) pregnancies. This type of pregnancy is diagnosed by the absence of an intertwined membrane. The ultrasound findings in this vignette indicate a dichorionic gestation, which can be delivered between 38 and 39 weeks.
❌ C-section is indicated at 34 to 37 6/7 weeks EGA:
Incorrect: This management plan is appropriate for patients with a monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) pregnancy, which is diagnosed with a “T-sign.” The lambda sign noted in this vignette indicates a dichorionic gestation, which can be delivered between 38 and 39 weeks.
❌ Induction of labor or elective c-section is appropriate at 34 to 37 6/7 weeks EGA:
Incorrect: This management plan is appropriate for patients with monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) pregnancies (diagnosed with a “T-sign”) when the presenting fetus is in the vertex presentation. The lambda sign noted in this vignette indicates a dichorionic gestation, which can be delivered between 38 and 39 weeks, and a breech presenting fetus means a c-section is indicated.
✅ C-section is indicated at 38 to 38 6/7 weeks EGA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Induction of labor or elective c-section is appropriate at 38 to 38 6/7 weeks EGA:
Incorrect: This management plan is appropriate for patients with a dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) pregnancy when the presenting fetus is in the vertex presentation, which is not the case in this vignette.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old primigravid woman at 33 weeks’ gestation presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of worsening fever and right flank pain. There has been no increase in urinary frequency, though the patient already voids every hour and several times at night since entering the third trimester. There is no associated hematuria, loss of fluid, uterine contractions, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mmHg. On physical exam, there is right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. The cervix is closed, thick, and high on digital pelvic examination. Urinalysis results are shown below. In addition to intravenous (IV) fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?        
 Laboratory value     Result    
 Urinalysis    
 Color     Clear    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Blood     Negative    
 Leukocyte esterase     Positive    
 Nitrites     Positive    
 Leukocytes     15/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     1-2/hpf    
 Casts     None
questions.solution:
Pregnant patients who present with fever, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and urinary symptoms (e.g., dysuria, frequency, urgency) and who have supportive laboratory findings (e.g., leukocyte esterase or nitrites on urinalysis, pyuria on microscopy, positive urine culture) can be diagnosed with pyelonephritis. Management consists of IV hydration and IV antibiotics. A urine culture should be obtained prior to administering antibiotics so that therapy can be tailored to the identified bacteria’s sensitivities.       

In pregnancy, pyelonephritis is associated with an increased risk of maternal sepsis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and preterm labor. For this reason, affected patients are admitted for inpatient care and treated with IV antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone, until they show signs of clinical improvement.        

Once symptoms improve and the patient has been afebrile for at least 24 hours, therapy may be switched to oral antibiotics to complete a 14-day course. If there is no improvement within 48 to 72 hours of initiating IV antibiotics, an evaluation for antibiotic resistance is indicated. A renal ultrasound is also often appropriate to exclude alternative pathology, such as an infected kidney stone that may require urologic intervention.   




Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous (IV) antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral antibiotics:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics are appropriate for acute cystitis or asymptomatic bacteriuria. However, this patient has a fever and flank pain, indicating the infection has spread to the upper urinary tract. IV antibiotics are now required. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) analgesics:
Incorrect: IV analgesics and hydration are used to treat nephrolithiasis, which typically presents without fever or positive nitrites and leukocyte esterase on urinalysis. While analgesics can help control pain in pyelonephritis, IV antibiotics remain the priority. 
❌ Alpha blocker:
Incorrect: Alpha blockers (antagonists) are often given in cases of nephrolithiasis to relieve ureteral spasm. However, this patient’s fever, flank pain, and urinalysis findings indicate pyelonephritis, which requires IV antibiotic therapy. 
❌ Renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Renal ultrasound is indicated when nephrolithiasis is suspected, which typically presents with flank pain and hematuria without signs of infection. This patient’s fever, flank pain, and urinalysis findings suggest pyelonephritis, which requires IV antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 20 weeks’ gestation with dichorionic twins presents for a routine prenatal ultrasound. The patient struggled to conceive and ultimately became pregnant using assisted reproductive technology (ART). Obstetrical history includes two prior uncomplicated cesarean births over 10 years ago with a previous partner. A 6 cm subserosal pedunculated uterine fibroid was laparoscopically removed 3 years ago. The patient is asymptomatic and appears well. The ultrasound shows normal anatomy in both fetuses. The placenta of fetus A invades into the myometrium. Which of the following historical features is this patient’s most significant risk factor for the suspected placental complication?
questions.solution:
This 39-year-old patient with a history of two prior cesarean births presents with ultrasound evidence of placental invasion into the myometrium. This finding is known as placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), which results in a firmly adherent placenta that fails to separate from the uterus after birth. The two strongest risk factors are a history of cesarean delivery (CD) (with the risk increasing with each additional CD) and placenta previa. Other risk factors include prior uterine surgery, advanced maternal age, multiparity, and intrauterine adhesive disease (e.g. Asherman syndrome).

PAS is usually asymptomatic prior to birth but can cause life-threatening hemorrhage at delivery. Antenatal multidisciplinary delivery planning is recommended to reduce maternal morbidity because complex surgery is often required immediately after birth. Absence of suggestive ultrasound findings does not exclude PAS. Therefore, clinical risk factors, particularly multiple prior CDs and/or placenta previa, are as important as ultrasound findings when predicting and planning for PAS.

Option Analysis

✅ Prior cesarean deliveries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prior uterine fibroid removal:
Incorrect: A prior myomectomy is a risk factor for placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) when it involves endometrial scarring. However, a large subserosal pedunculated fibroid can be removed without entering the uterine cavity. Therefore, this carries far less risk than a history of prior cesarean deliveries.
❌ Use of assisted reproductive technology (ART):
Incorrect: ART is associated with a modest increase in placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) risk but is far less significant than the risk from a full-thickness uterine incision, such as one created during a cesarean delivery.
❌ Multifetal gestation:
Incorrect: Multifetal gestation is a risk factor for placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), but it is much less significant than the risk from a full-thickness uterine incision, such as one created during a cesarean delivery.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Advanced maternal age (typically defined as ≥ 35 years) is a risk factor for placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) but carries less risk than a prior cesarean delivery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the OB/Gyn clinic with involuntary leakage of urine for the past year. The leakage occurs primarily with coughing, sneezing, or exercises. The patient has had three full-term vaginal deliveries and has a history of chronic constipation but has not had any other gastrointestinal symptoms. Medical history is significant for obesity with a BMI of 32 kg/m². The patient is not taking any medications and there is no family history of urinary incontinence.  Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72 bpm, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals mild pelvic floor muscle weakness and mild prolapse of the posterior vaginal wall. A cough stress test is positive for urine leakage, and a post-void residual volume is 50 mL. Which of the following is a risk factor for the patient's suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with involuntary urine leakage during activities such as coughing, sneezing, and exercising, which are classic signs of stress urinary incontinence (SUI). Risk factors for SUI include prior pregnancy, chronic constipation, and obesity, all of which are present in this patient. These factors contribute to pelvic floor muscle weakening and increased intra-abdominal pressure, leading to the characteristic urine leakage during physical exertion.

A thorough history and physical examination are crucial in evaluating urinary incontinence. Key aspects of the history include the onset, duration, and severity of symptoms, as well as any associated factors such as fluid intake, bowel habits, and medication use. The physical examination should assess pelvic floor muscle strength, identify any pelvic organ prolapse, and include a cough stress test to observe for involuntary urine leakage. Additionally, measuring the post-void residual (PVR) volume helps rule out significant urinary retention. Key historical and physical examination findings for the different types of urinary incontinence are summarized in the table below.


Option Analysis

❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus is more commonly associated with overflow or urge incontinence due to potential diabetic neuropathy affecting bladder function. However, this patient's symptoms of urine leakage during physical exertion are more consistent with stress urinary incontinence.
✅ Constipation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diuretic use:
Incorrect: Certain medications, especially diuretics, can contribute to urgency urinary incontinence rather than stress urinary incontinence, which is the likely diagnosis in the vignette.
❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Multiple sclerosis is a neurological condition that can cause urgency or overflow urinary incontinence due to bladder dysfunction. However, the patient's symptoms of urine leakage during coughing, sneezing, and exercising are characteristic of stress urinary incontinence.
❌ Pelvic organ prolapse:
Incorrect: While pelvic organ prolapse can contribute to urinary incontinence, it is often linked to mixed or overflow incontinence, depending on the severity and nature of the prolapse. This patient's specific symptoms of leakage with exertion point more towards stress urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office with involuntary urine leakage over the past 6 months. The patient reports regular dribbling of urine, a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying, nocturia, urinary frequency, and a weak urinary stream. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus with mild peripheral neuropathy, obesity, and a stroke 3 years ago. Current medications include metformin and aspirin. There is no history of pelvic surgery. The patient does not use tobacco and has no relevant family history. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diminished lower extremity reflexes and reduced anal sphincter tone, with no evidence of pelvic organ prolapse. A urinalysis is negative for nitrites, leukocyte esterase, and blood. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of regular dribbling of urine, a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying, nocturia, urinary frequency, and a weak urinary stream are highly suggestive of overflow urinary incontinence (OUI). A medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus with peripheral neuropathy and a prior stroke increases the likelihood of detrusor muscle underactivity, which can impair bladder emptying. A post-void residual (PVR) test, which measures the amount of urine left in the bladder after voiding, is the key diagnostic test for OUI. An elevated PVR confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating the inability of the bladder to empty completely.

To further evaluate the underlying cause of urinary incontinence, additional tests may be necessary. Urodynamic testing can assess bladder function and detrusor muscle activity, helping to identify issues such as detrusor underactivity or bladder outlet obstruction. Pelvic ultrasound or cystoscopy may be employed to visualize anatomical abnormalities or obstructions, such as tumors or severe pelvic organ prolapse. A thorough evaluation of the patient's neurological status, including tests for peripheral neuropathy or other neurologic conditions, is also essential to identify contributing factors.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cough stress test:
Incorrect: This test is primarily used to diagnose stress urinary incontinence, which is characterized by urine leakage during physical exertion, coughing, or sneezing. This patient's symptoms of incomplete bladder emptying and continuous dribbling are more consistent with overflow incontinence, making the cough stress test less useful for confirming the diagnosis.
❌ Test of urethral hypermobility:
Incorrect: This test is used to evaluate for stress urinary incontinence by measuring the displacement of the urethra-bladder neck during a Valsalva maneuver. However, this patient's presentation is more consistent with overflow incontinence.
✅ Post-void residual (PVR) measurement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: While pelvic ultrasound can help identify anatomical abnormalities, it is not the key diagnostic test for overflow urinary incontinence. The primary issue in this case is the functional aspect of incomplete bladder emptying, which is best assessed with a PVR measurement.
❌ Urodynamic testing:
Incorrect: Although urodynamic testing can provide valuable information about bladder function and is useful in complex cases, it is not the initial key test for suspected overflow urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a partner, reporting a fall down the stairs while carrying laundry 2 days ago, now with severe wrist pain. No other injuries or loss of consciousness are reported. The partner repeatedly comments, “She’s always been clumsy.” There is no significant past medical or surgical history, no current medications, and no known drug allergies. Review of medical records reveals two prior emergency department visits in the past 6 months for a concussion and rib contusion, both attributed to accidental falls. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 124/78 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the patient appears anxious and frequently glances toward the partner. There is tenderness and swelling over the left wrist with limited range of motion, along with faint facial bruising. Which of the following additional findings would most strongly support the diagnosis of concern?

choices.text: Circumferential bruises on the patient’s wrists bilaterally

questions.solution:
This patient’s repeated injuries and the partner’s dismissive comments raise concern that the injuries may not be accidental. Injuries that are inconsistent with the reported mechanism, including patterned or constriction bruises, should heighten suspicion for intimate partner violence (IPV). In this context, circumferential bruises on both wrists are inconsistent with a fall down the stairs, raise concern for restraint-related injury, and should prompt evaluation for IPV.   

When evaluating possible intimate partner violence or sexual assault, perform a careful assessment that documents all injuries, with attention to patterns that are inconsistent with the history. Screen for psychological and physical abuse, and assess immediate safety and available supports. Use a trauma-informed approach that is respectful, nonjudgmental, and supportive to facilitate disclosure and connection to resources.   

Findings that should raise suspicion include repeated emergency visits, inconsistent explanations, injuries in various stages of healing, patterned bruising such as fingertip or ligature marks, head or neck trauma, and visible fearfulness. Anxiety, depression, chronic pain, and other psychosocial concerns are common but nonspecific. During the examination, emphasize privacy, choice, and control. Describe each step and obtain verbal consent as the examination proceeds. Ask partners or caregivers to leave the room to allow private questioning and examination, recognizing that a companion may resist leaving and may pose a safety risk.   

P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced intimate partner violence, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope for Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources   

Option Analysis

❌ Bruises on the shins bilaterally:
Incorrect: Shin bruises are common accidental injuries and are not specific for abuse. Such injuries could occur in the described fall and would not be highly suspicious for intimate partner violence, the diagnosis of concern.  
❌ Positive chlamydia test:
Incorrect: A positive chlamydia test indicates recent infection, which may be acquired through consensual or nonconsensual sexual activity. On its own, it is nonspecific and does not confirm intimate partner violence, the diagnosis of concern in this case. 
❌ Positive pregnancy test:
Incorrect: A positive pregnancy test suggests pregnancy and is an important clinical finding, but it does not provide direct evidence of physical or sexual abuse.  
❌ Long-standing history of depression:
Incorrect: Depression may result from many causes, including past trauma, but it is not specific for intimate partner violence. 
✅ Circumferential bruises on the patient’s wrists bilaterally:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
